output: Thank you, Mr. President. I very much welcome the approach we describe in the White Paper, that we get to the bottom of the causes of malnutrition and obesity and the resulting diseases.
Unfortunately, in European food policy, whether we're talking about nerve profiles, food labeling, or even in some parts of the White Paper, we fall back on a very one-sided approach.
We are trying to solve the problems we have in Europe through product policy.
And I believe it is fundamentally the wrong approach to assume that there are good and bad foods.
Many proposed amendments demonstrate this. It does not exist.
There are only good and bad, or balanced and unbalanced, ways of eating.
This should be our approach.
The causes of poor nutrition are multifaceted.
Trying to solve this by guiding consumers through product labeling, or even by imposing advertising bans or regulations, or by using different VAT rates, will not achieve our goal.

I believe that everything we do here - and I don't want to preempt the debate on the labeling regulation - should be framed under the heading of what we can do to motivate consumers to think about their eating habits.
In my opinion, a traffic light labeling that suggests to him that I am now facing a good or bad product is more an instrument of disempowerment than an instrument of education and enlightenment.
That is why I hope for a balanced approach here and the realization that the path through product policy alone will not take us further. Thank you.
Madam President, Madam Vice-President, dear colleagues, budgetary control is not about new issues.
We are satisfied with the old ones and would also be satisfied with progress on the old topics.
Five points in the first place. Our urgent plea for support for Romania and Bulgaria in building the rule of law, the judiciary, and financial control.
We do not want to be where we are today in two years, and that is why this point is very, very important to us.
The second point is the declaration of assurance for the overall budget following the tiered audit procedure, involving the national audit offices.
It would be great if we could make decisive progress in the last six months, which are left to the Commission, or at least agree on a common path.
One becomes modest as a household controller.
The third point would be simplification
We need to provide more help to the lower administrative levels of the Member States in implementing EU law
It turns out that they are completely overwhelmed by large parts of EU law. This is also why the error rates are so high.
The fourth point, foreign aid, here I would like to address primarily Kosovo and the question of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Committee on Budgetary Control has been to Kosovo, and I would like to announce that Kosovo will play a certain role in the budget discharge.
I believe that we have fallen far short of the European Union's capabilities so far and that we urgently need to catch up in this area.
The fifth point would be to improve cooperation between member states in combating fraud.
We have homework here, primarily for the members of the Council.
In November, Parliament will vote on the legal basis, the anti-fraud regulation, and then we will have to consider together how to proceed if we want to achieve better results in this area.
And that has been our common wish so far, at least.
Thank you, Mr. President. India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other at all levels, especially at the level of so-called ordinary people.
Business travelers, tourists, students, and so on. A brief note on this. It also has significance for the Commission's legislative program, which we discussed earlier.
In global air travel, we need good safety regulations. Ones that are effective and not just a mere formality.
It would therefore be a sensible, truly necessary measure to finally abolish the nonsensical liquid regulations and come up with something better.
I voted for the resolution because it is a clear call on the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled with the questionable, indeed fraudulent, parliamentary elections in September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of the opposition and civil society.

At the same time, we have today called on the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between the peoples and to democratize the country by seriously considering the possibility of a
Consider reducing visa fees for Belarusian citizens when entering the Schengen area, thereby preventing increasing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
First of all, I would like to refute the notion, which I heard just a few minutes ago, that foreigners are flooding our job market.
And secondly, I would have liked a clearer, more unambiguous report from the Employment Committee.
Trust in the social cohesion of the European Union can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States and the European Court of Justice and not be satisfied with merely calling for a balance between fundamental rights and the freedoms of the internal market and free movement.
We are not changing anything with this. Fundamental social rights, like freedom rights, are human rights that must not be restricted by the free movement within the internal market.
And it is about defending and improving the European social model. And it is high time for the introduction of a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU treaties.
And it is time to change the Posting of Workers Directive so that wage and minimum standards requirements cannot be limited to minimum requirements. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr President. I would like to join in thanking the rapporteur, Doris Pack, a sentiment that has already been expressed by many of my colleagues, and quite rightly so.
We have someone with her who, hopefully, doesn't actually shed her heart and soul, but invests a great deal of heart and soul into this space.
I am pleased with her and the colleagues who have also said that there has been some progress, including in the area of police cooperation.
This is important so that actual life on the ground can also function in reasonable ways.

However, I still believe that we must repeatedly remind our interlocutors in Bosnia and Herzegovina that a great deal still needs to be contributed by them, by your side, much more than is currently being contributed in some areas.
The internal cooperation, the willingness to engage in this internal cooperation within the ethnic groups is something that we must constantly demand.
It's not a case of everyone trying to go their own way.
and also the integration into the regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is important.
Thank you, Madam President. The distance between the European Union and its citizens must not become as great as it has become.
We need to make sure it is reduced in size.
In this context, the Ombudsman has an important task, especially when and where he does it well.
Above all, it is also about the fact that we must expect the Ombudsman to act with commitment and a sense of proportion.
The point is that we should not raise expectations that are too high for anyone to meet.

However, on the other hand, it is also about ensuring that wherever shortcomings have occurred in the administration of European institutions, these are addressed and, where possible, reasonable solutions are sought that can then reassure and satisfy the citizens.
Experience to date has shown that the Ombudsman takes this task seriously and does a good job of it.
We can hope that this will continue to be the case and thank him and the rapporteur for this report.
Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, ten years after the realization of monetary union, Europe is in a severe crisis.
Banks are collapsing or are being supported with billions of dollars from the state budget. Sales are plummeting and millions of people are worried about their jobs and their future.
But it is not only the market that has failed. The ruling politics also seem incapable of learning from their mistakes.
We are of the opinion – and we do not wish to make a particular impression with such interim remarks – that serious mistakes were made in the construction of the Economic and Monetary Union.
One such mistake is the structural separation of monetary and fiscal policy. You cannot create a common currency without simultaneously harmonizing tax and spending policies, at least to some extent.
I think the economic imbalances in the Eurozone have become enormously worse.
And what we need now is indeed better coordination of economic and, above all, tax policies.
We need effective measures against tax dumping. Moreover, tax havens must be closed and capital flows finally controlled again.
We see the second serious mistake in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

Anyone who considers household consolidation to be inevitable in times like these is obviously living in a different world. There would be nothing more disastrous than responding to this economic crisis with public austerity programs.
The Stability Pact has clearly demonstrated its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our opinion, what is needed is an investment offensive to renew public infrastructure and improve the situation of the socially disadvantaged in Europe.
We see a third mistake in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is solely committed to the goal of price stability.

We advocate for democratic control of the European Central Bank. Furthermore, we demand a correction of the ECB's monetary policy mandate, in which growth and employment must be promoted at least equally with price stability in the future.
The current crisis also offers an opportunity for profound reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This opportunity should not be squandered lightly.
Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, honourable Members. Indeed, the automotive industry is in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
The financial crisis, in particular, has accelerated the crisis in this sector, and member states are currently working on solutions.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
And that is why we need European solutions for this key European industry in order to overcome the crisis.
Almost all car companies have European structures.

In order to make the necessary investments in environmentally friendly cars, as has been mentioned several times here today, and to implement environmentally friendly and fuel-efficient technologies, car manufacturers need public guarantees or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
But the supplier industry, and this is very important to me, must not be forgotten in this context.
It is precisely in the supply industry, in small and medium-sized enterprises, where jobs are created and where innovations take place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
In the last plenary session, the Council President made a proposal to protect key industries.
A good proposal, in my opinion. If one consistently follows through on this idea, this proposal, it would mean a Volkswagen law for the entire European automotive industry.
and this would certainly be a good instrument
But this protective instrument is currently being fought against by the European Commission.

And that brings me to my question to the Commission: will the European Commission persist with a lawsuit despite the crisis in the automotive industry, or will it change course in light of the crisis?
Dear Mr President, Mr President of the European Court of Auditors, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, dear colleagues, it has indeed become a tradition to note that
it is not possible to issue a declaration of assurance for the second time in relation to the ratio between expenditure at European level and administration at national level.

I can recall conversations with the former President of the Court of Auditors, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that due to the structures in place, it is not at all possible to provide a statement of assurance.
That is why we should start thinking about how this instrument can be brought to life in such a way that the goal of a declaration of assurance can be achieved when it is justified.
And of course, we need to distinguish a few things from each other here.
Firstly, a budget that contains around 95% subsidies is much more susceptible to fraud than a national budget, or a regional or a municipal budget.

A subsidy budget, which is essentially managed by the member states, who have demanded much more independence from us in the new financial period, because the criticism in the last funding period was that too much was centrally controlled.
Of course, this also means that responsibility for the money must be taken on at regional and national levels.
And in the third topic area, I just want to briefly address,
we must also learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
these are also things that are always thrown together
I also get annoyed when EU money is used to fund things that are not absolutely necessary.
but that was not fraud, that was waste

And that is why those who are responsible for the projects, especially in the area of structural policy, the Member States, also have the responsibility to ensure that money is not wasted and that only those projects are funded that really create added value for the region.
That's why we should consider converting parts of the structural policy into interest-free loans.
If Member States have to repay funds, they will only promote what they really need. Thank you very much.
It is not just me who finds it difficult to agree with the emerging self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to dealing with the financial market crisis.
Because if Europe, if this EU were a functioning democracy, one would first have to ask the question about responsibility and how all of this could have happened.
It is simply not true that all the problems we are facing now are a tsunami, something that is governed by natural law, but rather it is man-made.
And with all the regulatory zeal that has characterized this Union, one wonders why no action was taken when banks began to cross national borders on a significant scale.
Why, despite appropriate warnings, did no action take place when derivatives crept in like this?
I remember well that Nobel laureate Joseph Stiglitz was here and addressed all these points.
There was a silence, there was a taboo.
That is where one must start, because recognizing one's own mistakes is the only key to finding solutions in the future.
Thank you, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, my question is about what you think of Iceland and Hungary introducing the euro as a second currency.
Do you think that could solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is, do you believe it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which would then be used to strengthen the banks' equity capital?
My third question is, do you not believe that a reduction in value added tax would accordingly support imports, especially from China and India?
wouldn't it be more sensible to consider tax reductions for our businesses and for our employees, to pay investment premiums, and to adjust the progressive depreciation accordingly?
The focus is on increasing low-value economic goods by a factor of 10, so that apparent profits are not taxed, the money remains in the businesses, and wages can be paid better.
Thank you, Madam President. The comprehensive report illustrates how many human rights violations occur in the world on a daily basis.
This is particularly alarming 60 years after the declaration of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and calls on us to intensify our efforts.
This is also why I would like to advocate for establishing the current Subcommittee on Human Rights as a main committee.
Today we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Hu Jia, who campaigns for human rights and the environment in China.
However, because he is incarcerated, he was unable to take possession of it in person.
Shame on China! And tomorrow, a debate on human rights violations in Russia will take place here.
In our relations with these two countries, not only economic interests, but above all human rights, must be given a higher priority.
We demand freedom for Hujia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, Commissioner, dear colleagues, as rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, one gains interesting experiences, such as the fact that everyone talks about combating fraud and then no one does anything.
Or the experience that the member states calculate their payments to the European Union with sharp pencils, but when it comes to spending this money, they loosen their purse strings.
and even make it easy for fraudsters. For example, by the fact that it still takes an average of 36 months for irregularities to be reported to the European Union at all.
The European Parliament disagrees with this.
We want efficient fraud prevention that also includes prevention.
We want the member states to make the fight against fraud a priority and for us to discuss the necessities and challenges together.
We want to see greater interest from national judicial authorities in following up on OLA mediation results.
In the case of curved routes, there can no longer be areas free of right-of-way as has been the case up to now.
We need to equate European money with national money.
We want an independent agency that has the necessary resources and legal basis to fulfill its tasks.
And we want an office that can work smoothly and efficiently with the member states.
Our opinion on the legal basis 1073-99 covers all these points.
We advocate for the further development of this regulation as the core of the anti-fraud office, in collaboration with the Council.
We urge the Council to incorporate our opinion. We urge the Council to begin discussions on the further development of this regulation.
We want to channel Olaf's problems towards a solution.
And I thank all the factions of the High House for supporting this in a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech Council Presidencies to take up Parliament's ball and pass it back.
In our proposals, we have also incorporated solutions developed and submitted by the Council working group.
On our part, I can tell you that we are interested in a swift conclusion of this regulation and assure you of our constructive willingness to engage in discussions based on our proposals.
Consolidation of all Olaf legal bases, as the Council has indeed planned, means a further considerable loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
Olaf is soon going to celebrate his 10th birthday.
Consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
We take the fight against fraud too seriously for that.
That is why we want to implement what is feasible now in cooperation with the Council.
Thank you very much.
Mr President, I would like to take up a point that my Austrian colleague Paul Rübig raised earlier.
We spend less than one percent of European GDP on Europe. At the same time, we demand that the European Union should handle an increasing number of tasks for an increasing number of member states.
This accounting cannot add up. It is therefore truly unbelievable that we have been implementing austerity measures for many years, but not only in the area of economical sales management.
It is not about using our funds effectively, but rather about allowing finance ministers to collect money at the end of the year and incorporate it into their domestic budgets.
We would have enough new tasks for which we should spend our money.
We also have tasks that we have not really adequately budgeted for in years.
I believe that the European Union's information funding needs to be significantly increased if we really want to connect European citizens to Europe.
And there are many tasks in the area of student and apprentice exchange that Europe could deploy here.
is also advancing in the justice sector, a traditionally state-reserved area.
This corresponds to the changed living conditions of people in our Union.
But, and this point has already been made several times, integration must not interfere too much with traditionally established structures, especially those that are already functioning well.
Not everything can be lumped together.
Public records and public notaries are structured quite differently in many member states.
In Austria, but not only in our country, the notary's office as a public registry has a long tradition and a high level of security and trust.
This should not be jeopardized unnecessarily, just because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore integration and mutual openness, yes, but with a sense of proportion.
Thank you, Madam President. Honourable colleagues, plant protection products have been and remain essential inputs for agriculture.
Farmers need a minimum selection of plant protection products because it is about protecting the native cultural landscape, providing high-quality nutrition, and conserving resources.
We discuss chemicals all too often on a very irrational level.
But in order to get sensible results, we must think and act rationally.

The consequences of the original parliamentary position would have been disastrous. A broad ban on plant protection products would have led to lower agricultural yields and, ultimately, rising food prices.
Therefore, I am glad that a barely acceptable compromise was found in the trilogue negotiations.
It is commendable that we have maintained the three-zone system, albeit with significant exceptions for the member states.

A courageous step towards a consistent internal market solution would look different. In addition to acceptable compromises, we should not pre-empt a final definition of endocrine-active substances, but actually give the EU Commission the four years of time to present a scientifically sound definition.
Otherwise, we would be stretching the precautionary principle at this point.
And finally, I find it regrettable that we have not managed to initiate a follow-up assessment of the agreement that has now been reached. Thank you again.
The last time similar opinion polls were conducted during a visit by a head of government or state, the President of this House intervened massively.
At that time, it was about an issue that was important to him personally, namely the Lisbon Treaty.
When the president, the sovereignly elected president of a country, speaks today and is massively interrupted and disturbed by the socialist side, the president does not intervene.
Do you know what that is?
This is not democracy, this is arbitrary rule, and I demand that appropriate measures be taken.
Children and politics, rarely do the interests of citizens and politicians diverge so widely.
The issue of children is at the top of the agenda for citizens across Europe.
For politicians, children's interests are a distant concern, as we can see once again here.
I know of no country that has its own Ministry for Children. Nor does the Commission have its own representative for the interests of our youngest citizens.
The issue of children is spread across all parliamentary committees.
That is why I would like to particularly emphasize to the Commission at this point that it is dealing with childcare facilities and the Barcelona objectives today.
Thank you. In our parliamentary working group on Quality of Childhood, we have found that our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here, now, and today is completely uncertain.
A child today can climb all the way to the top of the social ladder or fall all the way to the bottom.
It can remain in its own cultural circle or seek a new one.
They may follow a similar life path to their parents or do exactly the opposite.
One can marry someone of the opposite or the same gender.
All of this was completely different more than 50 years ago, when we christened the united Europe.
The diversity that distinguishes us Europeans has become a determining factor in the lives of children.
The concept of diversity must therefore be incorporated into the pedagogy of child-care workers and teachers.
This is still far too little taken into account at present.
Europe's childcare facilities and schools are indeed struggling with the challenge of integration.
In matters of integration, we need to press the reset button and go back to the beginning.
Let's approach this topic once again completely free of prejudice, in accordance with the motto "Unity through Diversity."

And furthermore, I ask all the Members of the European Parliament who follow me, not only to advocate for gender mainstreaming, but also to fight for child mainstreaming, especially now during the global financial crisis, because otherwise we will be imposing immeasurable debts on our children. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. I will keep this very brief.
I am very grateful for the constructive contributions to the debate that I have heard here.

I would just like to send out two final messages. Firstly, I would like to expressly thank the Commissioner for not having fundamentally spoken out against the concept of minimum requirements for the safety net.
This proposal is neither the work of the devil nor a bureaucratic monster.
It is a problem-solving tool that we should give a chance.
That's why I would like to promote it again at this point.
And the second thing I want to say, and this is now directed at my British friends, is to Cross all the Parties.
My dear British friends, I do understand Caroline. I do understand your problem.
I can well understand that a country might prioritize energy security over compliance with an air pollutant limit value for a certain period.
I have great understanding for that.
I am also the last person who would not give Her Majesty additional time when it comes to building new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it.
The problem is, we haven't done exactly that.
This conversation has never taken place over the last four months.
I would like to ask you, this is now the outlook in the second reading, to be open-minded again at this point and to say, let's talk about a compromise here.
in my view, the completely irrational resistance, which is not justified from a competition policy or environmental policy perspective, to abandoning the fundamental opposition to minimum standards.
I believe that this is the point where a compromise can be reached, which I hope we will ultimately achieve in the second reading.
Incidentally, I do not believe that we should not seek a compromise in a first reading.
This legislation is too complex for that.

I do not want to end this legislative term as rapporteur and leave the next Parliament with legislation in which a legislative text is being discussed that is inconsistent, illogical, and contradictory.
That is why I ask for your support for the compromises when we vote here in an hour. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, I think the crucial question regarding all the economic stimulus programs currently being put together across Europe is, of course, who ultimately gets the money?
more blank checks are being issued to the banks, even though rapid nationalization would ultimately be much cheaper for the taxpayer.
And are the corporations and high-income earners to be further relieved of their burdens, even though they have been fattened up for years throughout Europe with tax gifts?

The more money is squandered on such purposes, the more foreseeable it becomes that such programs will fail and the more likely it is that the European economy will continue to sink into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The years-long policy of privatization, deregulation, liberalization, precisely this policy, has increasingly concentrated income among the top 10,000. And it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
And anyone who believes that they can overcome this crisis by continuing to pursue exactly this policy with minor modifications, I think has simply not understood anything at all.
The exact opposite of this is needed.
Instead of buying up bad debts from banks, tax money should be used to renovate schools, hospitals, and to restructure the European economy in an environmentally friendly way.

If private companies receive public funds, it must be clear that no tax money is given without employment guarantees and, above all, no tax money is given without the acquisition of public property rights, so that the state and, above all, the general public can also share in the future profits.
The best economic stimulus program currently available would be a radical redistribution of income and wealth from top to bottom.
The low-wage sector in Europe must be reduced, rather than being continually promoted.
We need higher minimum wages. We need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that the millionaires and the beneficiaries of the past financial market party now also bear the immense losses that have been incurred. And not the vast majority of citizens who never benefited from the financial boom in the first place.
I believe that what is socially just is currently also the only sensible approach in economic policy.
And it is the only way to break the devastating crisis dynamics.

Thank you, Mr. President. In early March, political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev were transferred from Chita in Siberia to Moscow to face renewed charges based on untenable accusations.
The first public hearing day was scheduled for March 31.
On the same day, the EU-Russia human rights consultations were supposed to take place.
These important talks have now been postponed by the Russian side indefinitely.
Russia is thus demonstrating very clearly the low priority it places on human rights.
The judiciary continues to be used not only to ensure justice, but also to eliminate regime opponents, and the EU is being duped as a result.
Thank you, Commissioner. Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for once again drawing attention to the ban on animal testing.

He has pointed this out because it reminds me that this is now the third amendment to the cosmetics legislation that I have been able to follow. The sixth amendment, the seventh amendment, and now the change to a regulation.
And we have indeed managed to ban animal testing.
We have succeeded in ensuring that consumers know how long a product will last by including a small can with a number inside that indicates how long it is still valid.

I also say this to some of my colleagues, especially to my colleague Reuthofer, who unfortunately couldn't be here at the beginning. Labels are never warning signs, not at any point. If a product were not safe, it would not be allowed to be on the market, it would not be allowed to be marketed.
Every product on this European market must be safe and harmless.
But the labeling gives consumers the opportunity to choose,
That is democracy and that is your freedom of choice.
I believe that we have very good legislation.
I have tried to make the process very transparent.
I have tried, as Mrs. Kostet also said, to bring together different opinions.

because I am concerned that we create legislation that is good for everyone, for consumers in the European Union, for the industry that has to work with this legislation, and ultimately for all those who benefit from it.
I'll say it again to my colleague Schnellhardt: yes, deodorants work differently for everyone, but the claim that they keep you sweat-free is still made.
And that's why it's important that the statements regarding my wrinkle depth around the eyes after a week in Strasbourg are reasonably realistic and reliable.
I would like to express my thanks once again to the Commissioner, also for the explanations he has provided, to my fellow Members and to my assistant, who has done most of the work.
Thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, the report by our colleague Mr Van Nistelrooij on the Green Paper and the future form of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most significant reports from the Committee of the Regions in recent years.
And we agree with the basic concept of the Green Paper, which states that territorial cohesion is about countering the polycentric development of the EU.
to ensure overall sustainable development of the territories with different characteristics and features, while preserving their diversity.
And it is correct that in the next planning period, a more comprehensive system of phased assistance will be introduced for transition regions that cross the threshold from 75 to 100 meters,
will exceed a certain percentage of the gross domestic product, and must be created so that these regions receive a clear status and thus have more security in their development.

And in colleague Kree's report on obstacles to the absorption of Structural Funds, the most significant shortcomings are rightly listed, for which applicants are no longer responsible when it comes to the absorption of Structural Funds.
are eligible for Structural Funds, such as excessive administrative burdens, too many complex regulations, slow and cumbersome centralized administration in the Member States.
And various recommendations are made to the Commission on what effective measures should be taken to remove these obstacles.
I would like to single out and emphasize two such measures.
Firstly, project managers currently have to keep their project documents for a period of ten years, so that they are available for checks that may be carried out by the Commission.
This is particularly an excessive bureaucratic effort for smaller projects.
It is true that this is now to be reduced to a period of three years. And secondly, the EU Commission's evaluation criteria for innovative projects are causing significant problems.
Innovative projects cannot be evaluated using the same criteria as other projects.
It is simply necessary for something different to happen here.

Thank you, Madam President. When Europe takes money into its hands and when, above all, the Member States take a lot of money into their hands to help the automotive industry in its crisis situation, it cannot only be about securing jobs and the status quo here and preventing bankruptcies, but it is also about a number of other concerns.
The most important ones have been mentioned.
It is about getting people to seek employment. They also need to secure this employment, and do so in the long term.
To achieve this, it is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation, and above all sustainability in the transportation system more strongly than we have done so far.

We should therefore link all our measures to these objectives, so that in a few years we do not have to face the accusation that we should have thought of all this many years ago, and that we would not be in the next and new crisis.
Thank you, Madam President. It would be nice if you could also grant me the extra half a minute that my Green colleague, Mrs Breyer, has just received.
The Commission had put forward a good proposal to update the regulation on novel foods.

Unfortunately, some proposed amendments attempt to supplement this proposal with provisions that are not compatible with the objectives of the regulation or even seek to interfere with existing case law.
The obligation of food business operators to monitor novel foods with a view to animal health and welfare would simply overwhelm traders.
And once again, there is an attempt to undermine the existing GMO laws, namely the demand for special labeling of such novel foods derived from animals that were fed genetically modified feed.
We just heard it.
In principle, anything that affects GMO legislation should not be included in the Novel Food Regulation.
I say this even though I myself, for example, had submitted a proposal to specifically exclude new plant species from the definition of novel foods.
But it cannot be that interested parties in this House misuse the Novel Food Regulation for electioneering purposes.
This appears to be the case with proposed amendments 62 and 90, for which the Greens have requested a recorded vote.
Who, dear colleagues, do you want to expose in this way?
My group has always been in favor of the consumer's right to know what is in their food.
Why, then, should one not indicate a nano-origin in the declaration of ingredients?
And although Amendment 62 somewhat clumsily attempts to anticipate my report on food labeling, I must tell you that I consider this labeling of novel foods to be entirely compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend that my group approve the aforementioned motions and will include references to the part of the Novel Food Regulation dealing with labeling in my report on the Food Labeling Regulation.
This is possible because we postponed the first reading on foot labeling to the next legislative term, against the wishes of the Greens.
But now it is clear to everyone how advantageous this postponement was.
Briefly, cloning is animal cruelty.
We are against it.
Nevertheless, food products must be included in this regulation accordingly, because otherwise they would be in a...
Thank you, Madam President.
If anyone does not want this man to chair the solemn opening session of the European Parliament, they should support my motion to amend the rules of procedure. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President, Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues. Let me make one thing clear upfront: in the upcoming vote on our colleague Schikirski's report, the distribution of food to those in need, especially in these economically difficult times, is not up for debate for me.
That is why I would like to make it clear from the outset that it was not easy to find a common line within our group.
Therefore, respect the personal decision of each group colleague to deviate from this and not to agree with the rejection of the report that we have planned.
Why can I not agree with the outcome of the committee vote in this form?
There are a number of reasons for this, which have nothing, absolutely nothing, to do with helping those in need in the European Union during these economically difficult times.

On the contrary, the amendments submitted by my colleague Nils Busk on behalf of the ALDE Group, which were unfortunately not found to be admissible, were intended to place the existing system on a sustainable footing.
Because the current system is an anachronism from the days of agricultural overproduction, which fortunately belong to the past.

Thanks to the successful decoupling of direct payments, intervention stocks have steadily declined in recent years, so that today up to 85 percent of food products must be purchased on the open market.
However, this has fundamentally changed the nature of the program and led to the loss of its agricultural policy dimension.
However, since we are now dealing with a social program, we need to establish an appropriate legal basis for it.

Herewith, we share the assessment of the Council's legal service, which merely refers to Article 37 of the EC Treaty on the common agricultural policy instead of Art. 37 of the EC Treaty on the common agricultural policy.
considers Article 308 as a possible legal basis, because otherwise it would clearly be an infringement on the national competence of the Member States.

This should continue to adhere to the principle of co-financing, because only on-site can the sense and nonsense of such programs be satisfactorily evaluated in the interests of all. Thank you very much.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, we too welcome the proposal from the European Commission and this Grünbach book in principle.

There is, and this is not a topic of discussion, a mass phenomenon, which has been described by the various previous speakers, where relatively small damages occur among a large number of affected individuals.
For the individuals affected, the damage is small, but when added up, it is significant.
An instrument is needed to deal with this problem and
In my opinion, it is right that people think about something like that.

I also very much welcome the fact, to keep things positive, that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has placed a crucial emphasis in its Green Paper on the question of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.

This is a significant difference compared to the White Paper of the Directorate-General for Competition, which was also discussed here yesterday and has so far completely ignored the possibility of extrajudicial dispute resolution mechanisms.
I think the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has gone further in its Green Paper than its competition colleagues.
However, I also want to make two things very clear, which in my opinion should definitely be understood as critical remarks.
In a few minutes, at 12 o'clock here, Parliament will vote on my report on the White Paper of the Directorate-General for Competition.
We will demand from the European Commission, with an overwhelming majority in this House, that a horizontal approach be adopted in dealing with this issue.
It cannot be that we end up with sectoral instruments, one for consumer protection, another for antitrust law, another for the capital market, and perhaps another for the environment.

Perhaps one more for social affairs, and they all contradict each other. They all interfere with the legal systems of the member states and ultimately lead to a legal and political mess that no practitioner can manage anymore.
We have had such examples many times in the past.
Just think of the debate on the Professional Qualifications Directive, which we later summarized in a single instrument because this fragmentation was no longer tenable.
The Commission should not make the same mistake here,
I should have promoted the horizontal approach from the very beginning.
This is the clear stance of the Parliament, and it will become evident in a few months, in a few minutes, it will become clear here.

One last point. I am also very pleased that we have reached a consensus that we do not want an American-style litigation industry with a turnover of 240 billion US dollars per year, where ultimately only lawyers profit and consumers gain nothing from it.
We want real rule of law in Europe and to stick to our traditional systems and our understanding of law. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, there are many ways to cope with the lasting consequences of the unexpected financial and economic crisis.

This revision package, this legislative measure as part of the European economic stimulus program, is designed as a good response, albeit not entirely sufficient, but it is, first and foremost, a good response to this temporary, albeit exceptionally critical situation.
And it also involves promoting greater simplification of procedures and greater flexibility in the application of existing values.
Provisions under the Structural Funds Regulation, as called for, dear colleagues, by the European Parliament on several occasions in recent years.

to invest structural policy funding in energy efficiency and renewable energy in residential construction. And that these measures should not only be considered for low-income households.
The relevant amendment rightly deletes the line on low-income households and instead introduces a ceiling of 4% of the total ERDF funding for each Member State for such expenditure.

Provisions from the Structural Funds of the ERDF, the ESF and the Cohesion Fund and a simplification of the regulations, which enable the rapid implementation of the programmes, have been provided.
In my opinion, an effective contribution, although not yet sufficient to address the current crisis situation.

a jumble of symbols confuses the consumer and does not inform him

Stalemate in the fight against fraud, nothing on prevention, more ethics not wanted and so on.

But when we take action, it's about really responding to the challenges of the digital age and not flogging dead horses.
And I will explain to you why I come to this word.
The proposal that is on the table actually only fulfills one promise. And that is the promise to promote the music industry.
If we find out what happens to the artists themselves and their income and calculate it, we arrive at
such low average amounts that it is by no means sufficient for an artist's livelihood, in a way that he can make a living from it.
Moreover, this money does not reach the artists directly.
And the fund is too small to achieve anything.
An artist I discussed this with told me that there is a redistribution here from the living to the dead.
I had to contradict him. It is a redistribution from the artists to the producers, to the music industry, and only to the big ones.

Thank you, Mr President. I share the rapporteur, Gilles Savary's, regret that the Commission has not pursued its original plan for an integrated action plan.
There are many good reasons why all parties involved, from local communities to the European Union, are striving to improve urban traffic conditions.
We know that most people in Europe live in cities and that the current traffic conditions are far from optimal.
Therefore, in principle, I agree with the plan and the report by my colleague Mr Savary to draw up appropriate integrated proposals from the Parliament's initiative.
I thank him for his commitment and also for the concrete suggestions.
At the same time, however, I would like to make it very clear that what many fear or believe they must fear will not happen.
No one wants to take away the right of municipalities, local and regional authorities, to shape their own traffic conditions.
From the European side, we merely want to contribute to ensuring that reasonable common rules are followed here, if a municipality, if a city, if a regional entity deems it reasonable.
The principle of subsidiarity is not compromised,
What we want to do here is to protect this principle.
It therefore remains that we strive, in the interest of citizens, to ensure that not when a citizen travels 10, 20 kilometers within
Europe continues to drive, he comes across a traffic-calmed zone that he believes he knows from his home town, but finds completely different rules there.
No one wants to impose city tolls or other regulations on any communities, but if they are actually implemented here, then they should also be done within a recognizable framework for the citizens.
For more than 100 years, we have agreed on the usefulness of common approaches when it comes to traffic signs.
This should also be the case in the future with this topic.
Thank you, Mr President. We have been dealing with urban transport in the EU for a long time now.
Why, really?

We are not actually responsible for this. The jurisdiction was originally created because about 80 percent of the population lives in urban areas, and because of the climate debate, they now want to address the issue.

Subsidere does indeed mean support rather than prescribe, but as an Italian, I was naturally better at it than I, as a German with only a basic knowledge of Latin, was.

Legislative measures at the European level are inadmissible for urban traffic.
supportive measures. That is our task.
A collection of ideas and the promotion of the exchange of best practices makes sense.
Not everyone has to reinvent the wheel.
Our cities need tailor-made solutions, but these can only be developed by the local actors, because they are the ones who know what is necessary.
The municipalities must meet very different situations. They therefore need sufficient room for manoeuvre, also in order to keep inner-city trade vital.
This is important for a city's attractiveness.
It is therefore important not to exclude motorized individual traffic and to focus more on urban logistics.
I would therefore like to see research into urban last-mile delivery promoted.
That relieves a city.
It is also important that demographic change is taken into account
our society is getting older after all.

We need a supply of everyday goods close to where people live if we want to reduce traffic. And this is also a challenge for the retail sector.
Anything else would only require a green field.
In conclusion, we do not need a monitoring station for urban traffic.
Such a position would cost a lot of money and produce a lot of paper that would only be filed away in Brussels. Thank you.
I fully support the Commission's goal of establishing a legal framework for the coordinated introduction and use of intelligent transport systems in road traffic.

My years-long personal struggle for the standard introduction of eCall, the electronic emergency call system, makes the urgency clear to me almost every day. But intelligent traffic systems can do much more.
They serve environmental compatibility, efficiency improvement, increased safety, and non-discriminatory competitiveness in road freight and passenger transport.

Furthermore, they support co-modality, among other things, by developing interfaces to other modes of transport such as rail, waterways, and air travel, where the integration of intelligent transport systems has already begun.
All of this cannot be achieved by the Member States alone, but only as a Community task.

Intelligent transport systems, based on EU-wide binding, fundamental standards and regulations for minimum quality, improve the environment for innovation and create planning security, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
I particularly welcome the planned open, vehicle-integrated platform for intelligent traffic system services.
The action plan finally includes a timeline for the introduction of individual systems. A for road safety, such as ESP and eCall. B for continuity in traffic management. For example, information on
Avoid toll charges or parking lot management search traffic. c. The use of real-time road, traffic, and travel data will enrich not only professional drivers, but all road users.
The directive sets out detailed requirements for the uniformly binding, coordinated introduction of intelligent transport systems throughout the EU and their application in the member states.
It also ensures the handling of personal data.
But beware! The introduction of intelligent traffic systems incurs high costs, as infrastructures and vehicles must first be equipped with the necessary information and communication technologies.
We still know too little about the willingness and ability of potential users to pay.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we clearly support aid for people with rare diseases.

There should be no political or social pressure in Europe on parents to consciously choose against having a disabled child.
The selection of embryos would be a major ethical breach.

but it would still be a matter of fact that there is a selection of embryos.

We must resolutely oppose genetic discrimination.
Therefore, Amendment 15 must be rejected in its entirety. Otherwise, our group would unfortunately also be forced to vote against this report, which is otherwise quite positive.
Thank you, Mr President. I voted against granting discharge to the Commission for the first time since I have been a member of this House, and I would like to explain why.
I would like to present my reasons. I am primarily concerned with the way the European Commission has handled and managed the accession of the two new countries, Romania and Bulgaria.
We are dealing with a multitude of problems in Romania and Bulgaria, with a high level of corruption, with a lot of money, with a lot of European money that has disappeared.
The European Commission only began to freeze these funds in 2008.
We lost a lot of money in 2007 and are now dealing with barely existing control systems, or with control systems that only function intermittently.
In Romania, we are dealing with a high rate of corruption and problems with the judiciary.
All of this is to be blamed on the pre-accession process.

My goal is to set an example, to also tell the European Commission that it must proceed differently for future accessions, and to also tell it that, if it has already been observed in other countries, it could certainly be more successful if it so desires.
I would like to call on the Commission to help the two countries build financial control systems that deserve the name and help eliminate the systemic weaknesses in these two countries.
Otherwise, we will have a long-term problem and a perpetual cause for concern for all of Europe. Thank you.

This means that the Commission can make comprehensive and fundamental regulations on the handling of animal by-products through the comitology procedure. This means that, as is unfortunately often the case, Parliament is left out. Thank you.

Marine pollution only becomes a focus of interest when a spectacular incident occurs. And then there is intense discussion about the threat to our seas from this ongoing pollution.

to protect interests and to integrate the principles of the third maritime package, which is urgently necessary, as the Legal Affairs Committee has also proposed.

Ladies and gentlemen, the UNGL will not agree to this resolution.
The Stockholm Programme completely misses the mark on the real challenges of the present.
The core error is that a Europe of rights is being established, which is granted to EU citizens, but not to other people living in Europe.
And these same citizens and human rights are not to be granted to them.
On the one hand, the EU wants to join the Charter of Human Rights, which we welcome, but on the other hand, migrants are sorted out according to the principle of legal or illegal.
This is how Frontex is being equipped to massively combat so-called illegal migration. And I tell you, this completely distorts the view of an unbiased immigration policy.
This is where Stockholm fails.
Another problem is the completely unbalanced relationship between security and freedom.
Yes, there is no freedom without security, but there is also no security without freedom. Freedom is not a bargaining chip, but a universal legal right of every human being.

Stockholm, on the other hand, symbolizes the EU's security obsession, in which huge supranational databases are created without adequate control mechanisms, merging intelligence and police data across Europe.
This makes the right to informational self-determination of people, waste paper, and the vision of a transparent person a reality.

there are checks, enough checks.
for example, it is ensured that the training of the staff, the certifications and the working conditions are properly controlled.

look at what works elsewhere in Germany where the economic efficiency and relevance of expenditures can be assessed, in Austria, and develop

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a microfinance instrument for the unemployed, those at risk of unemployment, and above all for people who do not have access to normal credit markets, is a good intention and is supported in principle by our group.
However, what the Commission and the Council have achieved so far in this process in terms of performance is simply insufficient, partly incorrect, and cannot be supported by our group.
First point of criticism, the issue of financial resources.
What is on the table in terms of financial resources is not financial resources for a program to combat unemployment. This cannot be described as a microfinance program. At best, it is nano-finance.
Secondly, we are fundamentally opposed to performing such sleight of hand, with no effect, that comes at the expense of other programs and thus fizzles out without end.
Thirdly, also of the opinion that the sustainability and success of such a program must include organic mentoring and coaching.
Many new start-ups, especially in the microfinance sector, fail. Therefore, the programme must also ensure this.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in the member countries are not withdrawn for the use of this program, otherwise it will be ineffective.
This means that unemployment cannot be combated sustainably.
We will reject it in this form.
Thank you. Today, after eight years, we basically all know it: the previous military-focused Afghanistan strategy has failed.
The imbalance between military operations on the one hand and insufficient resources for civilian purposes effectively prevents an improvement in the living conditions in Afghanistan.
And that is why our most important message as UNGL is that a radical change of strategy is necessary.
We need a radical change of strategy away from the military and, above all, towards the people,
This means that 40 percent of Afghans are unemployed. More than half of them live in truly extreme poverty, knowing neither healthcare nor adequate education.
The social question must be brought to the forefront. And that is what we expect from the Council, from the Commission, from all those involved.
This naturally includes strengthening responsible government action, strengthening agriculture, and integrating former Taliban fighters.
But I tell you quite honestly, anyone who only goes half way down this path and returns to military adventures is squandering every opportunity.

Thank you, Mr President. The current debate is a central debate about the character of the European Union.

and the Commission's current considerations regarding the future of cohesion policy are unacceptable.
The Structural Funds must be strengthened, not reduced.

I will say it quite openly: the renationalization of even parts of the current cohesion policy would have serious consequences for disadvantaged regions, including in Germany, for example in Eastern Germany.
And after the last round of enlargement of the European Union, the differences between the regions within the Union have indeed grown.
It is also important to me that the socio-economic conditions in regions that are just above the 75 percent threshold of GDP per capita are also recognized.
An abrupt cessation of funding after 2013 would be disastrous for these regions.
Ladies and gentlemen, of course, strengthening specific urban funding and city-related funding by the European Union is also extremely important.

Regional structural support is an essential instrument in European integration. In the past, Objective 2 funding in particular has been perceived by people in many regions as a driving force for local structural and economic development.
It is an important element for coping with structural change in the regions and also in the municipalities.
Here, Europe is truly tangible for the citizens, because it has a real impact on their daily lives.
However, we need simpler, clearer, and more transparent structures for the cohesion funds and better controls to ensure that the funds are used sustainably and efficiently.
Cohesion, the convergence in social and economic development, is a key objective in the EU. And that is why we must not weaken this instrument in the future, but rather strengthen it.
Cohesion policy in Europe needs more clarity, more transparency, efficiency, and also the self-responsibility of the individual member states.
and that is why it is important to stick to the system of additive support.
However, we do not want a renationalisation of structural funding.
Therefore, I would like to ask the Commission to ensure that the funding criteria from 2013 meet these requirements.

Madam President, it seems to me that it is somewhat symptomatic for us, for the EU in general, but also for Parliament in particular, that we reflexively engage in discussions about situations in countries whose circumstances are not new.
Unfortunately, it is often the case that events occur overnight, leading to a sudden outpouring of political demands here, which I sometimes find somewhat questionable.
I believe it does not behoove us to use a failed airplane attack alone to initiate a general debate about Yemen.
I believe we should be aware that it suits us well to consider a strategy for dealing with this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen requires a thorough analysis, namely that it is a failed state in which a government operates that no longer has control over large parts of the country, and we should analyze for ourselves what risks this poses for Europe.
The risks seem to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks also seem to be emerging on the coast of Yemen, where piracy is obviously taking place.
That's why I think it's up to us, and perhaps also to Mrs. Eschten, to consider what we can do to counteract these risks.
In my view, the answer is primarily how we can support the government in Yemen in regaining control over the country and mitigating these risks.

All other discussions about the long-term development of the country must of course also be held. But I do not believe it is really sensible, and that we will be taken seriously, if we now propose a list of demands across all political issues, from freedom of the media to women's rights here in Parliament.
I believe that will not achieve the goal in Yemen, but rather we should focus on what kind of help we can provide in the current situation to solve an acute problem. Thank you.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the massacre on 23 November last year in the Maguindanao province in the Philippines was a black day for human rights and a barbaric act of terror.
57 dead, women raped, wounded. They speak a bloody language.
As a journalist, I am particularly struck by the fact that 30 journalists were among the dead.
According to the renowned International Crisis Group, no other documented case has ever seen more journalists murdered in a single instance.
For this reason, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to find clear words, as we do today in the draft resolution.

However, as the EPP, we call for the text to be mitigated in three places through separate voting. Because we should support the Philippine government in its fight against terror and violence and therefore refrain from making accusatory remarks towards the government.
Therefore, on behalf of the EPP, I request a separate vote on recital F, which accuses the Philippines of displaying all the signs of a non-functional legal system.
Quote: in point 2, we would like to remove the assumption of so-called initial delays in the investigation.
Finally, point 6 claims that there are missing persons who are being held in Philippine prisons.
This, too, is currently an unsubstantiated allegation and should, in our opinion, be deleted. Thank you.

is not the position of the factions, which explicitly decided otherwise this morning.

Thank you, Madam President. The issue here is that we, as the European Union, must pursue a clear strategy and prevent a gold or oil rush.
Europe must actively get involved here.
Europe can demonstrate its strength as a partner by speaking with one voice.
It's about shipping above and below water. It's about fishing. It's about resources in the form of primary energy sources and raw materials.
Here, together with the other partners in the Arctic, we need solid and reliable agreements.

to combat job losses. Third, to use public investment to create jobs and promote sustainable ecological growth. And fourth, to strengthen and expand social security measures, ensuring access to,

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, first of all, many thanks to Mr Leichtfried for an excellent report that conveys sound and good content.
What is it ultimately about?
The aim is to strengthen transparency, consumer protection, safety and coordination, as well as quality management.
However, I would caution against setting up a new authority to deal with these issues.
I see subsidiarity in the report as a positive element. It should definitely be preserved.
For me, a clear distinction between taxes and fees is also very important, and all tasks that are official in nature, whether they involve identification or not, should be separated.
police measures, whether for counter-terrorism or similar, all these measures should clearly be financed from tax revenue and not from user fees.
If individual nation states then have a vital interest in taking additional security measures, then I also see them as being chargeable in this area.
Those who commission security in the public sector also pay for it.
I see it differently, however, in the technical or personal sphere, which can certainly be at the expense of the air passenger, provided it is clearly declared what it is about.

It is also noteworthy, however, that in the impact assessment presented to us by the Commission, an amount of approximately 0.1 percent of the total transportation fee is calculated for these measures.
We should not start too high, then.
I believe that we can also reach a viable compromise with the Federal Republic of Germany, which has extraordinary concerns in the area of subsidiarity.
I hope the final result will be very close to our proposal. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Madam Commissioner. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, the evaluation of passenger data is an attempt, similar to SWIFT, to combat global terrorism and...
balancing serious crime with the fundamental rights of every individual to protect privacy and also informational self-determination.
However, we must also be aware that in the age of mobility, there will be no adequate security in Europe and worldwide without effective and rapid data exchange.
And in the digital age, we must also ensure special protection with regard to informational self-determination and privacy.
That is why I also believe it is necessary to make a more precise distinction between the data needed to combat crime and the data that is sensitive to privacy.
And for me, it is actually beyond question that we must firmly integrate controls, legal remedies, rights to information, claims for damages, and the length of data storage into the agreement.
In the push method, it must be determined whether exceptions can or must be made in urgent cases.
And when it comes to the use of passenger data, we should also include serious crime.
To me, this includes crimes such as child pornography, human trafficking, murder, rape, and drug trafficking.
In my opinion, that would also be a contribution to protecting the personal rights of those affected.
I think it's good that we are postponing the decision on the passenger data agreements in question in order to establish a basic model for all future agreements of this kind.
also to develop and to give the Commission a negotiating framework that takes into account our own ideas on data protection.
Perhaps there will also be room in the future to consider conducting the fight against terrorism and crime together with our transatlantic partners in a joint institution.
That would certainly also be a step towards globally countering globalized crime. Thank you.
Yes, thank you. The previous speakers have rightly pointed out the importance of the EIB.

Policy coherence for development means that we do not take away with one hand what we give with the other.

For example, it makes little sense to invest development aid in building up agriculture in developing countries if we are simultaneously destroying local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.
We can also advocate for better healthcare as much as we want, if we hinder the trade of generics or drive up the prices of medications to unaffordable levels through patent extensions.

And while agrofuels may reduce CO2 emissions in the EU to some extent, they lead to deforestation and land conversion in developing countries, thereby exacerbating the very climate change we are trying to avoid. Not to mention the displacement of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity, and reduced arable land for food production.
At the moment, we, that is, the EU as such, are not particularly coherent.
The EU has long recognized in theory that policy measures should not contradict each other.
The Lisbon Treaty enshrines policy coherence in the interest of development.
Article 208 states that, when implementing policies that may affect developing countries, the Union shall take into account the objectives of development cooperation.
We must measure ourselves against this demand.
This year we will review the progress made towards achieving the Millennium Goals.
It is clear that without policy coherence, we will not succeed in fulfilling our promises.

We must be aware of this responsibility, like all of us who make and implement laws. Before we decide on a measure, there must be an impact assessment so that we can even recognize what European legislation could have negative effects on developing countries.
We need expertise in the Council, Commission and Parliament that can identify inconsistencies.
The Commission's work programme on policy coherence is a good step in this direction,
And now it depends on how this plan is implemented.
Policy coherence for development means that we must take greater account of the interests of local people in fisheries reform and not subordinate them to the interests of European fishing companies.
It means that we need to dry up tax havens into which funds from developing countries flow.
This means that we cannot agree to ACTA if there remains a suspicion that this agreement could hinder access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
So far, the Commission has not been able to dispel this suspicion.

Policy coherence also means that, in the creation of the diplomatic service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy area, and the powers of the development commissioner must be expanded, not restricted.
And it also means that we enable fair trade in the allocation of contracts in the municipalities, as my colleague Heide Rühle has proposed.
In many cases, we need to keep a close eye on the Commissioners and the Council to ensure they develop coherent policies.
In many cases, however, it is also up to us Members of Parliament to be coherent in the interest of development.
We need to network better between committees and we need a permanent rapporteur.
The report, which the Development Committee has unanimously adopted, makes many good suggestions and takes us a big step forward.
I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the Ombudsman and all the NGOs for their assistance and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can also be adopted by the plenary tomorrow.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have noted from the voting list that you, Mr President, intend to declare motion 2 inadmissible.

It is indeed true that Article 229 of the Treaty stipulates that a session of the European Parliament takes place on the second Tuesday of March.
However, this is not in contradiction to the motion that has been tabled here by my group.

This does not prevent you from holding a plenary session on the second Tuesday in March.
However, we want Strasbourg week to be in the eleventh week, so I say that there is no illegality here.
I would ask you to reconsider this. Thank you.

Mr President of the Commission, following the questions from my colleague Manfred Weber, did Commissioner Malmström inform the College that there are major concerns in this House about the current state of negotiations?
is the Commission aware that what it has decided today is certainly not what Parliament considers to be sufficient progress.

Did Mrs Malmström tell you during the debate in the Commission before the College's decision-making that there was a risk that Parliament would vote against the text that you are now presenting as an agreement?
Or did Mrs Malmström tell you that we will get a parliamentary majority with this text?

Madam President, dear colleagues, for months we have been discussing the issue of driving times and working hours in road transport.
And I wonder what arguments will now be put forward to prove that everything we have been discussing for months is nonsense.
The latest argument is that something urgently needs to be changed here so that nothing changes.
Don't you see, dear Mrs. Bauer, how absurd this argumentation has become, how riddled it is with lies and half-truths?
This debate is about nothing other than an extension of working hours for self-employed individuals.
For the past 150 years, labor law has essentially been about protecting people from excessively long working hours.
This applies to both the self-employed and the employees.
It doesn't matter whether it's a self-employed person who is overworked or an employer who overworks an employee driver.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessively long working hours, partly also from employers and clients.
Secondly, in terms of road safety, it is claimed here that nothing can happen there.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not at a DIY store and we are not amateur craftsmen. We cannot make laws based on the principle of "let's see what comes out of it."
Everyone knows that excessively long working hours are designed to be accident-prone, especially in road traffic with major consequences.
Third point: Who is going to enforce such a differentiated regulation, as you envision it, on our roads in the future?
Today, a state labor judge cannot verify whether someone appears to be self-employed or is self-employed without an extensive review of the case files.
Let's put an end to this nonsense, it's about fair competition,
It is not a matter of setting a priority today or tomorrow for the future debate on extending working hours.
Don't play games like that with this house. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President. Today, as I have done for many years, I am advocating for road safety, an improvement in the working conditions of our professional drivers, and the enhancement of their professional image.

Clearly, today we are not discussing the traffic safety regulations for driving and rest periods that all self-employed and employed professional drivers must adhere to. Today, we are focusing on working time regulation.
It is primarily an employee protection regulation, thus serving only the social protection of drivers and not at all road safety.
We don't need to protect the self-employed from themselves.

It is neither possible to monitor the working hours of self-employed truck and bus drivers without significant bureaucratic effort, nor is there a justifiable reason for such monitoring to take place.

Limiting self-employed professional drivers, and perhaps in the future also self-employed craftsmen, architects, or members of parliament, in this way in their permissible working hours sends the wrong signal.
Rather, the Member States should ensure that bogus self-employment is prevented under the
Drivers fight against drivers.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, just a few days ago, we were horrified to see on television images of vast areas of Poland and other Central European countries being flooded by water.
People have perished in the floods, and our deepest sympathy goes out to their families. Entire villages, agricultural land, and infrastructure have been destroyed.
The images on television have already been replaced by other images. However, the enormous damage still needs to be laboriously cleared up.
In dealing with damage of this scale, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the countries of the European Union.
After the 1997 flood disaster, Poland and this time also other Central European countries have once again been affected by a flood disaster.
We cannot yet regulate the weather, and flooding is a characteristic feature of rivers at certain times.
But the questions we must ask are whether, in the awareness that these natural events can always occur, the right measures are in place to prevent such fates.
were affected by such natural disasters and whether, for example, landscape planning adequately addressed issues of sustainable disaster protection.
When aid is provided, it should first and foremost benefit those directly affected by the natural disaster in order to secure their livelihood.

However, in the context of international cooperation, efforts to prevent damage caused by natural disasters should no longer be limited by national borders. Instead, member states should coordinate their efforts at the European level to prevent damage caused by natural disasters.
The flood protection along the Oder River, which has so far been jointly developed by Polish and German authorities, demonstrates that jointly implemented preventive measures can provide protection.
But we are far from finished yet.
We don't need a European disaster protection agency,
Protecting its country from disasters should be the primary task of a country's government, which should also include the development of disaster plans.

But coordination of aid in the event of damage or incidents should also be subject to efficient European coordination. And those organizations that provide help quickly and without red tape on a voluntary basis should not be left to bear the costs.
Therefore, I support Commissioner Georgieva's plans for us to implement these quickly as well in...

In 2007 and 2008, Libya voted against the United Nations General Assembly resolution calling for a moratorium on executions. There were also no official responses to repeated inquiries from human rights organizations.
For this reason, it is very important to us that the individuals who were executed are finally officially identified.
Every execution is one too many.
We reject executions and the death penalty.
It is inhumane, unhuman, and every one is one too many.
Therefore, in our resolution, we make a very clear request that we change this, that we disclose this, and that we now work together to ensure that a change takes place here.

No more hidden figures, but open information about what is happening here and a humane punishment for real offenders, but not an exaggerated punishment for those who deal critically with the regime in Tripoli.

That is why we support this
Mr Chancellor, esteemed colleagues, due to the limited time available, I will confine myself to the Chancellor's report.
It is undisputed that passenger rights and thus also consumer rights in bus transport must be implemented.
However, I would like to emphasize once again the problems that small and medium-sized enterprises are currently facing, especially from the perspective of the Federal Republic of Germany.
Public transport and regional transport cannot be separated, especially in rural areas, as they often serve a radius of about 50 kilometers together.
Secondly, it is not possible for small and medium-sized enterprises to receive advance payments for services without being at fault.
Here we have the principle of liability, which has proven itself very well so far and has thus kept the fares stable.
