Thirdly, I cannot imagine that delays not caused by the entrepreneur would have to be paid by the entrepreneur, just as liability can only apply to circumstances for which the entrepreneur is responsible.
Thank you, Mr Zeller, one and a half minutes. Thank you, Mr President. First of all, my sincere thanks to Mathieu Grosch for this profound report and the enormous amount of work he has put into it.

Europe cannot be experienced without its unifying borders, without a functioning transportation system. The European economy would not be successful, indeed it would not even be conceivable, without a powerful transportation system, without powerful, future-proof transportation systems on land, water, and in the air.
In particular, when it comes to environmentally friendly rail transport, we need even more community spirit and less nationalistic egoism.
For a sustainable future of transportation, all modes of transport must address the challenges in society, environmental protection, and the economy.
The report provides valuable and guiding insights.
However, I cannot agree with the report on one point: creating a transport fund from the resources of cohesion policy is something I cannot support.
Why?
Certainly, transport is a key element of cohesion in Europe. However, a separate fund from the cohesion policy resources would not meet the expectations it generates.
To unilaterally burden the Cohesion Fund and to relieve the Member States, which are particularly challenged, of the responsibility for ensuring a sustainable future for transport.
And we have just set up a special committee in Parliament to debate what the European Union's cohesion and structural funds will look like in the future. Its work should not be prioritized.
I therefore ask for the amendment to the report to be approved.
And furthermore, I believe that when we talk about sustainability and the future of transportation systems, magnetic levitation technology should also be given a future and a chance. Thank you.
Madam President, my esteemed colleagues, ladies and gentlemen, although we have a common internal market, we have fragmented supervision.
It is obvious that this cannot work.
We need strong, central European structures that utilize the expertise and detailed knowledge of the member state bodies, but also have the authority to intervene in emergencies.
I believe that, given the enormous tax burden imposed by this crisis, citizens expect swift, prompt, and appropriate decisions to be made.
Citizens are not interested in the power games played at the national level, where the only question is who decides.
What the citizen wants is for decisions to be made effectively, for problems to be solved.

And this is objectively the case, so that when it comes to measures in an emergency situation, this must be centrally regulated and decided at the European level, if the coordination between the member states is not sufficient and does not work.
This is in line with the decisions of the G20, the G8, and the heads of state and government, unfortunately not at the level of the Council.
The wheel makes him small, small, little square.
This is not an acceptable policy for citizens.
We expect the Council to take action. Thank you.

Ladies and gentlemen Commissioners, dear colleagues, one sometimes wonders what we have actually been doing for the past year with all these discussions and debates, and all those meetings in the trialogue, where I could have imagined spending my time in a more enjoyable way.

And at this point, more than a year after the European elections, when we were still proclaiming in the streets and squares how we wanted to tame the financial markets, we are actually facing a very meager to non-existent result.
The problem has already been described.
We are dealing with markets that operate globally today.
And the member states still believe that they are able to enforce rules in this area with their national supervisory structures.
And precisely because this did not work, it also contributed, not to triggering the financial crisis, but to it reaching Europe.

That's why I wonder when this realization, which is often expressed in Sunday sermons, will also be implemented in political action, where it suddenly becomes a matter of protecting stock market places, protecting banking structures, and no longer protecting citizens.

We in the European Parliament have dedicated ourselves to this task, and I hope that the Member States will also dedicate themselves to it, because they share the responsibility for implementing proper supervisory rules for citizens, ensuring that individuals' savings remain secure in the long term.

And of course, I hope, gentlemen Commissioners, that the Commission will now really do everything in its power to ensure that we achieve a good result as quickly as possible, in the interests of the people of Europe.
Dear colleagues, we in this European Parliament have a responsibility to ensure strong regulation of the financial markets.
All that we proposed was greatly watered down in the trialogues.
Council and government do not want strong intervention rights.
Giegold is right to call what is happening at the moment "tower-building thinking".
The intention does not seem to be strict regulation, but rather to design the system to be a little more fail-safe.
We will end up with a fragmented supervisory structure that will not be able to exercise real control over the financial markets.
Inadequate conclusions are being drawn from this financial crisis, from this economic crisis, and in doing so, the next crisis is already being prepared.
Many national economies, even in Europe, will not survive the next blows, with all the social and economic consequences for the people in Europe.
They expect that this predator will be recaptured, financial market capitalism will be reined in, and the primacy of politics will be restored.
When the CEO of UniCredit Bank, Alessandro Profumo, stated over the weekend that we need strong and unified European financial supervision and a common set of rules for all member states,
Member countries and he advocates for stricter capital rules, then it is an appeal to this Parliament to actually establish these rules.
It is up to this European Parliament to put pressure on the Council to urgently implement effective regulation. This would only be the first step towards a status quo ante.
Finally, let the big promises be followed by actions. My faction stands for strong European regulation.
Anything else, no regulation, would be a danger to the euro, to a united EU, and to democracy. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President, bad timing for this debate.
I would have liked to have seen the Dutch team win one more time, even if it was the last time in this World Cup.
Probably a bad omen, because now we're not allowed to watch and then they probably won't win anyway.

But to the point, Commissioner, yes, you are giving the right hand signal. Commissioner, Mr President, we are concluding today or tomorrow, to be precise, a legislative package that we have been discussing for more than two years.
This is not only due to the controversy, but also to a European election in between and the entry into force of a new EU treaty, which has led us to have to adjust some things.

But I believe that if we draw a conclusion from today's debate, I come to the conclusion that we should now vote on a compromise that is well worth saying yes to, even if one might do so with a clenched fist in one's pocket in one place or another.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
One is the environmental requirements for industrial plants.
The issue here is that we need to better enforce the best available technology in Europe.

I believe that we have found an exception paragraph in the compromise now before us, which gives the EU Commission, Mr. Botocznik, and that is quite rightly directed at you, the necessary tools to act in the

In the coming years, we must pay closer and more careful attention than before to ensuring that the approximately 52,000 industrial facilities affected in Europe ultimately make better use of the best available technology than they do today.
I have heard many arguments in this debate.
I would like to address one point and reflect it here, because I simply cannot understand it.
I was often told that using the best available technology is too expensive and that we are thereby endangering the competitiveness of European industry, especially during a crisis.
I don't like to remember my past, but I come from the former GDR, from East Germany.
The economic and ecological collapse of the GDR was also due to the fact that for decades, investment in technology had been neglected in the final years.

And I believe that every industry, every industrial company, is called upon to invest in the latest technology for the sake of its existence, because otherwise it loses competitiveness and, of course, also reduces pollutant emissions as a side effect.
I think we have the opportunity today to enact a law that improves this starting situation.
The second part of the directive, and this is a bit of the clenched fist I mentioned, is the large combustion plants.

Once again, as we did in the last directive, we are discussing further exemptions until 2020, and in some cases 2023, for large combustion plants that do not have to meet environmental standards, particularly air pollutant limit values.
I am addressing the Council here, but perhaps also a little bit all of us, that we need to think very carefully about how sensible it actually is that we do this regularly.
We welcome ambitious environmental targets, we discuss them, and we welcome them here. But whenever it comes to implementing them, to enacting concrete legislation, then a tragedy begins in Europe.
This is when the member states suddenly realize what it costs, what bills need to be paid, and then, as a rule, those who have made advance payments are also penalized.
There are, in fact, a number of member states that already meet the requirements today and will be left out in the rain in the end.
And I'll say it again here: both industrial plants and large-scale combustion plants are essentially coal-fired power plants. Let's not talk about science fiction.
We are not talking about things that are not available, but rather it is the state of the art.
Best Available Techniques, which are available on the market under competitive and cost aspects, can be installed in these facilities. And with this in mind, we conclude today.
Today, I am presenting a legislative package that I believe is better than what is currently in force, and that is why I encourage all of us to agree to it.

And I would also like to thank the colleagues who have been involved in this over the past two years, often under very difficult circumstances, for their support, their contributions, and above all, for the fact that almost all the major groups have signed up to this compromise. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Three things have happened while we have been debating. First, it is clear that Europe will become the world champion in football.
A good omen, I believe.
Who exactly it will be, we will see.
I don't want to give any preferences right now.
Secondly, Germany is receiving compliments from the UK.
Chris Davis, thank you very much. It doesn't happen every day.
It is worth noting that.
And thirdly, the world is still in order, even with the Greens, football is more important than environmental protection.
Because unfortunately our colleague Bas Aykut is already gone again.
But of course, congratulations to our Dutch friends.
I wanted to add two aspects to the debate that has just taken place.
First, I understand all the concerns and hardships of my Eastern European friends all too well.
As an East German, I am also half Eastern European.
And I understand that not every environmental policy step taken in Western European countries in recent decades can now be immediately replicated in Eastern Europe.
High-level environmental protection must be affordable.
Yes, that's correct.

But I believe that even when taking this sentence into account, it is worth voting for this compromise, because it does justice to the different starting positions in which many Member States find themselves.
And secondly, the argument that the use of best available techniques endangers competitiveness, especially in relation to China. This argument is not only false, it is even dangerous.
We must come to terms with the fact that industrial processes in Asia are definitely cheaper than they are here.
And we will only succeed in this competition if we use the best available technology in as many industries as possible.
Those who do not do this lose their competitiveness.
No one, not even this law, demands that an industrial plant be shut down tomorrow.
No one is demanding a jump from 0 to 100 to achieve any pollutant limit value within a week.
We have sufficient transition periods. But to say that one should forgo them for competitive reasons is wrong.

And I believe that with this directive, we have not only made a significant environmental policy decision, but also an important one for industrial policy. It would be worthwhile to work on this in the coming years. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to begin by thanking my fellow Members from the other groups for their assistance in drafting my report on Kosovo, as well as Mrs Eva Mahr, who has done some very valuable work in the secretariat here.

And I would also like to express my thanks to you, Commissioner, for the good cooperation, but also for what you mentioned, that it was important for you to travel to the north of Kosovo, to even spend a night there, and thereby to make it clear to the population that you stand for this population there as well.
They gave a speech at the university and opened the EU house there.

I think that was an important signal to make clear what this European Parliament has already expressed in the past and is expressing again now, namely support for an independent Kosovo on its way into the European Union.
We are currently facing a situation where there is once again an important crossroads for Kosovo, for its citizens, especially for all ethnic groups in Kosovo.
In a few weeks, the International Court of Justice will decide to give its opinion on the status of the declaration of independence made a little over two years ago.

I hope that this decision, this opinion, will be an opportunity, something like an open window, as it is called in English, to establish regional cooperation on a new basis, but from the perspective of state sovereignty.

starting from Kosovo and independence. And to make it clear that the common future for all the states in the region, for Serbia, for Kosovo and all others, lies in membership of the European Union, and that on the way there, the problems that still exist must be resolved.
It is also the text of a resolution that makes it clear that the future of Kosovo lies in the European Union.

I am glad that we have a majority in favour, which also calls on the five member states that have not yet recognised this to do so soon. The Commission is also being called upon once again to begin visa liberalisation as soon as possible.

because the citizens of the country, especially the young ones, must not have the impression that they live in an isolated state, that they cannot go out, while everyone else in the surrounding area will soon have this future.
I think that is the assignment
I hope that I will also find a large majority in the plenary tomorrow for this.

I have also tabled a new amendment that expresses strong regret about the outbreaks of violence in recent days and hopes for a swift and independent investigation, and does not take this as a basis for escalating emotions in the coming days and weeks. Thank you.
Madam President, distinguished representative, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues, the most tragic events in Kyrgyzstan, the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people, the
The burning down of houses and the streams of tens of thousands of refugees who left their hometowns and tried to flee the violence, all of this has shaken me and evoked sympathy for the victims.
At the same time, these events in Kyrgyzstan also shed light on the situation in Central Asia, which must not leave us in the European Parliament untouched.
On the contrary, we should devote our full attention to the countries in this region.

In this context, we should focus not only on the countries that are rich in natural resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but rather consider all countries on an equal footing within the framework of the Central Asia Strategy adopted in 2007.
That, I think, is our obligation.
The Central Asian states, which freed themselves from Tsarist and later Soviet rule less than 20 years ago, are burdened with a heavy legacy.
The arbitrary borders drawn by Stalin, without regard for the home regions of the peoples living there, apparently make cohabitation within and outside the borders of these states more difficult.
Poverty, corruption, disregard for human and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions, such as in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, where hundreds of thousands,
Forced labor migration and the use of violence in conflict resolution, as seen in Kyrgyzstan, leave the future of these states uncertain.
Here, the European Union cannot simply stand by and watch,

If we do not want to lead these countries down a path towards fundamentalist structures, if we do not want to condemn the people there to live under dictatorial regimes forever, then we need to make a full commitment.
In addition to the urgently needed material aid, we need contact with these states and active support for the democratic forces developing there.
Let us give Prime Minister Rosa Otunbayeva a chance to pacify Kyrgyzstan and move towards stable political conditions. Let us allow debate on this and vote tomorrow.

Resolutions must be followed by actions, so that the people in Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian states can feel that we are not leaving them alone on their path to the future or delivering them to undemocratic forces.
The expectations of us Europeans in these countries are high. We should not disappoint them. Thank you.
The report was voted down for four reasons.
The architecture of the service has numerous weaknesses, the details of which will continue to cause us great concern.
The second point is that the European ambassador will manage Commission funds in the future.
This exposes the funds to a wide range of risks, and the safeguards for these risks are still absolutely unclear.
The third point is the abrogation of the rights of this Parliament in a Council regulation.
In this procedure, we have de facto co-decision powers, and yet we have allowed the Council regulation to pre-empt Parliament's rights.
That is why, with regard to my dossier on the financial regulations, I would like to say that I do not feel bound by today's decisions.
The fourth point is the question of how we actually treat each other in Parliament.
In the last period, we decided on a parliamentary reform and procedures that we have now all trampled underfoot, also with the approval of the Presidium and also with the approval of the President.
Why do we have a parliamentary reform that prescribes procedures if, when it comes down to it, we already violate them and do not adhere to them?
For these reasons, I cannot agree with this report. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, I am very much in favour of green genetic engineering, but cloning is something else entirely.
You can't compare it to that at all.
Cloning is animal cruelty. And many colleagues have already said that here.
I also raised this point before the summer break, during the discussion we had. Only a fraction of animal clones are actually viable.
And those who survive, many, many of them die very early and in a very painful way.
They suffer from malformations of extremities, of organs.
They have weakened immune systems, they are susceptible to illness.
This means pain and suffering and this agonizing death.
Can we be responsible for that?
We are committed to animal welfare and then we want to support such a technique.
No, we do not want that, and that is why we decided in July that we do not want any cloned meat or animal products from cloned animals.
And that is only consistent.

Yes, we know that the products from the cloned animals or their descendants are probably not harmful to health, and I personally assume that they would actually be suitable for human consumption. But there is actually no shortage of meat from conventional production.
Why should we engage in cloning?
It is completely unnecessary to engage in this animal cruelty. And the population simply does not want it.
The public does not want these products, and we do not need them. There is no argument for cloned meat in the European Union.
And that is why we want a very clear regulation explicitly for cloned animals and yes, also for their offspring.
I want a ban on cloning and cloned products in the European Union. And I also believe that we can enforce this.
Of course, this must also apply to imports.
And I want to be sure that I am not being secretly served cloned meat because it is not labeled, as has already happened here in Germany.
And I don't believe that all meat can be traced.
For beef, it may be possible.
But with pork, due to the volume produced, it will not be possible to trace back whether there was ever a clone in the lineage.
Basically, I think yes, it is a matter of principle, it is an ethical question.
And other colleagues have said it: we must also deal with ethical issues, and we are also responsible for ethical questions.
And of course there is the question of animal welfare, but it is also a different question.
Experience shows, and I am an animal producer, I have studied this, that all reproductive techniques, once they really worked in animal production, were eventually applied to humans as well.
And so today we must ask ourselves: do we want to and can we accept cloning technology in the not too distant future, do we want to and can we accept it in humans?
Well, I don't want that and I can't do that either.
And even if a spare part clone could one day donate a vital organ to me, a clone of myself, I wouldn't want that.
And I don't think that's an exaggerated horror vision.
I believe that this would not be at all fair in the future if we were to allow cloning.
And that is why we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on cloned animals and their offspring throughout the EU.
And I am not afraid of the WTO.
We can enforce this.
We don't have to copy everything the USA does, despite all the transatlantic friendship. Thank you.
Thank you very much, colleagues. It is no coincidence that we cannot easily reach an agreement in this case, because two incompatible matters are being mixed together here.
We probably would have been able to reach a good agreement on trademark protection if we had focused on that.
But the conflation with the Internet as a material entity is also factually incorrect, because new, different strategies are needed here than in substantive law.
This cannot simply be transferred.
Moreover, one must be aware that we pay for every prosecution on the net with infringements of civil rights, because one cannot see or find this out on one's own.
And the third thing is really clear to me. If I already put cultural enjoyment on the web under threat of punishment, so that I have practically always had one foot in the...
If I'm in prison, when I look at the net, then I won't be able to use the opportunities that the Internet also offers for art, culture, and creativity.
That is why I appeal to you: let's continue to talk about it. That would be obvious.
Thank you very much.
Mr. Chairman, property, whether it is intellectual or physical property, is a fundamental pillar of the market economy.
And that's why I believe it's important that we think about how we can resolve this issue together in a good consensus.
We definitely need a warning signal.
Stop-Shop. It must become easier for consumers, the self-employed, and small and medium-sized enterprises to obtain corresponding licenses here.
And the availability of licenses for intellectual property rights that are valid throughout the EU is of particular importance.
We need an internal market for intellectual property.
Above all, we also need the original language to be available throughout Europe.
Every language is an important cultural asset, and it should be possible to issue licenses for a language that are valid throughout Europe and can therefore be used by all citizens.
We need interoperability and technical neutrality in order to be able to use this intellectual property accordingly.
And above all, we need sanctions for those who violate competition and trade law.
Dear colleagues, I have taken note that the Council does not wish to discuss the multiannual financial framework.

I would like to inform the Council here that the European Parliament already wants to discuss this and that the Council cannot behave like children in a kindergarten and say that it will not answer our questions or our proposals.
Secondly, I must ask the Council whether it wants Lisbon or not.
Lisbon is not just a technical change, but means more tasks, means more task completion and therefore also answering related financial questions.
In addition, the Council has made decisions that will lead to new financial expenditures.
This has been carried out by many colleagues.

If the Council wants this and if the Council wants that no more money should be spent, then the Council must also say where exactly it wants to save, how it wants to save, where it wants to reallocate precisely, and not just make general statements.

We propose percentage-wise shifts and then leave it to Parliament and the Commission to decide where the inconveniences should be made, especially since our options for reallocations and changes to the budget are extremely limited.

The tasks they additionally assigned to us are so challenging that they do not involve small, insignificant sums, but I will mention only the areas of financial solidity of our states and their corresponding financial difficulties.
And if the program has to be used, then these are not small amounts that can be easily reallocated.

The same applies to ITER, the same applies to issues of internal security, the same applies to major research issues, and the same applies to questions when I address the key areas of focus for Parliament, namely in the fields of youth education and research.
We are dealing in part with a lack of implementation. We are also dealing in part with a lack of transparency in the spending of funds.
All these questions need to be addressed and worked on in concrete terms, and not answered by silence on the part of the Council.
Dear Commissioner Hahn, colleagues, I have a problem with parts of the debate.
When we talk about mountains, islands and sparsely populated regions, I get the impression from individual contributions that they are extraterritorial and directly subordinate to the European Union.
But that is not the case.
Each of these territories belongs to a Member State, which are sovereign.
And the implementation of European decisions and objectives is still the responsibility of the Member States, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.

When I look at the European level, we have always paid special attention to these areas: mountain regions, sparsely populated areas, islands, as seen in Commission communications up to the Lisbon Treaty.
And here in Parliament, many decisions have been made to support this region.
When I hear many complaints here now that there are still shortcomings in the regions, I ask myself how the member states have dealt with the impulses we have sent out from the European level.
And how have the regions themselves approached this and utilized the European funding opportunities?

A new strategy is needed here. So I already feel sorry for the officials at DG Regio who have to incorporate the multitude of problems of islands, mountains and sparsely populated areas into a single strategy.

At the same time, we are experiencing an inflation of strategies concerning the Danube, the Baltic Sea, the Black Sea, climate change, and other such issues, so that we will soon need a strategy for the strategies in order to keep track of everything.

Ladies and gentlemen, let's put the fun aside. I think what's really at stake, and this has been mentioned today, and I am very grateful to Commissioner Hahn for bringing it up, is that we must fight to ensure that there is a coalition policy and a regional policy at the European level after 2013.
I think that is the focus of our work, and we should also convince our colleagues in the parliament that this will be the case.
And in a continuation of the coalition and regional policy beyond 2013, mountains, islands and the other territories will also find their place.
However, we should not get bogged down with individual motions for resolutions on this topic, for which there is currently no reason. Thank you.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, thank you to the colleagues who have worked so intensively on this project, especially to Mr Bilal Quadras.
This is proof that European politics is capable of responding to crises and offering solutions that help to move things forward.
We have had these situations of supply security multiple times.
The problem of supply security has thus become clearer and more evident.
We have been forced to act and we have acted.

We have found solutions that were not easy, that also mean new instruments, and that, and I find this to be the interesting part, do not simply create infrastructure standards in Europe, do not simply create common rules for prevention and emergency plans, do not simply provide certainty, as the Commissioner just rightly pointed out.
has demonstrated that we can offer people 30 days of security in the future, but also shown that we are capable of exploring compromises. Compromises that then lead to actionable solutions. That was

on the back burner, but it is now becoming apparent that both the role and responsibility of companies, which build the networks and are responsible for them, are in focus, as well as the flexibility of politics, which says, we do not force things that ultimately no longer pay off and are no longer smart.

are no longer reasonable. For example, flexibility is also needed in terms of returns, in terms of necessary returns, but not to say everything and always and at any price, but also the need or the possibility to be able to assess individual cases, as well as to strengthen cooperation in the regional area.

And just as important, I believe, is the reminder that member states must also assume their responsibilities. But if the solutions cannot be found there, the Commission will be given an additional task. The Commission, which is strengthened, but does not decide alone, but which then decides when other solutions are no longer possible or which has the final say.

Also flexibility, solutions that keep the burdens within manageable limits, and last but not least, ensuring that there are solutions. And that is the good news from Brussels for the people of Europe.
Mr President, my dear colleagues, my highly esteemed Commissioners, I do not need to emphasize how important coalition and regional policy is for coexistence and integration in Europe.
However, I also believe that the regional and cohesion policies of the future must increasingly focus on cities.
Because cities are an important driving force in the development of Europe.
At the same time, however, you are currently experiencing ecological, economic, and social problems in particular.
Therefore, my very specific question to Commissioner Hahn is: What possibilities do you see for highlighting the urban dimensions?

To be specific, Commissioner, you recently hinted at an event here in this house that you could imagine a certain percentage being reserved from the regional funds, precisely to emphasize the urban dimension.
Are these considerations still relevant?
If so, how high could this percentage possibly be?

Thank you, Mr. Chairman. First, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for initiating a new debate here as a former Minister of Economics and Innovation, which I believe can make a significant contribution to growth in Europe.
If every small and medium-sized enterprise in Europe created an additional job, we would no longer have any unemployed people in Europe.
We should therefore consider how we can enable small and medium-sized enterprises to hire new employees and become active in international export markets accordingly.
But research infrastructure is also an important concern, as is infrastructure in the transport sector.
I believe that the Commission has major tasks ahead of it here, particularly in restructuring the East-West connection, for example Paris-Budapest, or the North-South connection.
Additional jobs can be created here, which we urgently need in Europe at present.
Madam President, dear colleagues, undoubtedly we have made progress in recent years in achieving gender equality. Nevertheless, there are still many women who are relegated to low-skilled employment.
This applies not only to activities that are traditionally carried out within the family.
In the deregulation of recent years, employment under social insurance has often been transformed into atypical, precarious, and insecure employment relationships.
especially women there.
The European employment development from 2000 to 2010 includes 60% new, precarious and atypical employment relationships, predominantly two-thirds of which are women.
Women are often denied democratic participation due to their part-time employment or precarious employment in companies.
However, women today are far more engaged and better educated than in all previous generations.
They still earn 25 percent less than men on average.
We have dealt intensively with this issue in the employment committee and developed good proposals for the issue of women's employment. The inclusion, regardless of the status of their work in

social security systems, the creation of childcare facilities, the alignment of pensions and social systems towards independent living, and the design of work according to the principles of good work.
All of this has essentially been taken over in the report as precarious employment of women.
The Employment Committee is satisfied with the outcome of this work and requests approval for the report presented. Thank you.
Yes, thank you, Madam Chairperson. Mr. President of the Council, landmines will likely continue to be a major problem far into the future.
Do you think it is possible to initiate your own research programs to detect landmines?
This is not just a European problem, it is a global problem.
And can you imagine finding suitable institutions here that are involved in research programs in this area?

My colleagues, in the transatlantic dialogue, there are many things that unite us. These are fundamental values, fundamental rights of freedom and democracy. However, there are also many things that divide us, namely the application and concretization of these respective rights when it comes to transatlantic relations.
This contradiction becomes particularly evident when it comes to security issues.
Data protection is a source of constant misunderstandings. We have known this for a long time.
That is why the framework agreement, if we manage to get a very good one, will be a huge step forward.
We must find a solution here that enables citizens on both sides of the Atlantic to assert their rights with the other partner.
A second important point where we have similar foundations but very different approaches is climate protection.
That is why I very much hope that it becomes a topic and that it is discussed in detail.
The European Union must not use the transatlantic dialogue to weaken its own promises and commitments. Thank you.
For the first time, investment fund managers are bringing a degree of transparency and regulation to this opaque thicket of hedge funds and alternative investment funds.
Unfortunately, these rules have remained incomplete.
It is still possible to access the common market with unregulated products through passive distribution.
In essence, market access for these products is not effectively restricted.
Europe has thus missed an opportunity to extend its rules internationally and to achieve uniform regulation.
Secondly, unfortunately, unlike what Parliament wanted, there was no effective debt brake at the European level for the funds.
It is still left to national rules to limit how high the debt of the funds can be. And that means that the consequences of the crisis are not being drawn at this point.
There will be a national downward race in terms of regulation.
What is crucial for us once again is that the plundering of companies by private equity funds is not effectively prevented.
Of course, there are private equity investments that make sense for companies,
But the rules that have now been made are unfortunately far from sufficient,
The information rights of employees, who rightly expect this, as well as the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises against this form of exploitation, are also not effective.
That is why it is very difficult to justify this to the voters in this case.

Unfortunately, the responsibility for this does not lie with the Parliament, but rather with the intensive lobbying efforts of the relevant industry, which has been particularly successful with the British government.

Government, with the French government, but I must unfortunately say also partly with the German government, and we had representation of these lobbies here in Parliament, rather in the form of the liberal group.
We cannot agree to this proposal because it would set a precedent for Parliament's failure to enforce effective rules.
We cannot stand before our voters with our heads held high and say that we have successfully regulated this shadow economy.
We hope that we will make more progress when revising the directive.
Thank you once again, especially for the cooperation here with the colleagues in Parliament.
Yes, thank you very much. First of all, many thanks to my colleague Walz for the collaboration.
I can only emphasize that, even with differing positions, it has been a good collaboration.
Many believed, and I want to emphasize this point, that the crisis in the Eurozone was over.
Ireland shows that this has not been the case.
Europe is still voluntarily surrendering itself to the financial markets.
The EU member states must continue to peddle their government bonds on the financial market bazaar and earn the trust of speculators through suicidal austerity measures.
Over the weekend, we had to observe once again where this leads.

This time it was not the allegedly deceitful Greeks, but the model pupil Ireland, who was driven into the European rescue fund to save its banking system, which was also long considered exemplary, exemplary in its deregulation.
Meanwhile, the financial sector is already eyeing Portugal's capitalization, as its interest rates continue to rise.
The ECB shares responsibility for this drama.
By issuing Eurobonds, it has failed and continues to fail to offer a civilized alternative to the state casino.
While one half of Europe is recovering from the crisis, the ECB watches calmly as the other half continues to fall deeper into poverty and insecurity.
The bailouts of entire economies may be to the liking of European fund and banking crises, but they are of no help to Ireland, the monetary union, or the ECB.
Mr Trichet, don't listen to Mrs Merkel's simple finance ABC.
If you want to save the economic and monetary union, don't leave European government bonds hanging in the air.
Introduce Euro-bonds before the next victim of speculation falls.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, if you consider how we discussed this Commission proposal in the last legislative period, from total rejection to jubilation, with all the lovely things being said about us, then I must say that I am thrilled with what is now before us.
And so, a big thank you goes to the rapporteur and his co-rapporteurs for having turned this broad spectrum of opinions into a coherent opinion.
I believe the magic word for this lies in focusing on the patient.
So, instead of taking the many side effects into account, they asked themselves what the patient needs.
I believe it is correct that we have agreed that the patient can obtain information through various means, not just one.
But I would like to emphasize that the doctor will still need to be the patient's trusted person and will certainly have an influence on critical issues.
We guarantee this because we have banned the advertising for it and the information that the patient receives has been checked and approved by an authority.
This means that the information is now scientifically substantiated, and the patient can handle it with confidence.
Of course, it is true that not everyone can determine this.
It's available over the internet. We have various ways to do this, and I believe it's so widely spread that we don't need to worry about it.
I can only hope that the Council finally has the courage to take up this issue.
It is very important, action must be taken quickly.
Patients expect that.
I believe we have done a good job. Thank you.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, dear colleagues, coal is a part of the energy supply, that is undisputed.
It is also undisputed that competitiveness must be ensured and that subsidization cannot be the right approach.
The question now is whether the date of 2014 or 2018 is the correct one.
My colleague Rabka has put forward a number of clever arguments that I don't need to repeat.

And my request to the Commission is actually just that, there is obviously a large majority in Parliament, in all the committees involved, in favor of affirming that competitiveness must be a criterion.

But that in the matter of the deadline, one simply creates the necessary flexibility, which is certain to also create the possibility for the member states to implement it and that the burdens for the people, for jobs, and for economic structures remain manageable.

The only argument that has been mentioned, which incidentally also contradicts the Commission's impact assessment, which also seems to be leaning towards a decision in favor of 2018, is the argument that climate policy reasons may play a role here.
I want to emphasize this aspect once again. Whether you burn someone else's money or your own money, it makes no difference when it comes to the issue of climate change.

And my request to the Commissioner is to consider whether this four-year deadline might allow the Parliament and, if a new argument arises in the Council, whether this could not lead to the Commission also becoming more flexible.
I just understood the comment to mean that the Commission is giving it some thought, and I thank them for that.

Mr President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, if we must draw a lesson from Copenhagen, where you, Madam Commissioner, held the presidency, it is that the European Union must speak with one voice at such conferences in the future.
We may have differing opinions on this matter. But if we Europeans speak with different voices, our influence will not be credible. And if we are not credible, other people will not follow us.
Why should they?
That is why I believe it is correct that the figures we agreed on at the end of 2007 under Chancellor Merkel must essentially remain in place and form the basis of these negotiations.

I share your opinion that the ambitious 2-degree target should not be seriously questioned today for a significantly lower degree, because this makes the feasibility of these goals extraordinarily difficult and causes people to lose interest in them.
I have a great concern that we are questioning our intellectual property.
Our industry also invests money and manpower to develop things.
If we go ahead and loosen the fence around this intellectual property and leave the holes in it as they are right now, then the valuable parts, namely our property, will slip away.
I am very much in favor of technology transfer, but our companies must also see a reason to invest in it. And for that reason, intellectual property must not be improved.
As for obligations, I also tend to demand serious commitments from our partners worldwide.
but they must be credible and they must be feasible for these countries
Otherwise, we will do the exact opposite of what we want, namely, they will distance themselves from us.
appearing credibly in Cancun is an important point
The really big decisions will be made later in Johannesburg. But in Cancun, I believe we should prepare the ground.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in order, there will be no harvest.
Let's focus on the good land.
Thank you, Mr President. Mr President, there was an incident during the debate on the European Council this morning, which I do not wish to address any further, because I was the target of an insult.
But I want to say that there are levels at which I cannot be offended and where I do not consider it an insult, because to insult me, one must have a certain degree of seriousness.
I would, however, like to express my heartfelt thanks for the countless signs of solidarity I have received since then here in this House.
I would like to express my heartfelt thanks to you, dear colleagues from all factions.
I think this is a sign of our shared democratic and pro-European conviction, which the overwhelming majority of this House shares.
For that, my heartfelt thanks.

Dear Commissioner, dear Minister, dear Mr. Gosses, and dear colleagues and shadow rapporteurs, first of all, I am pleased that we have now taken this step, that for the first time a sector of the European financial system is being placed under direct European supervision.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe in a single market, for strong control over a sector that has contributed to the crisis.
I would also like to make a comment on this, Mr Barnier. The selection processes for the new authorities are currently underway, and the new authorities will only be as good as the staff.

And I can only hope that in selecting the staff, it will truly be about expertise, about independence from the financial industry they are supposed to control, about clear service to the public interest, and that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process that override these important criteria.
Moreover, there is still much to be done in the area of rating agencies.

We still do not have proper transparency of the information that the rating agencies work with. We have far too much use of regulatory ratings in the financial industry and in the regulations governing the financial industry.
We have serious conflicts of interest, we clearly have market power held by three major providers, and we have no liability for ratings created negligently.
That is why I ask you, Commissioner, it is good that the consultation is now underway and we are eagerly awaiting the results.
And I also think that civil society should participate in this consultation. But then it must also be about making a bold proposal.
I am already looking forward to your proposal.
Be as courageous as you have been so far and let us work together to create legislation next year that truly solves the problems that still exist in the rating market on a European level.
We owe that to the citizens.
Yes, thank you, Mr President, Mr Minister, Mr Barnier, colleagues. The damage that rating agencies can cause has been evident in recent months since the beginning of this year.
There is therefore an urgent need for action
And that is why I welcome, or rather, I welcome the directive, especially the fact that ESMA would be responsible for the supervision and registration of credit rating agencies.
I think this is an important and good step forward.
However, numerous good and further-reaching proposals were lost during the negotiations on the report.
And I would like to point that out again here.
The appointment of ESMA therefore remains the only real and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public database for creating ratings have been dropped. There is also no mention of establishing a public rating agency.
The consistent and continuous review of established ratings by the supervisory authorities has also been overlooked.

The Commission had also proposed promoting unsolicited ratings in order to overcome the disastrous issuer mandates for the evaluation of financial market products. However, nothing has come of this either.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into account in the reports that are still to come, on this subject of which Jean-Paul Groset and also you, Mr. Barnier, have spoken. Thank you.
Mr Chairman, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, I would also like to thank those who worked on this report, especially my colleague Mr Benzen.
I want to point out two aspects and perhaps make you think a bit.
We agree that energy efficiency, using energy sparingly, is the solution. The simplest and most sensible one.
The question is, how do we achieve this goal?
And I would like to ask what has actually been achieved by repeatedly approaching people in Parliament with new and higher percentage figures.
Have we really achieved more and moved more?
Or why and where has energy been conserved, or used more efficiently?
that the industry, which consumes a lot of energy, is more economical with energy because it saves money and because it is beneficial for them.
And I learn that when people know that this device consumes more energy or less energy, so when they see that and can decide for themselves which is advantageous, then they will choose that one.
Perhaps the method is not about working with percentages at all, but about advancing the method correctly through incentives.
Second question. The Commissioner has just very impressively and clearly explained how complicated even just describing the term "What is it actually?" is.
How different is this in the member states?
The colleague just pointed out that the member states also have very different situations, economically, geographically, totally different.
Is it the right answer to work with a number, to work with a binding number, or should we not think of that anymore?

I believe that in energy policy, we need to distance ourselves from the debates of the past, which rely on simple numbers, binding targets, and so-called miracle solutions to try to achieve something. Because it is clear that we have not achieved enough.
Perhaps we should try the other approach, the differentiated one, the one that takes into account the different situations and states of mind, but also achieves results.
It's about the effects. It's not about how we feel.
This regulation, which is being discussed today, has not received much attention in all committees for a long time.
But now, at the end, when the result was in, some people in this house woke up.
Unfortunately, some have not appeared for the debate. It would have been very, very interesting to hear their opinions as well.
As a former member of the Convention, the spirit of the Convention is still very, very clear in my mind.

which has clearly called in many areas for the European Parliament to be given certain rights in order to have and maintain its credibility within the framework of the institutions and towards the citizens.
In this sense, what the Convention laid down for us was still not a gift.
It was extremely difficult negotiations, especially led by the Belgian presidency vis-à-vis the Council, that enabled some important progress to be made.
I recall what my colleague Lehne said earlier, which was precisely the question of the constant possibility of checking whether the Commission has exceeded its powers.
Of course, there are some not entirely ideal regulations, such as international trade agreements, but I can still agree with the outcome.
I thank the Belgian presidency.
She really put her heart and soul into making something happen and our rapporteur, who negotiated with heart and mind.
13 I would like to make the following statement on behalf of our group. This is a motion that my colleague Göran Färm had tabled on behalf of our group on the Committee on Budgets.
We no longer re-submitted this amendment, but the Green Party faction re-submitted it with 40 signatures from Green Party members of parliament.
We will abstain from voting on this motion.
I have reached an agreement with the Green Party colleagues. We are in complete agreement on the matter.
However, since we have fundamentally stated that we will not be submitting any new amendment as a group, we will abstain.

However, I would like to explicitly state that we support this point on the financial transaction tax and hope that our colleagues on the other side of the House will support us in the votes in the coming days.
I believe it is important that we do not use national tax systems against the internal market.
And this is particularly important for cross-border services. Equal treatment is required here.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retroactive price limits were used to tax the crisis.
This is not acceptable, especially the financial, insurance and trade industries, but also energy is heavily affected here.
I hope that this will not also be used in the field of health services in the future.
I would also like to ask President Orban to review these regulations, because they are fundamentally contrary to the concept of the internal market.
It is important that the EU addresses the problems of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has submitted corresponding proposals.
At present, there is still no precise analysis of the implementation of the existing legal regulations.
There are also hardly any well-developed calculations and analyses available for the new proposals.
I may state that the EPP unreservedly affirms the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
Unfortunately, considering reality also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is claimed for entirely different reasons or even deliberately misused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for general immigration in the 27 member states.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers do not get a chance to profit billions from people's fates by exploiting our asylum laws.
Asylum procedures must be carried out in a qualified and careful manner.
Persecuted individuals must have the guarantee of finding protection within the EU.
That is why the Commission has included corresponding obligations in the new drafts.
I consider many of them to be correct, such as interpreters, proper health care, and consideration of special protection needs.
However, I also want to mention points that I consider problematic.
The authorities of the member states are given far too few opportunities to combat abuse.
The possibility of conducting expedited procedures and border procedures should be unduly restricted.

If an applicant massively violates their cooperation obligations, there are hardly any sanction options. On the contrary, if they disappear illegally, the member state should no longer be able to terminate their procedure negatively. If they reappear, they should be offered an expanded range of procedural options.
Even if the application is clearly unfounded, an accelerated procedure should still be possible after the second follow-up application.
This means significant cost increases.
The free legal advice provided by a lawyer, as currently formulated in the Commission's draft, represents a significant increase in costs for the states.
I simply ask the Commission to reconsider the consequences of their proposals on practical reality, financial impacts, and the problems for the administration of the Member States.
We want a high standard, but it must also be feasible and, above all, must not set particularly hard-pressed member states impossible tasks.
Mr President, thank you very much for allowing me to take the floor once again.
I have a big request for you, Commissioner Fühle.
I want to start by saying that false assumptions lead to incorrect cost estimates.
We currently do not have declining numbers in the area of asylum seekers, but rather significantly increasing numbers.
This has to do with visa facilitations, for example, for Serbia and Macedonia.
We are currently also experiencing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum rights in an attempt to enter a country in the European Union.

If one starts from the false assumption that disputing the first procedure in a higher-qualified reform would save costs in further instances, one automatically assumes that all member states have a poor first procedure, so to speak.
But that is not the case.
If you raise the standards overall, then this will inevitably lead to increased costs.
An increase in quality standards for all of us and also the complication of procedures, I am willing to discuss this, in practical reality leads to more costs.

That is why I would like to reiterate my heartfelt request to genuinely take the concerns of the countries into account, because the practical reports from the countries are partly available and are being provided.
Thank you, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, the report commends the Commission for its successful competition policy.
However, it must not be forgotten that unregulated competition can also contribute to rising unemployment and the growing gap between rich and poor.
Unfettered competition still takes precedence over people's social needs in the European Union.
The creed for free markets cannot obscure the fact that they not only repeatedly fail, but are incapable of establishing social justice on a lasting basis.
A few proceedings for competition distortion and price fixing simply do not solve this problem.
A fair and at the same time socially responsible internal market only works with strong and fair regulation.
More is urgently needed for this.
For example, it is not acceptable to constantly subject public services to private sector competition.
The report formulates recommendations for the Commission's future competition policy.
Much stronger consumer protection, the removal of public services from competition rules, and the control of cartels are all urgently needed.
Furthermore, a contractual clause for guaranteed social progress, which is at least on par with the competition rules in Europe, would be necessary.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is a truly important moment that we are commemorating the Holocaust of Roma and Sinti for the first time in the European Parliament today.
And let me begin with the farewell letter that a 14-year-old boy, Robert Reinhardt, wrote in 1943 before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz.
He wrote, I have found my parents again.
We are on the transport to the concentration camp.
I have mentally prepared myself to the point where I can endure death.
Once again, I thank you for everything you have done for me.
Greetings to all, see you in heaven.
Yours, Robert.

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return, like 500,000 other Roma and Sinti. And although Roma and Sinti were among the first victims of industrial-scale mass killings, along with the Jews, today, 66 years later, the full truth about it remains unspoken.
And the complicity of mainstream society is often covered up.
We need the whole truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust of Roma and Sinti must be punished as a crime against humanity and recognized so that this history does not repeat itself.
We must fight against the prejudices against these people with passion.
We must put a stop to racist abuse and acts of violence, such as those that took place in Hungary the year before last, and we must do so with civil courage.
Freedom, equality, and solidarity are not the privilege of a few, but the right of all, because human and civil rights are indivisible. Thank you.
Yes, ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, in my view, the issue now is to really exploit the possibilities of the law.
To push the limits of strong financial supervision in Europe. And we have doubts as to whether these possibilities are really being fully exploited institutionally.
We see flaws in the process. To date, we, as a parliament, have not received the list of candidates in advance, but only the final result.
It would be simple for you to send us the current ones for the executive directors.

We have clearly seen the lack of gender equality in the appointment of positions, and we have doubts, due to certain incidents in the process, that the member states are truly appointing this institution in the European interest.
and the other points in our letter justify asking a fundamental question.
But beyond that, it is of course about the suitability of the individual persons. And each person must be assessed individually and according to their competencies.
There, we see two major problems.

We have heard in the hearings that one of the candidates questioned the fact that it is a European institution, instead talking about a network of supervisory authorities, and was not prepared to correct this even when asked.
When asked whether they are prepared to make all lobby contacts with the financial industry transparent, we did not receive any clear statements.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us, the outcome of the vote depends on whether we receive clear and comprehensive responses to it.
Thank you, Mr President. Mr President, we in the Social Democratic Group have tabled the same motion.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and the distinguished House that we phrase it a bit more precisely.
We are dealing with a truly enormous influx.

And Italy, like every other country in the Mediterranean region, is certainly overwhelmed by the current problem and unable to solve it on its own. And Italy will certainly not be the only country confronted with the massive influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece, and Spain will also be confronted with this problem in the foreseeable future.

Therefore, we would like to request that we formulate the title of the debate very precisely, namely a statement by the Commission on immediate measures by the European Union to support Italy and other EU countries affected by the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I expressly welcome the outcome of the conciliation procedure.

The implementation of the regulation will ensure that, in the bus and coach transport sector, firstly, a high level of protection comparable to that of other modes of transport is achieved for all passengers, including those with reduced mobility.

Firstly, it achieves high levels of safety for people, secondly, it ensures a high general level of consumer protection, and thirdly, it takes into account the special circumstances of a transport sector that is predominantly characterized by small and medium-sized enterprises.

Thus, the extreme subsidies that would have made bus services almost completely impossible due to excessive subsidies are off the table, as are subsidies in which the majority of the member states would have fallen completely outside the scope of the regulation.
Bus transport services that benefit citizens in general must also offer a high quality of service to disabled people and those with reduced mobility.
They should be entitled to assistance. In the interests of social integration, this should be free of charge.

Thank you, Madam Chairperson. I would like to congratulate everyone, especially my colleague Mr. Kanzian, for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy process of drafting a compromise on this challenging issue.
There were successes that have already been mentioned, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope and other subtleties that have already been discussed.
With this compromise for bus transport, we have covered passenger rights for all modes of transport.
The next necessary step is to create a common, coherent and efficient framework programme for all passenger rights.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the EU's credibility among European citizens.
And in order to be credible, the coherence of rights for the different modes of transport must therefore be respected.
There is no other way for the rights of airplane passengers. Fundamentally different criteria apply, for example, for train passengers.

That is why it is particularly important when drafting a framework programme not to focus on the lowest and weakest standards, but rather to keep ambitious goals in mind for the benefit of the citizens.

Madam President, Mr President, dear colleagues, we are in the midst of a major economic crisis, we have been talking about it for months, and that is all true. However, we usually just discuss it in headlines and then continue to make decisions as if nothing had happened.
I believe it is because we in Parliament are not specific enough or honest enough in our behavior, but rather it is a headline-grabbing policy that is being pursued.
What is actually being done to promote growth and stability?
Do we ourselves contribute to managing finances more orderly and wisely?
Do we really critically examine whether we are making the right expenditures, or does each of us not have a new idea every day about where more money can be spent?

If we do not have the strength to concentrate financial resources on future projects, and that means conflict, argument, and decision-making, then there is no point in talking about innovation and research without providing the necessary funds.
is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, we must also pursue a policy that stimulates the economy and doesn't spend all day thinking about how to disrupt industry or the economy.
We cheerfully continue to make decisions, constantly demanding new decisions today as well, which disrupt the economy in its development.
Does anyone really believe that the issue of mandatory energy-efficient housing, to name just one example, contributes to economic advancement?
Do you really believe that our decisions, which you have often made in the context of energy, have harmed the economy?
Or have we disturbed them?
And I would like us to have a more honest conversation about this and then make a few fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that really move things forward.
It is more strenuous, more laborious, and will also mean conflict, but that is the essence of democracy.
Yes, thank you. Colleagues, the demand for a financial transaction tax is not new. Globalization opponents have been calling for such a tax for several years now.
But even five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be implemented in the foreseeable future.
But this week it is on the agenda in the European Parliament, along with a CO2 tax and Eurobonds, and I think that's a good thing.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments that Anni Podimata proposes in her report, and I think we will vote in favor of them accordingly.
They are urgently needed instruments,
So far, the consolidation of public finances has focused solely on cutting spending.
The reduction in public spending primarily affects workers, pensioners, and the poor, i.e., those who rely on the welfare state.
The revenue side of the public sector has so far been completely overlooked.
It is the second adjustment that can be made to consolidate public finances.
Above all, however, the revenue side also allows for the main contributors to the public debt crisis and the reduction of public debt to be adequately involved.
To consolidate public finances, an increase in tax revenues is simply indispensable.

In fact, the high level of public debt is primarily a result of the nationalization of private debt, namely the assumption of debts by private banks and the financing of the subsequent financial crisis by the public sector.
The states are therefore by no means solely responsible for the debt crisis.
It is therefore not only logical, but also politically necessary, to ask the financial sector to contribute.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally be held accountable as the main cause of public debt and would contribute to the reduction of this debt.
This is an important political signal sent out by this report, if it is adopted as it was presented.
But we also consider Eurobonds to be a sensible and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to reducing debt than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice.

The complaints of some surplus countries that their interest burdens would increase as a result of Eurobonds are not acceptable, because at the same time these surplus countries also earn money through their exports to the deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
But anyone who wants a social Europe, who wants the EU to remain united in the future, must at least agree in principle to a transfer union.
In conclusion, I would like to say to the Commission that I hope it will finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax that have been demanded for over a year now. Thank you.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the rescue umbrellas were meant to protect EU member states from insolvency.
However, they burden people with brutal austerity programs and let the perpetrators off scot-free. Moreover, the Commission is now also interfering in national wage policies.
Dear Mr. Hahn, it is absurd and it brings tears to one's eyes to hear this formal argument here, that it was not meant to be a social policy at all.
This position is completely unacceptable. Wage policy is not the EU's responsibility. This policy of the Commission is in blatant contradiction to the idea of this European Union.
The European Union was never a project for downward wage competition and social dumping.
it can be read there about wage rigidity, which is to be reduced,
to talk, wages should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, here blind people are talking about color. People who formulate something like this have no idea about collective bargaining systems.
They interfere with collective bargaining autonomy and lead the much-vaunted autonomy of the social partners and social dialogue to absurdity.

I want to make it clear that this Parliament is called upon to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, protect social dialogue, and prevent further erosion of social security.
We need measures against a counterproductive austerity policy and punitive actions. Thank you.
Mr Barroso, you are a clever man, but you have not answered my question.

That is why I ask again: when Mr Oettinger says that we currently suspect that certain plants that are still in operation will not survive our stress tests, I interpret this to mean that you are aware that these plants are so poorly secured that they will not meet the criteria.
Why then are they not intervening already today?
Because in my opinion, that is a real danger.

Mrs. Gabriele Zimmer now has the floor. I would actually like to ask the two representatives from the Council and the Commission why they believe they need to present their arguments on this topic using speech bubbles.
I believe it helps no one if it is not explicitly stated that, in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the Member States of the European Union and the European Union itself
it must finally fully meet its commitments to development aid and that it is in no way acceptable for Member States to increasingly shirk this responsibility.
It is unacceptable that one billion people still go hungry every day, and that most of them live in LDCs, the poorest countries in the world.

And it is unacceptable that a large portion of our development aid is not going towards the promotion and development of agricultural structures, but that this proportion has rapidly declined in recent years. With one billion people suffering from hunger,
And then to talk about hoping that the LDCs become more shock-resistant, I think that's getting to be cynical.
I urge you to address the problems in a concrete and clear manner and to assume concrete obligations in order to actually help the LDC.
In the context of internal market law, public procurement law is an essential component.

Mr. Barnier, when you say that you also want to promote social integration in this context, then I have to ask you, I have heard very little about the protection of social rights, I have heard very little about the protection of collective bargaining agreements.
That is one of the basic rules that you, as you say, do not want to question yourself.

If one wants to protect basic rules, one must ensure in the future that elementary social standards are protected when awarding public contracts, that collective agreements are not undermined, and that wage stagnation is prevented.
This is part of a modernized public procurement law.
And I expressly state that fundamental social rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe or we want a permanent conflict with the people who are turning away from this Europe, in which they do not see their interests safeguarded. Thank you.
Dear Madam President, dear Commissioner Krus, radio frequencies are a precious and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and from a societal perspective.
That is why the Radio Spectrum Policy Programme is of particular importance.
Radio frequencies must be used efficiently, taking into account economic, social and cultural aspects.
To achieve this, the technical capabilities must be fully utilized in all band areas to generate the highest possible efficiency.

The basis of radio frequency policy must be the telecommunications package adopted last year. This is because it was also established that the radio frequency management of the EU and its member states must meet cultural, social, and economic interests equally.
This must be taken into account, especially when harmonizing the use of frequencies in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend I is being carried out at very different speeds in the member states.
Further opening of the UHF band, especially below 800 MHz, should therefore only be considered after taking into account the experience gained in clearing this band.
Many technical and financial issues have not yet been conclusively resolved.

The issue of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities in the technical conversion, for example in the field of wireless microphones, has not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
When distributing frequency bands, the various interests must be weighed against each other responsibly.

On the one hand, the widespread provision of mobile broadband networks is a fundamental requirement in the interests of European citizens. At the same time, however, the development of public and private broadcasting must continue to be taken into account as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity.
We need to set the course for technological development, Europe's positioning in the field of digital information technology, and cultural diversity.
Mr President, dear Mr Rehn, I would like to say first of all that you have described it, the situation has worsened.
The Eurozone is experiencing a growing divide between countries that are recovering and those that are weaker.
And the costs of supporting the weaker countries are continuing to rise.

In this situation, I have a few questions for you. As Commissioner for Monetary Affairs, I ask you: on the day-2 customers of the ECB system, liabilities and claims between central banks have accumulated to a value of over 400 billion euros.
This is because the banks are still not adequately financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these liabilities that are not provided for in the Eurosystem?
Then the big problem, why we are not making progress with the restructuring of the debt, is that the banking system, as Mrs. Ford also said, is not set up correctly.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When will the Commission present this?
And as Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, how do you assess this delay?
What do you do to make it go faster?
Then we saw, as we Greens had predicted for a long time, that the measures taken against Greece and Portugal would not work as long as the macroeconomic conditions in the Eurozone were not improved.
We still have absolutely rising interest burdens from a macroeconomic perspective for these countries.
We have seen increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries.
And we still have a lack of demand from several European partner countries, especially from the strong Euro countries.
and we have rising resource and food prices, at least if you take out the recent ups and downs.

I wonder, in addition to the bailouts for these countries, in addition to the financial assistance, what measures are being taken to ensure that the weaker countries receive macroeconomic relief in areas such as taxes, external demand, and interest rates?
And how...
I would therefore encourage you to propose a strong package that improves the macroeconomic conditions of these countries in the Eurozone.

And finally, in my view, the measures have hit the weakest in Greece, Portugal, and Spain against the spirit of the EU treaty, while the stronger, the wealthy, have so far not been called upon to bear any of the burden.
What measures are you taking to ensure that the wealthy are also called upon to contribute to the costs of this crisis?
Thank you, Mr President. Mr President, Mrs Kinga Göns is a Member of my group.
One can be against Ferenc Jokh, one can be for Ferenc Jokh.
One can reject Kinga Gönns as a politician or be in favor of her.
This can certainly be determined freely and independently by anyone, whether they are in favor of or against a person's political beliefs.
The debate we are having here is about the last dictatorship in Europe.
And we lead them through one of the most brutal and bloody dictators that exists on the European continent.
I find it absolutely unacceptable that an elected democratic member of my group is compared to a bloodthirsty dictator.

I believe that Parliament must also reject this, especially from the representative of a party that is known for its hatred and persecution of the Roma minority in Hungary, which is unparalleled in Europe.
If any person here does not have the right to criticize Mrs. Kinga Göns, it is Mrs. Mauer.
Mr President, my esteemed colleagues, dear visitors, Europe's cultural diversity is an important asset that must be preserved and expanded in the future.
