In order for this to be possible, we must address the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the cultural and creative sector.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, but it also represents a significant economic factor.
In the EU, approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to approximately 2.5% of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that is developing faster than many other areas of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content offered by the cultural sector, just as the nature and quality of content have changed and evolved through technology.
We therefore need to create framework conditions for the cultural and creative industries in which they can develop sustainably in the face of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
The cultural and creative industries are a driving force for Europe.
That is why we must also focus on this area in the field of school and vocational education.
We must impart cultural and creative competencies to young people and also in the offerings of lifelong learning.
However, we must also better strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural workers. And not only the entrepreneurial competencies, but also a good media literacy in the field of new technologies.
We need framework conditions in which cultural workers can secure their livelihood.

And that is why we will have to intensively address the issues of copyright, social security, and intellectual property, as well as open access to information and content, in order to further develop the

to ensure the creative and cultural industries continue to thrive in a digital environment in the future and to preserve Europe's cultural diversity and heritage as an essential characteristic of the European Union.

Mr President, dear colleague Kellam, dear colleagues from the Baltic countries, dear colleagues, today we are commemorating in a special way the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These expulsions are among the darkest events in European history.
Indeed, the past century was not only and not least called a century of expulsions, and not without reason.
And today we all bow our heads in respect for the victims of these inhumane acts.
In this context, we demand a comprehensive investigation of Soviet history and, in particular, the atrocities of Stalinism.

And today's Russia should not understand this as a political attack, but as support for the re-evaluation of its own history, which, like the history of other European countries, is marked by both light and dark sides.
But just as we think of the victims from the Baltic countries, we think of the Armenians who were expelled from Turkey at the beginning of the last century.
We commemorate the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
Deporatations in Europe reached a particular peak in the middle of the century under the Nazi regime and the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The expulsions after World War II also left deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav wars.
We must also not forget, however, that many colonial powers were characterized by expulsions.
We must demand a serious examination of the various forms of displacement and the specious justifications for them.
And this also includes clarifying guilt and punishing the guilty, insofar as this is still possible, as is currently the case with Mladic.

But the crucial answer is European unity, especially through and with the independent Baltic countries, and a clear commitment to continuing the European unification process that has not yet been completed.
This historical task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but especially to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many female politicians from all countries in Europe, from East and West, have worked on this,
For example, let's think about the Danzig Declaration, signed by Polish President Woźniowski and German Federal President Rauch.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must be vigilant, even towards the first signs of displacement, as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all statements, such as the one suggesting that Arab immigrants should be sent back across the Mediterranean in boats. And we must resist when some want to abolish Europe's borderless achievements and return to a new narrow-minded nationalism.

Let us bow in reverence to all the victims of displacement and deportation, but let us unanimously commit ourselves to the continuation of European unity, as the only true guarantee against such a future.
Politics that brought so much misfortune to people in Europe and beyond in the last century. Never forget, never again were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have lost none of their validity. You are best off in a united Europe. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues. I had the opportunity to experience the referendum on the independence of South Sudan as a parliamentary election observer. And I was impressed by the overwhelming support of the South Sudanese people for determining the future of their country themselves.
And I also saw the great expectations among the people, who saw the independence of their country as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands of so-called internally displaced persons, who were driven by the decades-long fighting in the south to the refugee camps in the north, set out on their way to their former South Sudanese homeland.

And of course, in addition to the independence of the country, the people of South Sudan want above all to live in peace and pursue a path towards a happier future, after all the decades of warfare in which millions of South Sudanese had to lose their lives.
On July 9, the new state of South Sudan is set to officially become independent and expand the family of nations in our world.
The starting conditions are as bad as they can be. And a lot has already been said about that here.
70% of the people live as nomadic herders, 80% are illiterate. The conflict over Abyei is escalating into a military conflict.
There were already dead and wounded there.

As if that were not enough, rivalries between tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also increasing, and according to observers' estimates, more than 1,000 people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and mutilated are barely counted.
Sudan was already among the failed states
There is a danger that the state of South Sudan is already beginning as a failed state.
I am firmly convinced that Europe has a great responsibility towards this region.
given the colonial past of the countries there. Together with the UN and the African Union, this is where the common European foreign policy is needed and can prove itself.
This is not just about money, but also about supporting the fragile, emerging civil society.

And we must negotiate hard with those who hold the fate of the country in their hands, namely the tribal leaders, heads of military groups, so that they do not disappoint the hopes of their people in the country. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. I am very grateful to my colleague Bartolozzi for making Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament with his initiative to submit this question.
While the former Soviet states of Central Asia are now discussed in Parliament from various perspectives, Mongolia and its situation have only received very limited attention here.
It was Mongolia, quite wrongly, that as a state of the former communist bloc, was relatively quick to take advantage of its independence and embarked on a path towards democratising its society.

As early as 1992, the Mongolians adopted a democratic constitution, and since then, several elections have taken place, which, according to observers, have generally had a democratic and correct course, which is far from being a matter of course for the states in this region.

The Mongolian government has been trying for several years to combat corruption by law and in 2010 imposed a moratorium on the death penalty, something that even some major democratic states have not managed to do to this day.
Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this large country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, are suffering from the consequences of a transformation process that is still ongoing.
Thus, a rural population that still lives predominantly in a nomadic fashion is crowding into the few cities that are not prepared for this in terms of infrastructure.
The country's mineral resources are not extracted in an environmentally friendly manner.
Energy problems complicate civil and economic life.
Sandwiched between its large neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia is at risk of becoming even more dependent on these countries than it already is.

Mongolia's efforts and successes – and here I see the glass as half full rather than half empty – in democratizing society should be recognized, as they are exemplary for this region and show what is possible despite a difficult past.
And Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only through aid programs, but also by the European Union being directly present in the Mongolian capital with its own delegation.
Representation as a sign that the fate of Mongolia and Europeans is not indifferent and that European interests will no longer be represented from the embassy in Beijing. One more sentence, please.
I am very disappointed that the Conference of Presidents was not prepared to lend additional support to this cause by allowing Parliament to pass a resolution. Thank you.
But, dear colleague, of course I recognize this right.
I only assume and hope that you also acknowledge the right that the position of the Dutch government is not declared ex cathedra, but is open to discussion in a multinational democracy.
I have absolute respect for Mr. Rütte, who is in favor of a 2.7% increase in the EU budget.
I have taken note of that. And I am pleased that you have been listening carefully, because in this Parliament, the positions of all governments are openly discussed.
In that regard, I did not fully understand the meaning of your question. But what I thought I heard is that you, too, are committed to democracy.
That is, after all, already progress. Thank you very much.

First, I reacted so excitedly because I am still upset that we were not able to get a joint resolution on security in place here. Because the absolutization of a position was more important than unity.

Secondly, I explained at the time in the debate, and I will reiterate it now, that I too have learned and now see that we need to do more in the area of increased safety regulations for European nuclear power plants, exert more pressure, and show more initiative.
That is precisely why I was in favor of the joint resolution, and that is why I believe we should support the Commissioner and not constantly attack him.

Ladies and gentlemen, regarding the intermediate category. I would have certainly been able to imagine other solutions initially, Mr. Pieper, especially since the regions that currently have the highest requirements and will no longer have them after 2013 will receive a transitional arrangement.
The discussion, however, revealed that we need to consider additional regions, particularly those affected by the crisis.
We are talking about 51 regions at present.
And given the large number of affected regions, it would be downright negligent not to establish an intermediate category.
Only in this way can a reliable framework be established for the responsible promotion of these regions, which must overcome development deficits through their own efforts.
Otherwise, there is much light and much shadow to be found in the Pipa report.

Among other things, we criticize the lack of a clear commitment to a much more decisive fight against poverty and consider the formulations contained herein, which link cohesion policy to conditionalities that force member states to implement reforms, to be unclear and highly open to interpretation.
Period. Cohesion policy must remain an instrument of social balance and solidarity in all regions.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, Internet-based regional cooperation is becoming increasingly important in the future.
Cross-border cooperation and macro-regional collaboration are extremely important in an increasingly interconnected Europe for achieving the 2020 goals.
Border regions still face special challenges today.

Cross-border concepts and projects in areas such as infrastructure, business cooperation, research collaboration, labor market development, and further education are the driving force behind large parts of the European Union.
We need clear and simplified structures for the management of interregional projects.
Different national requirements among project partners often make cooperation and the realization of concrete, sustainable projects more difficult.
It is an important step that the PIPA report includes the demand for an increase in the share for interregional cooperation Objective 3 to 7%, and I would like to strongly support this.
Thank you, Madam President. Dear Commissioner, dear colleagues. After almost three years of intensive work, after far more than 3,000 proposed amendments, after countless conversations, discussions,

After the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogues, it is now up for a vote. The political package, the major compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers on the future labeling of food products.
This regulation aims to provide consumers with more and better information about food products, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions.
But that's not all. The European food industry is also expected to benefit.
The goal is legal certainty, deregulation, and better legislation.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises. And it is important to know that the food sector in the European Union consists of over 80 percent of SMEs.
At the same time, this labeling must be suitable for every food product and every non-alcoholic beverage. From basic foodstuffs to highly processed ready-made meals.
That is why mandatory labeling in traffic light colors is not possible, because this labeling is not suitable for staple foods.

Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political and ideological differences in Parliament, despite all the national egoisms of the member states, the compromise that has now been reached is still impressive.
Allergens will be recognizable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is indicated.
There is origin labeling for pork, poultry, lamb, and goat meat.

For other products, a follow-up assessment will determine whether and how the origin can be indicated, for example for milk and dairy products, single-ingredient products, i.e., products consisting of one main ingredient, and meat in processed products.
Imitation products, etc., must be clearly marked on the front, and the same applies to molded meat and molded fish, which are composed of and glued together from small pieces.
Nor may packaging create the impression that something is inside that is not actually there.
If a picture of fruit is on a yogurt, there must also be fruit in it, not just coloring and flavorings.
In addition, the mandatory declaration of the most important nutrients, always per 100 grams or 100 milliliters, is required for reasons of comparability.
Added water in meat must be labeled, the date of the first freezing in meat and fish, and many other details.
But most importantly, all information must be legible.

We have defined readability, we have established a minimum font size, and we have instructed the Commission to establish binding rules for additional factors, such as the contrast between the font and the background.
At the same time, we protect the craft industry from excessive costs and bureaucracy.
Fresh products that are not pre-packaged must provide allergen information, but not the full nutritional information that can only be determined through expensive analyses.

The Commission originally wanted this, but it would have destroyed our national and regional characteristics and specialties. It would have led to a European uniformity, and that's why we prevented it.
But now we have all come to an agreement, and the reputable consumer protectionists are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

I would therefore like to thank all those involved, the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission, and in particular Commissioner Dalli for his statements, which he will hopefully be making shortly and which will help to resolve the deadlock that has developed in our political discourse.

And I am particularly grateful to the Hungarian Presidency of the Council, which has achieved something that was almost no longer to be expected, almost the squaring of the circle, the agreement on this regulation. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. Chairman, esteemed Commissioner, and esteemed Polish Presidency of the Council. Allow me to join in your thanks to the rapporteur, Mrs. Ayala Sender.
As mentioned earlier, the Council had been blocking progress on this issue since 2008, until a compromise was finally reached under the Belgian presidency.
As mentioned, improved data exchange between member states will enable cross-border prosecution of various traffic offenses throughout Europe in the future.
The goal must be to increase road safety and reduce the number of traffic fatalities and injuries.

Together with Dieter Koch's own-initiative report on road safety, which makes a number of very specific proposals, this directive, with its repressive nature, can also contribute to better compliance with these rules.
I no longer need to go into the rules, as they have already been presented positively here.
The change in the legal basis from European transport policy to police cooperation has finally allowed the Council to draft a common position.
However, this means that some countries, such as Great Britain, Ireland, and Denmark, are excluded.
As a result, once again, not all European citizens are treated equally.
Citizens must be aware of the data protection rights they have.
We have tried to strengthen this aspect so that access to the collected data, its transmission and its storage are regulated as strictly as possible.
We also placed great importance on the information.
While the current text does not fully meet the expectations of Parliament, I am still optimistic that this is a first step in the right direction.
I hope that in the coming years we can build on this foundation to take a step towards greater harmonization of European traffic regulations.
The revision clause introduced by Parliament would definitely allow such a procedure.
I deeply regret that this text has now become embroiled in the institutional conflict between the Council and Parliament over the correlation tables.
During the trilogues, we agreed to find an overall compromise on this issue with the joint declaration.
I would just like to remind you that the European Association of Road Traffic Procedures will be meeting tomorrow.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear female colleagues, dear male colleagues, first of all, my heartfelt thanks to Mrs. Mack.

Many thanks also to the colleagues who prepared the reports beforehand, Mrs. Mörkes and Mrs. Cavaglio. This is a follow-up. And the day is approaching when we will not only be making political decisions...
but also have to prove that we are serious about research and innovation, which is the crucial question for the future viability of the European Union.
And that is why I am very grateful that the representative of the Committee on Budgets also pointed out that adequate, good financial resources in this area are an important issue.

We will soon have to settle the dispute as to whether we have the strength to provide the necessary financial resources to ensure that this area of research and innovation truly becomes a central priority.
It is of central importance for the question of whether and how Europe will develop in the future.
By then, it will no longer be enough to deliver grand and small Sunday speeches; instead, facts will have to be presented.
Second point: We ourselves cannot avoid looking at whether we can use our resources more effectively, and I believe this is very well highlighted in the report.
How do we achieve a simplification in the procedure?
How do we achieve speed?
We are receiving research funding that is being made more effective.
How can we create a stronger structure and greater simplification in the sometimes still complex maze of different research funding?
Sometimes less is more. Few projects, but a lot of money invested, ultimately have a higher impact.
And that is why I am grateful that we have once again taken a step forward in this report.

Of course, the European Research Council and the European Institute of Innovation and Technology will play a special role. And of course, the area of small and medium-sized enterprises is an important one.

We also need a solution for the states that are not yet as advanced in promoting excellence, which must remain the only principle, rightly and necessarily, in the future. We also need an answer for the states that are not yet as far along.
And in this report, the idea of a possible competition also emerges, which could perhaps be used to promote new top research centers in neighboring regions.
And I believe that this is an important task that still needs to be resolved.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, in view of the current extraordinary situation resulting from the financial, economic, and budgetary crisis, decisions at the European level should focus on urgent and essential issues.
This is the only way to restore the trust of our citizens in the seriousness of our actions.
My report is about the strategy to prevent endless human suffering, resulting from approximately 35,000 deaths and disabilities each year.
4.5 million often severe injuries resulting from road traffic accidents, as well as the prevention of associated economic damage of 130 billion euros annually.
The number of deaths alone is equivalent to that which would be mourned in the crash of 250 fully occupied medium-sized commercial airplanes.
What wouldn't we do to prevent that?
The costs of accident consequences significantly exceed the annual total budget of the European Union.
That is why I am sure that it is appropriate for us to take sustainable action in this area.

Thanks to the constructive cooperation of all shadow rapporteurs and many colleagues, we have succeeded for the first time in developing a unified, holistic, and coherent approach to improving road safety.

It takes into account the contents of the UN Road Safety Charter 2010-2020 as well as the contents and objectives of the road safety work of the EU member states and broader sections of civil society.
Firstly, it includes ambitious, yet realistic goals for the period up to 2020, and the Sirum vision for the period beyond that.
By 2020, the number of accident fatalities must be reduced by 50 percent, the number of children killed by 60 percent, and the number of seriously injured individuals by 40 percent.
This is in the best interest of each and every one of our people, as well as our economy.
We recommend that the Member States break down the objectives and methods into their own territory and expect them to develop their own road safety action programmes.
Secondly, it specifies who is responsible for each activity and measure.
This is by no means just the European Union.

In the context of subsidiarity, the holistic approach means that Member States, regional or local authorities, and even individual road users must take responsibility in line with their duty to cooperate.
And thirdly, it includes how, i.e. with which instruments, activities, and measures the goals are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are just one strategy.
We cannot and do not want to do without guidelines, recommendations, and assignments.
Particular attention has been paid to subsidiarity, which means that responsibilities and areas of competence have been clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission's diverse activities.

However, since they come from a wide variety of directorates-general, such as transport, economy, consumer protection, environment, communication, research and development, internal market, and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes even contradict each other.
This is why we propose the appointment of a road safety coordinator within the European Commission.
This sustainably avoids the establishment of a road safety agency, but greatly increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the selection of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically grounded approach based on comparable, high-quality data, definitions, and statistics.
We therefore call for, among other things, a harmonised analysis of injury and accident causes, as well as the EU-wide exchange of data while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six main fields of action were identified.
They concern humans as road users, traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructure, their intelligent networking, and the special consideration of vulnerable road users.
I request approval for tomorrow.
Thank you, dear chairperson, dear colleagues. Yes, we should focus on urgent and essential issues in traffic safety.
I am very convinced of this, and in my view, this primarily concerns the two biggest attention-distractors in traffic: alcohol and excessive speed.
The European Union also needs to have something to say about this and not just propose technical measures, which in my opinion are good but far from sufficient.
The lack of attention, especially in cities, is a particularly dramatic problem for inattentive drivers.
That's why the speed has to be reduced here.
And I was very pleasantly surprised that there was a broad majority in favor of recommending Tempo 30.

This needs to be given special consideration, and it is included, and I think it is important and good that weak road users are finally being brought into focus, and I hope that these measures will finally be implemented.
That seems pointless to me, but I would like to extend an invitation to him.
I have never seen him in the discussions about Rio or about other major global conferences, but I have always heard him speaking here in the plenary.
I would really like to ask you, Mr. Colleague, to come to the committee.
Engage with us, submit your proposals, and we will continue to discuss the statement with you.
And the contribution you just made to the discussion is completely useless.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your introductory remarks.
However, these general statements are not an answer to the questions that were asked.
Because the questions are aimed at ensuring that we quickly arrive at results.
The industries that we want to exempt from these additional burdens or where we want to establish fair conditions need planning security.
We therefore need quick decisions.
We need swift decisions, reliable decisions and also clear statements from the Commission.
And this process has been going on for a very, very long time.

We all knew that this was a very complicated procedure that we were embarking on. But back then, in the compromise on the Emissions Trading Directive, we also said that we would do this under the Emissions Trading Directive.
provided that the industries in Europe, which are unduly burdened by this, can experience relief, because otherwise they cannot compete with other areas of the world.
And I expect that what was the basis for the deal back then, was also the basis for the decision in Parliament, with the Council, with the Commission, that it will be implemented in this way.

And I'm a bit concerned that along the way, the circle of people affected by this is getting smaller and smaller, that one becomes, if I may put it this way, increasingly more narrow-minded in their perspective, that one excludes more and more areas.

It's not just about steel, it's about aluminum, you know that. It's about many other areas, chemistry and so on. And that you simply don't implement in reality what was the political basis for the decision back then.
Commissioner, you have rightly pointed out that the situation for industry in Europe has not become easier since this decision, but rather it has become much more difficult.
we have a completely new situation, we have a much more competitive situation
We are all fighting for this and are saying in Sunday sermons that industry is a very important area for the future development of Europe.
Yesterday, we heard some wise speeches here again.

I expect, and I believe that Parliament expects, that what was agreed upon back then will also be implemented now. This is for the benefit of the industries, not the industries themselves, but the people who work in these companies, the jobs, and thus also Europe's future opportunities.
Do you know of any example that would actually justify the effort of spending many millions, indeed billions, to develop these body scanners?
Are there examples that prove that this has increased safety?
Thank you, Mr President. I would like to start by thanking the Council representative for the very clear description of the current situation.
We have constantly heard in this debate that it is about improving the situation for working women who have to decide for a child.
In my opinion, the directive focuses too much on increasing maternity protection to 20 weeks.
But do we really believe that the decision to have a child can be reduced to 20 weeks of maternity leave?

As a mother of three children, I am well aware that comprehensive concepts for family-friendly services and good offers for families are necessary to positively influence the decision to have a child and to establish equal opportunities for women.
The present draft of the guidelines does not do justice to the diverse, and in some cases very good, proposal and overall concepts in some Member States.
We need flexible solutions that are tailored to the situation in the member states and societies and the resulting needs of families.
Maximum demands and wishful concerts do not lead to a solution here.
That is why we must first develop a solid and realistic basis for negotiations here in Parliament.
And the comprehensive protection of mothers and the well-being of children have the highest priority there.
This can be ensured in different ways with different models.
Those who want to get somewhere by charging headfirst into a wall won't necessarily reach their destination faster.
A lack of willingness to compromise does not open doors or build bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution for more maternity protection in order to move forward here.

I believe that we really need to look for a new approach based on the Commission's draft directive, with more flexibility for different concepts in individual Member States, in order to significantly improve maternity protection for women and also protection for children in their first months of life.
This does not work with the draft that is before us today, which certainly did not have the broad majority support, as some colleagues have tried to make clear today.

I would like to see a bit more flexibility and a bit more realism here, and a bit of a better look at what the member states have already achieved today, without questioning our basic demands for that.
Yes, Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to make a few comments on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have already done.
Instead of putting a stop to tax evasion, which would be sensible, and instead of plugging the loopholes for tax evaders, they have produced a Swiss cheese with large holes.
The planned transition period of five months gives tax evaders plenty of time to transfer funds from Switzerland to other tax havens.
Since foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is sufficient to convert the assets stored in Switzerland into foundation assets,
The relevant forms are available at Swiss banks.
The tax investigation authorities in Germany recently received information about several tax evaders who are hiding their assets in Switzerland.
The agreement now grants these individuals amnesty, and the tax investigators are no longer allowed to use the information they have.
What kind of agreement is this that ties the tax investigation to a chain?
A promotional video for Swiss banks states that, as a result of this agreement, customers will continue to benefit even more from the values of the Swiss financial sector in the future.

This agreement is obviously lacking not only the necessary coordination at the EU level. It also contradicts the EU's efforts to create more transparency in tax matters, to make tax collection more efficient in the member states, and above all to combat and prevent tax fraud.
Therefore, in our view, this cannot be acceptable.
this agreement and we ask the EU to also stand up against it in case of doubt. Thank you.
Mr President, thank you very much. In accordance with the rules of procedure of our House and in consultation with the groups, I request the referral of this work back to the committees.
Thank you, Madam President. I am pleased that we have succeeded in getting a sustainable, effective directive off the ground with Roberta Angelilli's report, and I would like to thank her for that.
The directive represents a significant step in the fight against child abuse.
However, we must not lose sight of one thing: the vast majority of crimes still occur within children's immediate social environment.
The perpetrators are found in families, schools, and social circles,
And here we are still at the beginning of our educational work.

That is why our children need to be empowered. Strong enough to have the courage to confide in a trusted person in an emergency, but also strong enough to recognize dangers such as grooming when using the internet.
We must therefore work together to ensure that media literacy plays a greater role in the education of our children.
Education is of utmost importance here, as many teachers and parents are unaware of what their children can do with computers or mobile phones.
And I believe there is a great need to catch up.

It is therefore to be welcomed that the present report also places great emphasis on prevention, since the authorities, as well as schools and families, must do everything in their power to prevent such heinous crimes from occurring in the first place.
As a result, the EU also needs better negotiation strategies with third countries, such as the USA and Russia.

And pages stored outside the EU can only be deleted effectively and quickly if we also work closely with these countries in the search for the perpetrators and jointly send out a clear signal against the condemnation of child sexual abuse.
Once the perpetrator has been caught, the legislator has unfortunately often been surprisingly lenient, suspending the majority of crimes on probation.
In future, the severity of the offence will be taken into greater account here.
Overall, however, it is important that the public debate continues, as the topic has a wide range of dimensions.

Prevention, victim protection, technical development, as well as extinguishing before blocking, legal proceedings, education, and intensive scientific documentation of the facts must continue to be advanced even after tomorrow's vote.
The fact is that we must by no means fold our arms and do nothing.
Rather, we must all accept the call to action, each of us, and ensure prevention and education.
Thank you, Mr President. For years, the volume of the EU budget has remained at approximately the same level.
The EU's tasks have constantly expanded and the financial requirements have increased significantly.
Thus, necessary new institutions have been created for financial market supervision.
However, in order for these institutions to effectively carry out their tasks, they need to be well-funded.
As a result of the financial and banking crisis, the economic weaknesses of some EU member states have become undeniable.
To strengthen the economy of these countries, a comprehensive economic stimulus program would be necessary.
Some economic experts even speak of the need for a Marshall Plan for the crisis-ridden EU countries.
The EU does not need austerity programs that destroy growth, but rather a growth-promoting spending program that secures jobs and income for workers and young people in the EU.
but what is the Council doing in this situation
It shortens the Commission proposal, which already falls far short of what is needed.

If a reasonable increase in the budget is not feasible in the current political climate, then Parliament and the Commission should do everything in their power to at least prevent the cuts proposed by the Council. Thank you.

until it makes it more difficult. Mrs. Zimmer, here is the laptop, please. Yes, thank you very much, Mrs. Zimmer. Ladies and gentlemen, it is precisely in times of crisis that it becomes apparent what kind of European Union we really want.

Do we want a Union where the actual glue that binds us together is that we say it is not indifferent to us whether people have to live in poverty in any country within the member states of the European Union?
let us recognize our shared responsibility to fight against poverty and social exclusion.
Or do we opt for a union as outlined by colleagues from the far-right factions in this Parliament?

Sometimes I believe that with the attitude of the member states and especially some governments of these member states, we are dangerously close to this vision of a European Union as formulated by the right-wing extremists.
Just don't do anything together, don't use any common tools, don't set any common indicators, use vague wording wherever possible.
The Third Report makes this very, very clear on many issues, and I believe we need to become much stronger in this area.
What we need is an immediate halt to the sell-off of public assets, the sell-off of social security systems.
We need social and ecological minimum standards.
With winter approaching, it cannot happen again that people end up on the streets, are evicted, and ultimately freeze to death because of rising energy prices.
Here we share a common responsibility, the responsibility as the European Union.
We must stand up for that, not for the nationalist nonsense we've heard from the right.

What advice would we have given to our colleagues in 1931 or 1938, when we were in the midst of the Depression, when the financial markets had already undermined the democracies and when we were heading towards wars?
I think two things would be necessary. Two emergency measures. We need something like a transitional government.
Do what you need to do quickly. Don't let yourself be slowed down. Regulate every product, every institution, and every player like Frau Möller.
Merkel said. But a transitional government alone that enforces the fiscal emergency program cannot have a future if there is no democratic emergency program.

And that means in this case, of course, we need a European community, of course we need other treaties, of course we need a system that works, but that only becomes legitimate and gains legitimacy if there are popular votes.

And we need to start campaigning now because the situation has become so dramatic that a complete change of thinking is necessary before the right-wingers, before the national dividers, regain control over something that was already built up.
Thank you, Madam President. There is no doubt that this House is committed to transparency and openness towards the citizens.
Of course, my EPP Group does that too.
But the present report goes far beyond the actual goal.
Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are being ignored. The protection of competitive processes, sensitive and personal data is being disregarded.
This is a massive violation of data protection, which we otherwise always advocate for.
Should we now give up the privacy of the world public?
This is precisely the danger with the present report, because administrative procedures and decisions, which also include personnel issues, for example, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information in the context of approval procedures, court proceedings and competition proceedings.

With its vague, unclear, and overly broad definitions, the report allows public access to such documents as well. This is because a document is defined as any data or content that is in any way related to the policies, measures, or decisions of any EU body or institution.
This also largely includes preparatory, confidential and secret documents, as well as all related information.
And so this definition encompasses not only documents, but also information.
Information from ongoing interinstitutional procedures, such as informal trilogue negotiations, must also be published.
Do you know, Mr. Rapporteur, what that really means?

It means public access to the proceedings. It means public influence on the decision-making process. Then we might as well just bring in the lobbyists and let them negotiate. But does the public really want that?
I can't imagine it.
In addition, documents related to non-legislative procedures, internal administrative measures, etc., are also to be published. Where is the public interest in that?
Or would it not rather hinder our work?
I believe this report was not created in the best interests of our citizens.
It would bring about a flood of useless information.
He would make our work impossible and, above all, as you heard from the Commissioner, he is not acceptable to the other institutions because he violates the existing rules and laws.
You know that, Mr. Rapporteur, and basically, you are working against further transparency and against the citizens. Thank you.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, with such an important and comprehensive topic as the White Paper on the future of transport, there is always a great risk of ending up with a Christmas tree, where everyone tries to accommodate their two or three preferred topics.
When you look at the result that will be put to a vote tomorrow, you can undoubtedly congratulate our rapporteur Mathieu Grosch.

He has managed to develop a good, coherent and manageable result from several hundred proposed amendments, which sets the main focus for the future of transport on safety, environmental protection, energy and technology.
I expressly welcome the fact that such important issues as the social, health, and labor law conditions of employees are adequately mentioned here.

This is particularly important in view of the impending shortage of skilled workers in the transport sector, which must be actively addressed if bottlenecks in well-trained professionals are to be prevented in the future.
Further opening up of cabotage in road transport only on the condition that social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given an important place here.
The safety on our roads is an issue that we must continue to address in the future.
I have a more critical view of other points.
That's how I would have liked a statement on the model ship, where more traffic would be shifted from the road to the rail and waterways.
And for this reason, I also do not think the discussion about the Giga-Liner is the best solution for more sustainability.
Further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening up of national passenger transport should also be critically evaluated and reconsidered.
There are still technical harmonization and fair competition conditions to be resolved here.

But as I said, in this report, I hope that the expectations of Parliament are expressed here, that it does not remain a pious wish list, but that a goal is achieved by 2020 and our proposals have become reality. Thank you very much.
It has only been 20 years since the Central Asian states gained their state independence as a result of the collapse of the Soviet Union.
Coming from a dictatorship, the establishment of democratic and rule-of-law structures in these states remains a lasting challenge.
Nevertheless, these states are important trading partners of the EU and its member states due to their wealth of mineral resources and raw materials.
It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU's relations with these states within the framework of partnership and cooperation agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements are intended to promote collaboration and foster partnership-based actions, but not to lead to unilateral stigmatization.
Child labor, and especially forced child labor, is unfortunately still a widespread problem in many countries around the world that needs to be combated.

However, it should be noted that it was common in many agriculturally-oriented European regions to extend school holidays for children during harvest time and to give children from farming families the opportunity to help with the harvest, which no one would today describe as forced labor.
However, if there are signs of child forced labor in the cotton harvest in Uzbekistan, consequences must be drawn.

The same consequence must then apply to all other countries where child labor still exists, including those where we pursue economic interests of a completely different magnitude, such as in India or China.
We should not apply double standards here.
Mr President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I can only join those who have already congratulated the Presidency of the Council.
In difficult times, they were not only an honest broker, but also a European broker.
I think that was very comforting to feel in these difficult times, when we have political currents in a number of member states that suggest to people that one could achieve more alone than together.
and you have placed the commonalities at the forefront
And it was also very refreshing to see that you have also found approval among the people in Poland in the internal political debate with this clear European agenda.
It wasn't exactly easy in this context.
and also the highest respect for what you have achieved.
In the past six months, we have been able to make significant progress, particularly in the area of financial market regulation.

If I may single out one area of focus that I was able to negotiate myself, namely the issue of regulation for short selling and uncovered credit default swaps on government bonds, where the Commission has not dared to propose strict regulations, where everyone has told us

Member States were told that they would not prevail, and where it has been possible, thanks to the Polish Presidency of the Council, to sanction such a highly speculative instrument and where it is necessary to ban it in order to contribute to greater stability in the financial markets.
I would like to express my sincere thanks to your Finance Minister and the Secretary of State, who have brought this about through a laborious discussion process between Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of what can be achieved together in the interests of security and stability in Europe.
Mr. Steers, thank you for that.
Since yesterday, colleagues, the new surveillance mechanism for economic imbalances has come into effect.
In the meantime, the specific content regulations are also available.
Which developments does the Commission now consider dangerous? Which economic problems does it want to see corrected?
An increase in unit labor costs in Euro countries of more than 3% per year is considered a problem by the Commission.
A threshold value for falling wages, on the other hand, is not planned.
Cheap, dear Commission, does not automatically mean good.
It is not enough to train the member states to achieve prosperity at the expense of their trading partners.
Without investments in education, health, and energy efficiency, we can exploit our workers to the bone, but we won't be writing any economic success stories that way.
Another example from the scoreboard: the loss of export market shares should be monitored and penalized.
That's nonsense.
As global trade increases, Europe's share statistically speaking inevitably decreases.
The indicator therefore penalizes countries that are already integrated into global trade.
That is why we believe the Commission should withdraw this basket and overhaul it. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by joining in the thanks to our rapporteur and everyone who worked on the report, because it is not routine, even if this is the 40th time we have had to deal with competition policy on the basis of a Commission report.
I would like to thank the Commissioner very much because 2010 was the year when you were fully responsible for competition policy for the first time, for the very comprehensive presentation.

However, I would like to express the hope, and you have just addressed this in your contribution, that we will soon see some progress in the area of subsidies, particularly public subsidies in the banking sector.
should have come, because now, due to the new stress test by the European banking supervisor, a new capitalization in the banking sector is once again being demanded.
and I don't believe that all of this contributes to the stability of the banking system when on the one hand we still have a multitude of unanswered or unresolved legacy issues
We have, and in fact, new cases have already arisen as a result of the pressure being built up to increase the equity ratio, particularly in the area of private banks.

So, here is my truly urgent request, Commissioner, to reach a swift solution that also contributes to stabilizing the banking sector in such a way that it can also meet the challenges in the international environment.
The second major issue, merger control, will continue to be a major concern for us in the coming years.
Here, too, I can only urge the Commission to continue along the clear and transparent path it has taken so far in the context of merger control.

I believe that it is in the interest of all parties involved, especially consumers, that we ensure in the area of merger control that competition is possible even in larger or different structures, which I do not wish to evaluate.
In that sense, thank you to everyone who has worked on this. And I hope, Commissioner, that we will soon reach a solution, particularly in the banking sector. Thank you.

Commissioner, I believe you have just hit the nail on the head by jointly acknowledging that we are capable of launching a third industrial revolution in Europe if we realize that we can seize the sustainability opportunity as an industrial opportunity.
Then you also spoke of resources, and that brings to mind a thought that I have completely forgotten about today.
I forgot about the human resources in my office.
And Mrs. Philipp, allow me to say that you have worked like a horse. The results are wonderful, you were a key person in this matter.
And for that, I would like to express my gratitude.
Thank you, Mr. President. In order to exercise freedom of speech in Parliament, one also needs a functioning microphone system.
My button for turning on the microphone has broken.
I would like to request that a technician restore the freedom of speech. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, honourable colleagues. It amazes me that we always have to remind people what structural and cohesion policy actually means.

Cohesion and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union and, by definition, it is intended to strengthen economic and social cohesion within the Community, while promoting growth and employment in underdeveloped regions in particular.
The necessity and success of coalition and structural policies have proven themselves, especially during the years of crisis.
In many regions, the situation looks even more difficult. As far as economic development is concerned, these funds would not be available.
The implementation of the funding structure is based on operational programmes, as previously mentioned, which describe the funding strategy of the respective region.
The European Union, Member States and regions are working together in partnership here, thereby creating genuine European added value.
The success of coalition and structural policy is also based on the reliability of the programs and the funds made available and allocated.

That is why I am very surprised when Member States, and also the Commission, as we are now seeing, repeatedly attempt to use the Structural Funds as a piggy bank for all sorts of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the sense and purpose of coalition policy and furthermore unsettles the actors in the regions who are already working on achieving the goals on the basis of long-term strategies and contracts.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and promoting economic growth are important goals.

However, this will only be achieved if the partnership-based cooperation between the regions, the Member States and the Commission is maintained and the actors in the regions are involved and remain involved.
Because only you have the knowledge of what needs to be done in your regions.
Cohesion and structural policy is the unifying, partnership-based, and solidarity-driven link between the various policy levels in the European Union.
It makes the solidarity of Europe visible on the ground in the regions and it should not be abandoned lightly due to political quick fixes. Many thanks.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman, Commissioner. I support the compromise found in the Triod, which aims to strengthen the negotiating power of dairy farmers vis-à-vis the processing industry, although I am aware that it does not solve all the problems currently facing dairy farmers in some Member States.
As early as 50 years ago, Commissioner Manzold had provided preferential measures for the creation of producer associations as part of the CAP.
In my country, Luxembourg, the dairy industry is the main pillar of our agriculture due to the high proportion of grassland.
Our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to join together in a cooperative that handles milk processing itself.
Five member states voted against the compromise in the Council for precisely this reason, as it does not meet its requirements as a soft landing instrument.

The European Commission has the right of initiative when it comes to legislative proposals, which is why I would like to urge you to submit a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament in 2012 to correct this obvious and costly error in the system.

A linear reduction in the superlevy by 2015, which is applied to each kilo of milk delivered, or the abolition of the fat correction, could at least mitigate the negative effects of the expiring regulation without harming the unaffected member states.
However, the present milk package is also intended as a final report by the High-Level Group, which aims to ensure a smooth transition when milk quotas are phased out.
It is astonishing that milk quotas are not mentioned at all in this report.
The young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and four other member states, who are trying to prepare for the liberalization of the milk market and expand their production,
In order to remain competitive in the global market after 2015, they can only do so by purchasing additional quotas now, even as the milk quota system is nearing its end.
A huge additional and unnecessary capital expenditure that puts them at a disadvantage compared to their counterparts in 22 member states. Thank you.
So, by all means, the Blue Cut. Question: are you aware that we have had community bonds for a long time now?
And the resolution does not speak of Eurobonds in general, but of very different options.
and are you aware that not all of these options require a contract amendment
I find it questionable that you have once again isolated generalities about Eurobonds here.
We should not give up the level of detail that we have achieved here with Mrs Goulart's good proposal.
I would like to hear a bit more differentiation in your statements and am curious to hear what you have to say about it.
I just want to say briefly, dear colleague Gulda, that this is not an evaluation I have made here.
I just want to point out that the last Italian government bond before Italy joined the euro yielded 10%.
and there was no outcry in Italy and no one said that other countries should now take over
It was self-evident that one had to pay high interest rates.

And now suddenly, because we had ten years of low interest rates and got into excessive debt because money became cheap, for investments as well as for public spending, we want to prolong this with Eurobonds.
This is a trap from which we cannot escape, and I stand by that.
Thank you very much, Commissioner. Your answer has really rather disappointed me.

They obviously want to stick to the old system, where complicated negotiations have to be conducted per country and where, in turn, no further access to literature is granted, meaning that no additional opportunities are created for the blind and visually impaired.
This is all the more sad for me because the European Union is now blocking a step forward in the WIPO, while all the other or many other contracting parties would be willing to move forward.
A huge opportunity is being missed here.

They are not fighting for more rights for authors here, but against people to whom the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities should guarantee equal access to cultural goods and that they can also participate fully in these cultural goods.
I appeal to you, please break down the barriers and agree to a binding contract.

Dear colleagues, the discussion here in this House shows that we actually represent the entire spectrum. On one side are those who want no restrictions at all, and on the other are those who associate every form of immigration with the threat of mass migration.
These are the two extremes within this house.
I believe that family reunification must be considered with great reason and also expressed with rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed problems in member states where measures are taken that are too restrictive.
Because family reunification cannot be burdened with so many obstacles that in the end no one can be reunited.
On the other hand, it is entirely justified that member states demand language skills, that they demand integration, but also that they demand a willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, the Member States naturally have the right, and we should not push these problems to one side, to articulate the problems that arise in the context of family reunification.

If countries like Greece or Malta or Romania or Italy are no longer allowed to express the problems they have in this context, then I no longer know if we are democratic if we simply ignore the problems.
I don't think we need another directive just yet
I believe we should discuss the problems carefully and then think about how we can eliminate them.
The constant re-production of guidelines does not lead to an improvement of the guidelines and their implementation.
We currently have some implementation problems,

And I also fully understand that we first need to come to terms with the fact that we should not be creating a new directive and adding something to it before we have thoroughly discussed the problems of the old directive in any way.
I am in favor of listening to the member states and at the same time respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
And if one does this with reason and understanding, then I also believe that we will find a good path.
Mr President, Pomyśl, Sanim, Pomyśl. "Think, Sanim, think," urges the Polish aphorist Stanislaw Wierzylec. And we in this Parliament could sometimes do with this piece of advice.

A few weeks after the resolution on the Central Asia strategy was adopted in this House, in which the Central Asian states were given failing grades, attention is now being drawn to the strike events in Zhanaozen.
reflecting on the situation in Kazakhstan, without waiting for the results of the ongoing investigations, which are being carried out with international participation.
As much as the dead are to be lamented, and the injured and detained have the right to an investigation of the events that followed, the background remains unclear.

Even Vladimir Koslov, chairman of the unregistered opposition party ALGA, said, "That was a group of other people. The unrest is not in the interest of the strikers, because it only provides a reason to take violent action against them."
Central Asia expert Arkady Dubnov said, also quoting, that it is not impossible that parts of the Kazakh opposition living abroad are also involved.
On the other hand, it could well suit someone in the Kazakh capital Astana to maintain the tensions.
After all, the power elite in Kazakhstan are already fighting over the succession of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
End of quote. We had the opportunity to speak with the Kazakh opposition in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador here in Parliament.

The UN special envoy Miroslav Jentschak announced today that he is impressed by the Kazakh government's attention to the events of Jana Ozen, and that it is necessary to uncover the true background of the unrest.
We should take the Kashmiri authorities at their word, judge them by their actions, but not resort to knee-jerk condemnations.
If I understand correctly, the statement you made today is: Yes, the Commission is fighting to continue the food program for the most needy people in the European Union.
It will do everything possible to present concrete ideas in the foreseeable future, a) where the program will be located exactly, b) how funding will be arranged.
I believe this is urgently necessary and think that we share the responsibility of ensuring that this food program actually becomes a reality.
not because I consider it the ultima ratio, but because in my view it is a signal to show people that we still have a basic sense of the necessary solidarity with those in need.

the living conditions of people in the European Union who, unfortunately, have not been able to participate in development and who have become the first and greatest victims of the way the European Union has fought the crisis.
I am thinking here of Greece, I am thinking of Spain, I am thinking of other countries where exactly what we do as the European Union primarily harms the poorest of the poor.
We are setting an example, but unfortunately it is no longer enough.
I therefore think that it is urgently necessary that we do not only consider the 18 million people in the European Union who are currently dependent on food aid being provided to them

It is not about making resources available, but rather that it must be about putting the fight against poverty back on the top agenda, or even placing it there for the first time, at the top of our own agenda.
We have not conveyed this signal so far.

But in my view, this is the crucial point if we want to make progress here and if we also want to gain the trust of the citizens of our European Union that we are truly creating a social and solidaristic Union.
In that sense, you have our support.
We ourselves, dear colleagues, are also called upon to do something to ensure that the governments that have been blocking progress must abandon this attitude.
I think that's also a piece of self-commitment for us.
Esteemed colleague Dohl, I have listened to you attentively.
What you are proposing, namely to introduce a growth test for all expenditure in parallel with the subsidiarity test, effectively means narrowing down the objectives to growth.
I would like to know how you reconcile that with the principles of a Christian Democratic faction, which surely still recognizes goals beyond growth.
It is common knowledge that the economy cannot give birth to children, raise them, or provide them with a life in an intact natural environment.
This suggests that the priorities are being changed by the Commission and also by the Council, and that they are being reconsidered.
As a group, we will carefully examine whether what you presented this morning actually corresponds to a change in priorities.
Until now, the motto has been: the economy first, and it needs functioning financial markets.
And that was initially what it was all about: to restructure public finances, reduce debt, and keep the markets calm.
And Mr. Dohl, who unfortunately is not present now, I just wanted to say that I would hold the same opinion as Georges Marchais.
Although I didn't understand his answer, I would disagree with him.
I think the measures that have been introduced were simply wrong.
They were not right. It was not right to focus solely on economic recovery and completely ignore what happened to the people.
It was not right to prioritize the stability of the euro above all else and to say, "What happens to the people is completely irrelevant to us."
It has to be the other way around. First, it's about the people, and then we can continue to talk about euro stabilization.

The speculative attacks on Spain pushed the interest rates for Spanish government bonds to over 6% and more, and thus also close to the interest rate level at which other countries such as Greece, Portugal, or Ireland had to resort to the support of the rescue fund.
And the austerity policies imposed on the member state by the EU, the ECB, and also by the IMF, with drastic reductions in all types of public spending.
The reduction of wages and pensions, the increase in VAT, and much more have placed the burden on citizens and have not prevented a new spiral of austerity.
Rigorous cuts in public spending, exacerbated by the downturn, are driving up the debt ratio of states. And this must be our common realization.
When Mr Draghi recently said that the European social model is finished, I am pleased, Mr Barroso, that you say no, we in the Commission do not think like that.
Then I also expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece and to Portugal, to Ireland, and to carefully document what happens there.
What happens to people who are currently struggling to survive?
What is happening or what are we doing together to finally interrupt this suicide spiral that has begun, especially in the most affected debtor countries?
We can't just stand by and watch this happen.
And we are of no benefit from socio-political programs that will work at some point in the future, when other measures have already taken effect.
We need to act now. Where have your objectives from the 2020 strategy to combat poverty gone?
Whatever happened to the European poverty platform?
It has been set aside.
That was before the crisis.
But now, in the midst of the crisis, people need help, they need support, and they need the European Union to take action.
You don't need empty promises.
We need concrete ideas about what should be done now.
If you do that, you will get the support of my group,
Support all those who have recognized the signs of the times within the Commission and want to change things.
But please don't just carry on like this and say that it will work out.
It will be too late if things continue like this. I urge you to present a concrete project, a concrete program, on how we can now actively help the people in the affected countries.
Do something about it.
We will have to do this in our countries so that the funds for the ESF 2013 or 2014 to 2020 or for the other programmes are not blocked or cut,
that the Member States fulfil their responsibilities. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, the current state of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a fairy tale about tax policy.
The situation in the Council is quite simple: little progress is being made on tax policy proposals.
Why?
because some countries are against further tax cooperation,
They benefit from aggressive tax planning. They are tax havens themselves.
And the treaties clearly state unanimity in tax matters.
That is why the EU Commission has repeatedly suffered setbacks with its proposals in the past.
They are watered down, they don't move forward, as with the interest rate guideline. And with newer proposals, out of eagerness to comply, nothing more ambitious has been proposed.

Therefore, Mr. Schimeter, I ask you, I know your job is not easy in this regard. Change the strategy, propose strict measures, and then rely on increased cooperation to end the blockade position in the Council.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal before us will certainly not prevent a state bankruptcy where it is likely to occur, even with the risk-sharing instruments.
But doing something is still better than doing nothing at all.
And extraordinary situations sometimes require extraordinary measures.

The budget and debt crisis in some states has led to such an extraordinary situation that important projects and measures within the framework of cohesion and structural policy can no longer be implemented because the banking sector is no longer available as a financier and private investors are no longer available.
I consider the proposal to create risk-sharing instruments for the continued financing of projects in structural policy to be an extraordinary measure.
The means of cohesion and structural policy available to countries that wish to use these division instruments can be used to provide financial security for projects already underway.

I am very grateful to the rapporteur, Danuta Hübner, for her significant contribution to clarifying the Commission's proposal and for once again clearly outlining when and how these instruments should be used.
However, I also believe that these risk-sharing instruments must only be due to the current situation and cannot set a precedent for the future funding period.
When a change was called for in the 2009 regulation on biometric passports, to conduct a review after three years and submit four studies, our group supported this.
And this was also because she had repeatedly raised major concerns for data protection reasons and also because of the overestimation of the benefits of biometric data in travel passports.
The belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this method, and what follows from it, as well as the underestimation of other links in the security chain, are truly problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this major misconception, namely the assumption that it is unchangeable and most trustworthy.
And that is, in fact, not the case.
These data are also modifiable over the course of a person's life.
In children, they look different than in old age.
And that is also why reliable and serious studies and the conclusions drawn from them are necessary.
Counterfeiting continues apace.
we have now been able to determine.
As incidents in Great Britain and other countries repeatedly prove, chips are not at all secure against misuse.
They are broken cheerfully and can cause lasting damage to those affected.
Standards within the EU are also extraordinarily diverse.
The error rate is very, very high, as in France and the Netherlands.
And time and again, the question must be asked: what good are biometric data to us if documents are being forged and are in circulation?
So if one link in the chain is forged, the original documents are inconsistent, biometric data would not help us further.
One last thing: the Chaos Computer Club in Germany only needed a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

To do this, the friends from the Chaos Computer Club needed the lid of a plastic bottle, a second-hand adhesive, a digital camera, and a bit of wood glue. In just a few minutes, they had cracked the chip. That's all there is to the so-called security.
We expect the Commission to present the studies and, of course, also the results and the consequences that follow from them. Thank you.
Esteemed Council, unfortunately, the Commission is not as adequately represented today as I would have wished, out of respect for Parliament.

As a representative from a region that is massively affected by the planned changes, namely the Eifel, after carefully following the debate, I am compelled to ask whether the unfortunately only marginally viable attempt,

whether a unification of the criteria for disadvantaged areas really meets the needs of these regions. Especially since the necessary information is not available here for a meaningful and responsible decision.
Above all, I wonder whether a sufficient impact assessment was actually carried out.
In order to do justice to farmers, we need not only biophysical criteria, but also socioeconomic criteria.

And that is why I am calling on the Commission to reconsider this important aspect with the necessary time, detached from the overall package of the CAP reform, and above all after the necessary documents have been submitted and a careful analysis of the impacts has been carried out, based on the criteria.

I do believe that we must work on this, in cooperation with the Asylum Support Office and the Greek authorities, to more quickly identify which persons who have come to Greece might actually be next in line.

They can also be transferred to other countries in the European Union because, firstly, they can definitely never return to their home country and, secondly, they may also bring with them potential and qualifications that can be meaningful and goal-oriented for everyone.
However, the main goal is also to help the Greeks to facilitate registration and identification more quickly, in order to expedite the aid processes, but also

to return to their home countries those who neither have the qualifications nor the right to stay in Greece or the European Union, because they would actually have had a chance to stay in their own home countries.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Commissioner. Thank you also to the rapporteur for her always very committed and exemplary work.
I can share much of the criticism that Sophie Infeld has expressed, support this, or have also supported this in part.
but then there always comes a point at which one must take responsibility.
And for the EPP, or for myself, I therefore also maintain that we must now deal with the realities and cannot retreat to ideological or theoretical positions.
The fact is, the USA has been collecting this PNR data for ten years and there has not been a single complaint.
The fact is that we all do not want to stop data traffic, even if we hold a negative attitude towards it.
They had just carried that out.
The fact is that we do not want air traffic between Europe and the USA to come to a standstill.
And the fact is that the USA has a right to know who is coming into their country.
And the fact is, in my opinion, that the legal services have all told us verbally that this agreement is better than the other agreement, than the alternatives.
That is why one must also take responsibility here.
and this is why we were elected
Responsibility for the citizens, whom one would otherwise leave alone with less protection and rights.
responsibility for the airlines, which would otherwise be left in absolute legal uncertainty, as the Commissioner had also pointed out.
Responsibility also for the EU as a contracting party in matters of data protection and security, and also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
That is why, all in all, even considering that this agreement is not perfect, we are in favor of agreeing to this agreement in the end.

And if you want to better protect citizens and if you also want to provide citizens with better data protection, you take on this responsibility here as well and agree to this agreement. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr President. Thank you, Commissioner. Those were insightful statements you gave us.
Thank you very much for that.

Figures sometimes say more than big words, and to this day, the European Parliament, as you also mentioned, and the European Patent Office have granted nearly 2,000 patents for plants and almost 1,200 patents for animals, which were developed with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I can mention two outstanding examples. The approval of patents on genetically modified and selectively bred barley. This applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
This is why our farmers, as well as our brewers and producers, are affected, as are we consumers.
And this example, in my opinion, shows a devastating extent of patenting.
Second example, the so-called long-life tomato. Not to be confused with your long-life oil that you have in your diesel engines.
This patent was obtained using a trick by the US-based company Arcadia, which bypassed the valid EU rules.
It is not the tomato that has been patented, but its genetic material, specifically selected enzymes.

This shows the tricks being used here. And this is despite the fact that, as you said, Commissioner, in Article 4 of the 1998 Directive on the Legal Protection of Biotechnological Inventions (Directive 98/44/EC), it is clearly stated that plant varieties and animal breeds a and b, which are essentially biological processes for the production of plants or animals, are not patentable.
We believe that this definition needs to be clarified, it needs to be interpreted more precisely.
Technical procedures used to support conventional breeding should not lead to patentability as a whole.
We specifically do not patent life.
And we need a clear signal here for more ethics and more honesty in dealing with creation, once again against the patentability of life throughout Europe.
Therefore, Commissioner, we demand a clear statement from the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are and will remain prohibited in Europe.
Secondly, we demand a clear stance on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive: no patents on life.
And thirdly, Commissioner, on behalf of many farmers and breeders in Europe, we demand a clear establishment of the breeder and farmer privilege throughout all legislation. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. I am speaking on the discharge for Europol and Eurojust.
Regarding Europol: there is little to no cause for complaint here.
The annual financial statements reflect the financial situation in 2010 in all material respects, and all underlying transactions are in accordance with regulations and therefore also lawful.
The only thing that stands out is the high transfers in relation to the overall low initial costs.
Europol attributes this to the move to a new headquarters. This is, of course, understandable.
