But Europol says it will take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
Furthermore, Europol intends to commit to monthly monitoring of budget execution starting in 2012.
I recommend that we follow up on this to see if it actually happens.
Against this background, I recommend granting Europol discharge.
Regarding Eurojust, the annual accounts also reflect the financial situation in 2010 in all material respects.
All transactions are also lawful and compliant here.
But here too, high operating expenses were carried over to 2011.
According to Eurojust, this was mainly due to an organizational structure project, a new computer infrastructure, and data processing costs.
It is announced that all of this will be improved in the future, and that tender requirements will also be better adhered to.
I also recommend that we review this in the future and, above all, check whether all open positions are actually filled in the future.
That has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, we would have to consider cutting funds, and that would be negative for Orius.
I still recommend discharge. Thank you.
Madam President, most esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what should worry and alarm us is not the sheer number of unemployed young people in Europe alone, but the trend.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of unemployed young people increased by 26.5 percent, according to the International Labour Organization.
It is this development that urgently requires measures. We are not only disconnecting an entire generation from the job market, we are disconnecting an entire generation from a livable future.
If we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that young people are turning away from this EU because they have no reasonable work and life prospects.

Commissioner, I urgently request that you ensure that decisive countermeasures are initiated. I already recognize some progress, but please make sure that the long-standing mental lull does not now turn into operational haste.

When I read that the Commission is launching a program under which young people applying abroad are now to receive financial support, then we are organizing a traveling circus that does not solve the problem.
And on the contrary, it becomes counterproductive. Technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff are then lured away from the states that are wealthier and not in this crisis.

What is needed now, in this crisis, is to identify the cause of this development. Offensive measures, namely the reduction of this austerity policy, which is having a negative impact on the economy in Europe.
We need a targeted growth policy, we need to strengthen domestic purchasing power, public investment in education, research, and alternative energies.
that would be the way
By combining it with European funding, it would then be possible to actually develop an integrated concept that creates a life perspective for young people.
Last remark: This youth unemployment is also incompatible with the nonsense of wanting to raise the retirement age for people to 70.
We need a different policy that gives young people access to the job market.
That is why I make a heartfelt request. Thank you.
Colleague, you just said that everything that would speak in favor of the financial transaction tax is speculation, and then you came up with very speculative examples yourself.

I would like to know from you what you think, in light of what you have said, about these investigations by the Commission and the student commission, which very, very clearly state that the real economy has so far been mistakenly included far too little in its dependence on...

The financial markets have been shown that 95% of companies are by no means dependent on borrowing money and that it is indeed possible to reverse the negative growth effect that has been discussed so far by spending on corresponding growth promotion of public investments.
Is this just speculation for you, or would you say that such a well-founded, broad-ranging study by the Commission also has its justification and represents a strong argument?

Thank you very much. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, the financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been under discussion for many years, but I believe it incorporates essential elements of the Tobin tax.
She is at least open to the idea of involving the financial markets in taxation, taxing them, and, above all, making them share in the costs of the crisis.
I think that is a very important signal to the financial markets,
But this is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.
There were a number of actions in a whole series of member countries, including petitions and written appeals to politicians to finally introduce a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I think that the Parliament has achieved a great success with the majority that is emerging here for this report, for this tax.
Certainly, this is not enough to stabilize and limit the financial markets, as might be necessary. But I think it is a truly important step that has been taken here.
And I would like to expressly appeal to the Council to take the voices of citizens, voters, seriously and to work towards this end.
that there will be a real introduction, that the introduction of this tax will not be blocked in the Council due to the British position or other positions.
I think it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax and I think it is a great responsibility in the

It is now up to the Council to take action. And I would like to use my speaking time to appeal to the Council to do everything in its power to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, I believe that despite all the detailed issues that can be discussed and will be discussed further in the legislative process, we should be pleased about one thing in particular.
It must be clear: financial markets cannot function according to the model where banks pocket the profits when everything goes well, and taxpayers foot the bill when things go wrong.
And that is why it makes sense to subject financial transactions to a tax.
And it makes sense to do this across borders.

In Europe, or at least in the Eurozone, we will not have upheavals, but rather we will make a lasting contribution to achieving a stable financial center that generates what financial centers are actually intended for, namely that companies pay.

Having access to capital means that savers have the opportunity to put something aside or set aside for retirement, and that the financial markets once again fulfill the purpose for which they were created, namely to provide added value for the real economy.
What drove us into the financial crisis were products that created no value for the real economy.

And that is why it makes sense to contribute through a tax to ensure that this is heavily punished, that it is sanctioned, that it is controlled, in the sense that capital once again fulfills its purpose.
And that is why I am advocating for this proposal to be adopted by a large majority today.
The reform of the general preferential system was indeed necessary.
It is good now that there are longer repayment periods and that there is more security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the Development Committee has already pointed out.
Unfortunately, the Commission only refers to World Bank classifications.
In the past, Parliament has repeatedly expressed strong criticism of the gross domestic product as the sole criterion.
The definition of upper-middle-income countries can refer to countries with a gross domestic product of $4,000 or up to $12,000.
So that is a huge and far too wide range. And it does not do justice to the realities on the ground in any way.
We certainly don't find it problematic that countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are dropping out.
The reform in this regard was therefore good.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China, on the other hand, are countries with upper-middle incomes. We certainly don't have to worry about them falling out of the APS either.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer countries, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Up until now, the Commission had at least also taken into account the vulnerability criterion, i.e., countries that export little or only very few goods.
This at least prevents countries that are less dependent on exporting products and are therefore very vulnerable from being rated too high.
Why, then, did the Commission highlight this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji, Gabon, and Botswana, for example, will thus be excluded, even though their economies fall below the vulnerability criterion.
Why didn't the Commission continue with the old criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate anyway?
There is a growing suspicion that the Commission wants to force poorer countries into unfavorable free trade agreements.

The preference system, however, is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development path of a country or region no longer plays any role at all.
Fortunately, however, our colleagues in the plenary will still have the opportunity to agree to our amendment, which includes vulnerability as a criterion.
However, the new regulation also leads to trade regions being torn apart.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
And the Commission should focus more on developing regions rather than individual countries.
Here too, we Greens have submitted an amendment, which we hope will receive a lot of support.
And it is also problematic when countries that have benefited from the APS until yesterday are supposed to fall out of the program overnight.
We see in our own countries that transition periods are necessary and that a few months are not enough for economic development.

Ultimately, however, we Members of Parliament must also consider whether we want to focus solely on speed for all legislative initiatives and then work with lopsided compromises, or whether we would rather involve the entire plenary.

I believe that the entire parliament is important for legislation, and for democracy as well. And it is not time or speed that is important, but rather it takes time to enforce democracy and properly pass laws. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President, High Representative. I was also a member of the European Parliament's election observation mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to witness the hope and expectation for a better future with which people stood and waited at the polling stations to cast their votes.
We know today that these expectations were not met.
Although the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were not fair or democratic.
We need to address this offensively, as colleague Nedeljewa has also done in her report.
The previous president, Yusuf Kabila, declared himself the winner of the election. The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have flared up again, and it is unclear whether third countries like Rwanda are involved.
The civilian population is the one that suffers in every case, and has not been able to live in peace and quiet for decades now.
The country's wealth is squandered in a swamp of corruption. In all international evaluations, the Congo remains in one of the last places.

The international community of states, particularly the European Union with its capabilities, must increase pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow for genuine democracy in his country. He has an opportunity to do so during the next regional elections.
and that the Congolese army does not harass the civilian population, but finally takes international fugitives for crimes against humanity like Bosko and Ndanganga and brings them to justice.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to no longer supplying any more weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Colleagues, the Tupac is intended to create additional enforcement rights against crisis countries in the Eurozone.
The European Semester, which was established as a framework for necessary and improved coordination of financial and economic policy, is to be given teeth.
According to the Commission's wishes, member states should be forced to accept financial aid.
The Six-Pack has already established extensive sanctioning possibilities that can be imposed on Eurozone countries with financial problems.
The European Semester is already being perceived by citizens more as a dismantling of democracy than as a sensible economic policy coordination instrument.
At the same time, the German government is openly threatening Greek citizens with expulsion from the Eurozone if they make the wrong decision in Sunday's election.
Why don't we stop these humiliating and undemocratic threats?
In a situation where the Euro crisis has once again dramatically escalated, I am thinking of Spain and Cyprus, it is not helpful to publicly shame member states that are in the midst of a crisis.
We should finally develop solutions. The TUPEX rapporteurs have developed some very sensible approaches to this end.
Elisa Ferreira did indeed mention the debt redemption fund. This would be a worthwhile and sensible measure to combat debt.
but also Jean-Paul Gauzets proposal for an orderly state bankruptcy.
However, it is crucial that Europe makes a joint and solidaric effort to put the Eurozone back on a growth path.
The strong countries in Europe must stop being complacent and pointing fingers at their partner countries.
They need to start doing their homework, invest in growth, and take responsibility.
The one-sided austerity policy à la Merkel has simply failed as a solution to the crisis.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues. In June 2010, the EU heads of government finally realized that the European community needs a better coordinated financial and economic policy.
At the summit, they essentially invented the European Semester.
It is indeed entirely correct that members of an economic and monetary union cannot solely focus on how their policies affect businesses, workers, and consumers in their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.
An internal market without coordination in economic, wage, and social policy presents a great temptation for member states to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can economically, but also politically, bring the monetary union to its knees.
And that is exactly the situation the EU is currently facing.

The German economy has been draining the lifeblood from its neighbors for years, failing to stimulate growth through investment and wage increases. Instead, Berlin has brought the Eurozone to the brink of ruin with a decade of aggressive export policies.
That is why it is encouraging that the Commission is slowly getting to grips with this core problem of the Euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and is making corresponding suggestions.

The Federal Republic is quite rightly being called upon to invest more in education, research and childcare. And quite rightly, the Commission is being called upon to stop the abuse of mini-jobs and to align wage growth with productivity growth.
This is a late, but important realization.
And I hope, Commissioner, Mr Rehn, that you will vigorously advocate this demand to the German government, even if there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, esteemed colleagues. First of all, I would like to express my gratitude to the Commission, especially Commissioner Barnier. For the simple reason that the experience from the last legislative period, before 2009,

It was the case that, with the exception of a very brief moment of awakening when the proposal for the European Private Company was put forward, Mr McCreevy, the predecessor of Commissioner Barnier, effectively put company law to sleep. And we have not managed to address this important issue, which is also significant for the internal market, in these five years.
have progressed.
Fortunately, that has fundamentally changed.

In the meantime, there are a variety of consultation documents from the European Commission, and an expert group has been established to address the issue of further developing company law. We currently have a very timely consultation, which, as a Parliament, we are naturally also addressing.

The Legal Committee has decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report. This is simply because a report would require additional time and, of course, would also be somewhat more detailed.

We have chosen the method of an oral question to the Commission in order to be able to discuss this issue with the Commission, with Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time to make clear in a subsequent resolution our position as Parliament on what should happen now.
I believe that it is necessary to develop a new action plan for European company law, similar to the one we had about ten years ago. And this for many reasons.
There are gaps within European company law. Real gaps, which essentially mean that the single market is not complete.
I want to mention the example of the lack of the 14th directive on seat relocation. Most of it is based on a very typical example of such a gap.
Parliament has called for this twice in the legislative reports, demanding that the European Commission come up with concrete proposals on this matter.
There is also the expert panel appointed by the European Commission itself, which has also expressed the same opinion.
It is simply one of the fundamental freedoms in the internal market that a company must be able to move within the internal market, including with regard to its registered office.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

However, against this backdrop, I must also criticize the fact that the European Commission's statement on the 14th Directive so far actually falls well short of Parliament's expectations and, in our opinion, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
But we are confident that, in the course of further work, if it comes to an action plan, this proposal will hopefully be included in the action plan after all.
Another important point in corporate law is the question of the further development of corporate law with the aim of reducing burdens for companies.
We already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example on the subject of competition.
But I believe there is also more to be done and there are further aspects that will be clarified during the consultation.
We are also expecting further proposals from the Commission here.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the issue of the European Private Company, which is currently stuck in the Council.

If there are individual member states in the EU - and I can express my own opinion here - if there are individual member states that are not able to break the deadlock on their own due to a lack of decision-making power,

If we want to move Europe forward, then we must consider using the instrument of enhanced cooperation, as we have done with other initiatives such as patents and family law, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
And I would ask the Commission to give this issue some serious thought.
Another open issue is the question of applicable law, i.e. a kind of Rome regulation for cross-border problems in company law.
I also believe that this issue requires further investigation and discussion, and I would ask the Commission to do so.
this is also closely related to
the insolvency law, but it has already been announced that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the foreseeable future.
You see, there is a huge amount of work to be done in corporate law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken the initiative here once again and that it is clear that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can also represent progress in shaping the internal market.
Parliament supports this in principle and in approach.
We will, of course, discuss the details further. We will certainly do that.
But for that, thanks to the Commission.
And now, of course, we would be pleased if the Commission would actually take up our initiatives and turn the concrete proposals into reality. Thank you.
Dear Commissioner, I greatly appreciate your proposal regarding productivity-oriented wage policy.
But you cut a deal with Mrs. Merkel on the minimum wage, and I don't believe you about the question of job creation in the healthcare sector.
How is new work supposed to be created there when the Commission has already forced southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by up to half?

How can employment in the healthcare sector grow if, in the new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester, the Commission is forcing some member states to further reduce their healthcare spending?
I fear this point in this plan is merely announcement politics, not a real initiative for new jobs.
On the contrary, due to austerity measures, there is already a shortage of medical supplies and medications, not just in Greece.
I think that those who are constantly setting up new bailouts for banks must now work towards a bailout for the people, especially for securing medical care in the crisis countries. Thank you.
Yes, thank you. The mood among countless pro-Europeans like myself is one of frightened horror at what is currently happening in Europe.
It is, after all, encouraging that it is now being stated much more clearly what we are dealing with and that Italy is not being ignored either.

You know yourselves that you are caught in a series of traps, not only in the trap of debt and growth, but also in the trap of trust and in the trap of power. Addressed to the Commission and also to the Council.
Unfortunately, they have so far neglected to actually address the central issue of the financial sector's detachment from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here is repeatedly evaluated in expert opinions as no serious limits have been set on the shadow banking system.
Furthermore, we are dealing with systemic risks. The issue of "too big to fail" has not been adequately addressed, and there is little need to say anything about the rating agencies.
As you prepare for the summit, I can only urge you to restore credibility in Europe by seriously addressing the issue of power between the real economy and the financial sector.
In short, they are finally working credibly to ensure that the banks are brought to heel and that the citizens are not always left to bear the burden.

Mr. Kollege Fehrmann, you come from a country that has rejected the euro, but presumably with the central argument that one wants to retain the flexibility of devaluation, especially for socio-political reasons.
In light of the experiences you have now had in Sweden, would you recommend that the Greeks also leave the Eurozone in order to be able to actively use this socio-political instrument of devaluation?
Yes, thank you very much, Mr President. I would also like to express my sincere thanks to the shadow rapporteurs and to the rapporteur.
We adopted this report in the Environment Committee with a substantial majority, with 62 votes in favor, zero votes against, and no abstentions.
This shows that we are actually very, very closely aligned there, including when it comes to compromises.

And of course, the top priority in these legislative procedures must be a high level of protection, a high level of consumer protection, especially for the most vulnerable members of our society, for children who need protection.
And when it comes to gluten intolerance, this is a problem. And especially in kindergarten.
If you take a look around, I have two children of this age, and considering the prevalence of allergies and intolerances there, I believe we were in the right place.
And we should also discuss this with each other in the second reading, with the Council and the Commission.
And I think that we will then also arrive at a good result.

Thank you very much. A report about a traffic accident over the weekend involving an HGV driver who fell asleep from exhaustion and drove into the ditch has once again confirmed to me how necessary it is
clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest periods and their monitoring using a digital tachograph is important for us, for road safety, and also for the people affected themselves.
The digital roofograph represents a certain innovation. It has new problems, but also old ones.
The new problems arise from new manipulation possibilities, which we also need to control technically.
The old problems are those that we can observe, so to speak, in the control or lack of control in various member states.
What we are now regulating anew has to take into account, in my view, several essential factors. Firstly, that not every time when no journey is recorded automatically results in a rest period.
because many drivers have to load and unload, and this is naturally also considered working time.
The second problem is that the speed records were removed from the file.
I think that's wrong, because there are also major accident risks here.
We also want to have weight sensors and we also want to have a hotline to report fraud, which is anonymous and can be traced.
What I will also be bringing forward is a motion that animal transport control be included in this regulation.
I think this is important because it is also a central element of our legislation.

Madam President, many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not have any lasting disabilities if professional medical help had been provided quickly enough after their accident, that is, within the first so-called "golden hour".
We would be a significant step closer to Vision Zero.
Well, the eCall system we are discussing today cannot prevent accidents. Nor does it absolve anyone from the duty to provide first aid.
It is only used to automatically inform an emergency response center in the event of a serious accident.
In order to prevent misuse and overloading due to minor accidents, it must establish linguistic contact with the accident vehicle.
Only when the emergency call is confirmed or no one responds anymore, are emergency doctors sent to the accident site, equipped with a few, but life-critical pieces of information.
The responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies subsidiarily with the Member States.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the e-call system remains dormant, meaning it does not send any signals or data and cannot be located.
From a data protection perspective, it is therefore far superior to a mobile phone.
The system only becomes active when it is automatically awakened by sensors or manually triggered by a conscious action.
It then sends an agreed minimum set of information to an emergency operations center,
Europe-wide, uniform standards and specifications will ensure that this data is recognized, evaluated, and handled upon arrival as an emergency call.
Therefore, the member states must also upgrade and expand their emergency medical service chains accordingly.

We want this eCall emergency call system to be based on the EU-wide emergency number 112, to be free of charge for users, to work throughout the EU, and to be compatible with the emergency call systems of neighbouring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable technology, neutral, open system architecture.
Other intelligent public transport services, such as real-time traffic information or availability of parking spaces, can also be offered through these systems at a later date.
In recognition of the automotive industry's outstanding achievements in providing private emergency call systems, these should retain their legitimacy alongside the public 112-based e-call.
Users can also choose such a system based on comprehensive information.
This may also involve costs.
use of data for workshop insurance, towing services or other service providers
A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme highlights a small problem we've created for ourselves today.

Because if this brewery or the beverage retailer is 107 kilometers away from my home, I no longer have a chance that they will continue to offer me their products in the future, without having to buy a new tachograph, without new bureaucracy.

And that is why, dear colleagues, I voted against this resolution today, because I believe that we should not impose too much on our small and medium-sized entrepreneurs. There were many points that we were able to include, which were positive, thank God.
It was actually planned that only 50 kilometers within the radius of a regional provider would be accepted.
That was completely absurd of the EU Commission.
So, maybe 100 kilometers is just about feasible.
But what if it goes beyond that?
Also, I think it's exaggerated.
And one last point, as a representative of an employees' organization in the CSU, I must say: with this regulation, we are creating complete control over employees.
Why?
For example, someone who is responsible for construction or who sells beverages or brewery products is completely monitored throughout the entire workday via GPS.
For these reasons, and also for data protection reasons, I consider what we have decided today to be highly questionable, and I would like to reiterate why I voted against it.
Yes, thank you very much for this question.
Why I'm not waiting for this decision,
I waited for the approval of the European People's Party in the Legal Affairs Committee when we were still in the process of asking the necessary questions about legal certainty regarding ACTA.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
They did not want that. Now it is obvious that the ECJ is to be used for delay. That is clear.
Why I said that about the broad scope for interpretation,
Because, as you have asked two questions, I must answer both of them, unfortunately that is the case.
because you can read out and interpret into these broad formulations the surveillance of the internet, the auxiliary police, ISPs, everything.
And that means legal uncertainty. Legal uncertainty is not helpful for our economy either, ladies and gentlemen.
Mr Leichtfried, I would like to ask you, are you in favour of discussing the modernisation of copyright at European level?
or are they completely against the rejection of any intellectual property.
And how do you envision the E-Commerce Directive being adapted to modern conditions in the future?
From your statement, I gather that you reject any debate on these issues and do not stand for intellectual property.
Is that correct or how do I see it?
Yes, thank you very much. This is not about individual facts that we need to discuss here, but about the fundamental question of how we stand on democracy and civil liberties.
And when we look at the Akta, we see that it is in a way symbolic of a lack of transparency, of a lack of democracy, of a violation of fundamental rights, because it was negotiated in secret.

and was brought about in an undemocratic manner, because the free use of the Internet simply would no longer be possible afterwards, and neither would the freedom to use generics to the same extent as before.
These are the reasons why millions of people have taken to the streets and have already voted against ACTA.
Yes, ACTA has been voted on, on the streets, on the internet, in relation to the Committee on Petitions, in very many countries, not only within the EU, but also in the EU.
also outside the EU. And I believe we must not ignore this vote. This is a vote of direct democracy by many citizens who elected us.
I can only tell you to put the file away, that would be decent.

Madam President of the Council, as rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have completed two procedures under your presidency: the Financial Regulation, which provides a set of rules for the upcoming MFF period, and the OLAF procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation has been pending in the Council, and you have brought this process to a close based on the results of the Polish presidency.
I would like to thank you for two truly very, very dedicated financial officers who have worked on these files and also reached out to the ambassadors.
they will be missed, his efficiency as a negotiator will be missed.
They have truly earned themselves a reputation for looking after the financial interests of the European Union.
Thank you very much.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking here now as the representative of my group and would like to support the motion proposed by my colleague Mr Fjellner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This requires careful handling of the issue of intellectual property rights.
In order to clarify the outstanding issues, the European Commission has submitted this proposal, which it has presented to us, to the European Court of Justice for an opinion.
I believe that respect for the highest court of the European Union alone demands that we wait for this decision.
There is objectively no reason at all to make this decision today.
No one is prevented from voting against it once the Court has presented its decision and its opinion.
But the decision that will then be made will take place in a different consciousness, in a different awareness than today.
I don't mean to say that the wrong way drivers on the Internet highway should determine our policy. And that's why I ask you to support this motion. Thank you.
As always, when colleague Turmes speaks, he is very wise, and one would wish that what he says had much more influence on European politics.
I wanted to follow up on that.
Of course, these project bonds are a great idea, but only if they are sustainable and if the necessary political foundations are established.
We run the risk of using guarantees to hedge against risks that we cannot control politically.

Specifically, the energy transition in Germany would require a 3,800-kilometer grid network, but only 100 kilometers of these corresponding high-voltage transmission lines have been built, partly due to resistance from citizens, including those who are very environmentally conscious.
We need to come up with something from politics.

One idea would be to create joint TEN corridors, combining not only high-speed rail lines and broadband networks, but also constructing corresponding pipeline networks above them, perhaps alongside the highways.
This does, however, require a much more comprehensive plan than has been provided so far, but I would like to at least suggest this at this point.

Dear colleagues, I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements in the European Union. However, I am also aware that a country's borders are always a very sensitive issue for our member states and will always remain so.
I am aware that the problems between the member states regarding Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
And there are various problems.
And by ignoring them, you don't make the problems better, and you don't solve them better either.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic and it would never occur to anyone here to want to close the border just because we are having problems.
But I also ask the Commission for support in this area, not for restrictions and reprimands.
The veil investigation was established because we want to ensure security while also allowing freedom of travel.
And if we carry out undercover operations successfully, particularly at the borders with the Czech Republic, where one or another drug dealer is involved in many cases, not just a few instances,

If they are trying to secure a transition, then I think it would be a good idea for the German Minister of the Interior and the Czech Minister to sit down together and work out a joint solution to the problems at the border.
And the Commission should not regulate this, but rather act positively and supportively.

We want to put the populists in their place, but solve the real problems together. That is why I also ask the Council to work together with Parliament to find a solution so that we can successfully pass the Schengen dossiers, so that we have freedom of travel and at the same time ensure the security of citizens.
Thank you. The cases of disproportionate border controls that Parliament lists in its question also show why the Council actually wants to exclude Parliament from Schengen.
The Council wants to continue undermining freedom of travel without involving Parliament or without any form of parliamentary control, without any form of public scrutiny.
No wonder, then, that they prefer to pat themselves on the back in back rooms, away from uncomfortable questions.

It is no wonder that the German government wants to rule out any evaluation of internal borders altogether, without evaluation, and thus does not want to look at how much freedom of travel is being restricted.
However, Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people of Europe and therefore also to the European Parliament. Thank you very much.

Dear Mr President of the Council of the European Union, dear Dimitris Christofias, it is a special moment for me today and for my group to be able to welcome you here in your capacity as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also pleased that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person is at the helm of the EU whom we can count among our political family.
You are taking over the presidency at a time when the European Union is facing enormous challenges. And it is time to set the course for whether the European Union...
Will the Union actually have a future, or will it turn out to be, and that would be a historic defeat in my view, a footnote in history?

After the discussions we have had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the chairmen of the parliamentary groups and parties in your country, I know that you are counting on this
You have prepared for the presidency excellently and are also aware of the significance of your task.
But, and you have also made this clear today, you deliberately want to draw the attention of those in power to the living conditions of people.
And I can tell you here, after all I've heard in recent years, this is the first time a President of the European Union has done and announced exactly that, and said, this tone.
I have long missed hearing in official speeches that this is about the people, it is about those who are not responsible for us being in this crisis, but who have to bear the greatest burdens.
It is difficult to implement this approach exactly.
I believe, however, that a great deal would already be achieved, and you will do this, I am quite sure, if you encourage people, above all, to engage with your presidency and, as you express it,
to ensure that they stand up for their rights and that they contribute to ensuring that the Council and the European institutions are fully aware of this task.
We keep talking about the euro and its stability, about the necessity, which I also see, that it is important for the functioning of the European Union and for the Eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
There were political conditions for this, which were defined.

It can never be the goal of the European Union to accept, for the sake of a functioning euro, that people in the European Union must go hungry, that health systems collapse, that municipal administrations have to cease their work.
Something has gone wrong here.
It is not what we can call the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support your demand that it must be about social cohesion, about solidarity between the individual member states, but also between the various population groups.
And the European Union must not allow itself to be repeatedly used as an instrument or spokesperson for a specific segment of the population, nor should it present itself in this way.

And one last point I would like to address, of course, to emphasize that everything you have mentioned in your priorities is important to us and that we will support the points that go in this direction, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to ensure that people are no longer afraid.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
And I think that some decisions in recent weeks and months, particularly in the elections in Greece and the referendum votes in Ireland, were also driven by fear.
And if the leaders of the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Best of luck with your work!
Colleagues, I believe that we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-rapporteurs.
The colleague will find it very, very important to work on this file quickly and reliably in the coming weeks and months.

The eyes of the world are currently on us and on the Council, waiting to see if we will take this step to overcome the banking crisis in Europe through a further step towards European integration, namely through a European Banking Union.
It should be noted that the Parliament demanded this with a broad majority two years ago.
We have conducted 26 trilogues.
We have taken a step in this direction, but unfortunately not as far as would have been necessary.
Additional billions in bills have been generated as a result.
It is good that the Council has now drawn the necessary conclusions and wants to take this step to further deepen the Eurozone.
And it is commendable that the Commission has drawn up the proposals so quickly.
However, there are some difficulties associated with the Council's decision that the ECB should become the eurozone's supervisor.
In the Council, this leads to unanimity and means that Parliament does not have codecision powers on this issue.
Based on the experience with the supervisory package, this is not acceptable,

And that is why it is important that we work quickly here, but also that we negotiate this proposal on changes to the ECB together with the necessary changes to the existing supervisory regime as a package, and in doing so, effectively establish the principle of democratic participation by Parliament.
Democracies also face additional challenges.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has no responsibilities to date.

If it is now to be responsible for banking supervision, Parliament needs full budgetary rights, full control rights, the right to ask questions, the right to appoint, and I am sure that Parliament will fight for these rights by a large majority.

The complex issues that go beyond this, such as the internal market, consumer protection, and the balance between European power and financial responsibility, will have to be thoroughly discussed in the coming weeks. Thank you.
Thank you. By proposing to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is attempting to push these countries into free trade agreements.

These are not free trade agreements, as the term "economic partnerships" suggests, but are solely concerned with the interests of the EU and not with the development interests of the partner countries.
This is completely contrary to the EU's goal of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments towards this objective.
Countries such as Cameroon, Ivory Coast, and Namibia would be severely affected by this restriction.
Regional integration projects such as those in Southeast Africa would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
South-South cooperation would be at an end.
We cannot advocate for free trade in the world and only mean that other countries should kindly buy our goods.
If the Commission really believes that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The development committee of this house has recommended rejecting the Commission's proposal.
And we should support this in the plenary session.
Thank you. There are an enormous number of human rights problems in both Central America and Peru and Colombia.
And we, as EU Members of Parliament, cannot simply close our eyes to this.
We will thoroughly examine the roadmap for human rights demanded by the EP in the case of Colombia and Peru, once it is drawn up.
It must have substance and be binding, and include initial results such as the conviction of offenders and the safe return of displaced persons to their land.
And of course it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.
We Greens believe it is right that the Trade Committee is demanding environmental and social standards in the proposed regulation on safeguard clauses, and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The Trilogue must then confirm these, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
In fact, the EU must do much more to keep an eye on the situation on the ground and, above all, the impact on the local population.
And that is why we Greens demand a proper impact assessment before every negotiation, one that not only examines the economic consequences for the EU, but also the impact on human rights.
Yes, thank you. Mr Barroso, I made it clear in the first round what I wanted to focus on.
I am concerned with my group's expectation of the Commission to fulfill its responsibilities in the relevant bodies, such as the Troika, in order to make it clear that we as
European institutions stand for ensuring that people are not driven further into poverty, that working hours are not shortened, and that ecological and social standards are not undermined.
That is their task.

And if we succeed in making this clear, we will also be sending a signal to the people who are protesting by the thousands and hundreds of thousands these days, who have taken to the streets, and with whom we, as a group, also express solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or in Barcelona.
I heard the news this morning that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and going on strike.
Where have we ended up, where people in deep social and personal distress can no longer receive any help and support because the healthcare system has collapsed?
here we really need to finally take action
And I'll say one more thing: an approach that is in the minds of many responsible people is that the people in Greece and in other countries have been living beyond their means.
They must be punished for it today and must endure sanctions.
is unfit to strengthen a European community, a community of solidarity.
I am not accusing you of this, Mr. Barroso, but this is an approach that is prevalent in many countries and, unfortunately, is also present in my own approach time and time again.
Mr. Chairman, I admit, I made a mistake.
I would like to make a statement not on this report, but on the Morera report on the agreement on immediate autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan.
I would then ask to be called up again.

Thank you, Madam President. The new directive creates a framework for dealing with books, newspapers, artworks, films, musical pieces, and TV productions that are protected by copyright, but for which the rightful owner cannot be identified or located.
Accordingly, books, films, photos, or other intellectual creations for which no rightful owner can be found should also be made available to the public.
And thus a cultural treasure is unearthed.
For us on the Culture Committee, it was particularly important to emphasize the special significance of the diversity of the European Union's cultural heritage in this legislative initiative.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting stations, there are countless unused works, and simply because their rightful owner is not known, they have not been made available up to now.
That changes with the directive,
In the future, it will enable the use of this cultural asset, provided that a thorough search is carried out prior to publication.
This is a very important point, so that it is not said lightly that we cannot find the rightful owner.
Because a balance had to be found between the real existing rights of the creators of works and the need of the public to be able to use such works, where the rights situation cannot be clarified.
A particular focus for us was also ensuring that both known and unknown rights holders continue to be fully protected.
And where the rights holders cannot be found, the draft makes it possible to use the digitization of orphan works.
Projects like Europeana and other major European digitization projects, as well as our museums, archives, educational institutions, and public broadcasting will sort things out.
In the future, however, it must also be about opening up the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers and also to the public.
In my opinion, this draft of guidelines and the compromise that has now been reached is indeed a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
And I believe that the cultural treasure that has been accumulated in Hing holds enormous potential.
We should continue to work on this when revising the directive in two years. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. Chairman, esteemed Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council. I would be pleased if we could also include clear language in the 2013 proposal.
We would like to see signals from the Council on how we can expand the growth and competitiveness potential in Europe and, above all, how we can once again provide employment for young people.
Could you please tell us in which budget lines you intend to promote youth employment and focus on entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises?
We know that the ZIP program is the essential prerequisite for this. I only see cuts by the Council here.
or the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs programme or the programme for media pluralism. Here there are only cuts.
Do you really believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by making cuts in areas that guarantee growth and employment?
I heard that a growth and employment package is to be proposed by the Council.
Where can this be found in this budget, which has been submitted by the Council?
Nordsee-Werken-Emmen had to file for insolvency last Wednesday because a guarantee from the Lower Saxony state government was not unexpectedly renewed.
This company, with 700 skilled jobs, is in the process of transforming from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be saved through a bulk loan and that jobs can also be saved. Because the 700 colleagues at SIAC and Nordseewerke have already had to accept significant cuts in their wages.

And that is why I ask the Commission to examine this procedure benevolently, but also promptly, so that these 700 jobs are not jeopardized, because these 700 jobs are needed to organize the energy transition and to organize sustainable energy on the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the colleagues there suffer because of the state government's poor crisis management.
Milieu goods often look harmless, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes, they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes that can use them to control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile phone software from Nokia Siemens Networks that played into the hands of Iranian security forces in suppressing the Green protest movement.
Protesters were abducted en masse, arrested, tortured, and sentenced to death.
And that is just one example of many.
In addition, the Commission is said to be promoting these dubious dual-use goods through its catalogue of measures for an innovative and competitive security industry.
The goal is to achieve better utilization of synergies between security and defense technologies.
We risk literally selling out human rights, as well as our security interests, for the sake of a questionable industrial policy.
That is why I would like to ask you to approve the amendments from us and the Social Democrats and everyone else.
Yes, I would like to ask my female colleague Regner, what do you think the trade unions could do to combat youth unemployment in Spain and Portugal, for example?
Demonstrations will be too few.
What active policy could the internal market implement here?
Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I believe that with today's debate on MiFID we are entering the core area of financial market regulation.
Having made it through this legislative period, it is now about regulating the financial markets and not just looking at individual products, as we have done in the past.
I just want to mention a few key words.
We certainly didn't make things easy for each other last year.

We conducted a hearing in committee, we surveyed all stakeholders and all interested groups, and based on that, we developed a result through various processes, working documents, and similar things, which we will present to the plenary for a vote today and tomorrow.
I want to highlight a few points.
Topic number one, market structure.

On the one hand, we must of course acknowledge that a great deal has happened in the financial markets in recent years. This is of interest to us, but as a Parliament, we want to ensure that all trading in financial instruments takes place within the MiFID framework. That is why we are also introducing a new category under many conditions.

have agreed to the so-called Organized Trading Facilities, where only non-equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is to be prohibited, and where, according to the execution in terms of execution and transaction and interaction of the clients, an appropriate execution can take place at their own discretion.
I believe that this will make an important contribution to ensuring that the entire range of OTC securities traded is conducted within the MiFID framework.
Another major issue that was not addressed in the last MiFID is so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.

Here too, our goal was to establish clear rules of the game, so that this area, which can be very dangerous and can also be used manipulatively, is subject to strict regulations with minimum holding periods.

Trading interruption options, with the ability to test algorithms, with the possibility of a supervisory structure to review algorithms, with the introduction of a so-called tick-size regime, a minimum price size, and through corresponding fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of commodity futures markets.

I do believe that we have a special responsibility here to limit the speculative component in genuine futures markets to such an extent that we do not contribute, through misguided regulations, to people in the third and fourth world being unable to buy food.
We have therefore adopted a two-pronged approach, with the aim of curbing speculation, but without harming the real economy.
We want to achieve this with position limits, with strict upper limits on the number of contracts or positions.
However, we also want to ensure that those who can prove that they really need a product are not suddenly engaging in speculative market activity by implementing a so-called position check system.
Another issue that concerns us greatly is the area of investor protection.
I would just like to point out here that we have chosen a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
The aim here is to identify the needs of specific customer groups,
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex documents.

It is about defining appropriate products for target groups, conducting product tests, telephone recording, appropriate consultations, disclosure obligations. But, and I would like to briefly hint at this, it is about applying subsidiarity in the area of commissions.
Member States should have the opportunity to make appropriate adjustments in accordance with their structures.
I think we're in the right area here.
When my time is up, I want to thank everyone who has contributed here.
I find it a shame that one only gets four minutes of speaking time for such a difficult dossier.
I would like to thank all my fellow Members who have contributed here, and the Commission for its very constructive role in recent weeks and months.

And I hope that with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow, we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council in order to conclude this important dossier as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, first of all, thank you very much for the overall good cooperation on this report.
We have been able to further improve a Commission proposal at key points, which already took major steps in the right direction.
There will be more transparency in the area of market structures, more comprehensive transparency, especially in the area of derivatives trading.

under the Mifid framework. The decisions in the area of high-frequency trading, our compromise, go much further than what the Commission had originally proposed and deserve the support of Parliament as a whole.
And even on the issues that have provoked widespread public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

In the area of commodity and food speculation, after major and difficult debates, it must be said that the regulations are now much stronger than the Commission's decisions, because position limits are now being established as binding.
However, we still need further changes in this area to close any remaining gaps.
And I hope for further amendments here through the plenary vote and eventually also in the trialogue.
And it is gratifying that Mr. Barnier has already signaled his support for the Parliament's more far-reaching proposal.
However, where the report has weaknesses is in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the ability to ban products, which is progress, but we still have no changes in the area of commission-driven advice.
The distribution of financial products is still not primarily oriented towards the interests of customers, but is heavily dominated by which product offers the most commissions.
Consumers in Germany, and throughout the EU, have lost a lot of money.
Remember the open-ended real estate funds.
Unfortunately, for citizens in France, Italy, Spain, and Germany, not much will change even after our compromise.
The basic principle will continue to be commission-oriented.
To refer to subsidiarity here is a bit too simplistic.
I would have liked to see stronger rules here.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, as the saying goes, all good things come to those who wait.
The report on type approval for L-category vehicles has ultimately turned out to be a good report.
The work took longer overall than we all thought, and especially than we had hoped. And there were far more pitfalls than we would have liked.
But at this point, I would like to once again express my heartfelt thanks to the rapporteur, Mr. Vandekamp, for the truly cooperative and excellent collaboration.
Together, we have still been able to achieve a lot in the negotiations with the member states.
As the rapporteur for my group, I recommend that we approve this report. However, it could have been much better.
And by better, my highly esteemed colleagues, I mean safer.
For us Social Democrats, the safety of vehicles and thus the safety of drivers has been a priority from the very beginning. This is especially true for the safety of scooter and motorcycle riders.
The number of motorcyclists involved in accidents has remained constant for years.
In general, the number of accident fatalities in Europe is decreasing. However, this is not the case for motorcycle accidents.
Reducing the number of motorcyclists and scooter riders killed is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on Europe's roads - that was and is my goal.
Every death is one too many.
This issue must be addressed in depth, especially in a regulation that is so advantageous for the internal market.
I am still convinced that this can be achieved using effective anti-lock braking system (ABS) technologies.
And I am equally convinced of its cost-effectiveness.
It is simply not true that ABS is too expensive.

Nevertheless, we have achieved that, starting in 2016, all new motorcycle models and, starting in 2017, all existing motorcycle models with a displacement of 125cc or more must be equipped with ABS by the manufacturer.
Motor scooters can be equipped with ABS or combined braking systems, at the discretion of the manufacturer.
Unfortunately, we must admit that we have not achieved any improvements to the Commission's proposal on this point.
I would have liked to see much more here. But the Commission and the Member States have, to put it mildly, shown themselves to be very slow to act.
Nevertheless, we managed to get the Commission to present a report in 2019.
The report must be based on traffic accident data from the member states and is intended to investigate the mandatory installation of ABS on motor scooters.
It shall also be forwarded to the Parliament and the Council.
On the basis of this report, the Commission will then consider making the installation of ABS in scooters mandatory.
You see, the topic remains very, very much alive.
Therefore, we will attempt to close the mandatory legislative gap starting in 2019.
I am sure that the collected data will prove me right.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for two-wheel drivers in Europe and that accident numbers will decrease in the future. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Matthias Grote, there is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
and I believe that applies to what we are discussing here today.
I am very much in favor of us discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new entry into the energy markets through unconventional resources, both in gas, predominantly in gas, but also in oil and

I believe it is neither appropriate to succumb to great euphoria about the great gas future, nor is it appropriate, as some of my colleagues from the Greens and the Left have done here, to paint large horror and scare scenarios on the wall that have nothing to do with reality.

I think we need to bear in mind that these unconventional resources have the potential to change all the energy supply relationships we know between suppliers and demand, and that the economic calculations of existing energy sources are also being called into question.
we should face the development

I think we should acknowledge that this can also be an opportunity for Europe, not just a risk. We should prepare ourselves to positively embrace and utilize new technologies, to fairly weigh the opportunities and risks, and not to fall into ideological debates. Thank you.
Commissioner, thank you for your answer. It does not entirely satisfy me.
because I think it's a very very long time, a year between the notification that the complaint has been received and possibly only receiving a response so late.
I believe that a complainant who takes the trouble to file a complaint - and usually he has already gone through the entire legal process in his member state - deserves more.
We rely on citizens to engage with the European Union.
If they do it in this form, we should treat them accordingly

And I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have a procedure here that is clearly formalized and clearly regulates the rights. This is now a declaration about how the Commission wants to handle this.
On another point. I have no objection if it serves the cause that one tries to reach a kind of consensual clarification together with the member state.
But that will not always be enough.
We observe that, for example, things move relatively quickly in economic matters when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.
But when it comes to environmental issues and similar matters, where a large number of citizens demand the European Union's involvement or social rights, things become a bit more challenging.
I believe that these facts also need to be clearly taken into account.
And for the next report, I hope that we will have a clear formalization of the complainant's rights vis-à-vis the Commission, which are truly clear and well communicated.
Once again, if we really want European law to be applied, after we have gone through so many procedures here in the European Parliament, in the Council,
We have decided together. Then we must inform those who are taking care of it, those who are really committed to Europe, as well and as precisely as possible.
That is a very, very important concern for me.
And I will also closely observe what has developed here next time. Thank you.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, five years ago the EU's Central Asia strategy was launched.
If one asks today for an assessment of this strategy, the evaluation is mixed.

We see how individual member states strive to establish good economic relations, particularly with the resource-rich countries in this region. On the other hand, these efforts are not making progress.
Accompanying states in their transformation process towards modern democratic societies or, as the recent events in Kazakhstan show, development is even characterized by setbacks.

Nevertheless, or precisely for this reason, the European Union and its member states must express their influence in this region more strongly together, also and especially towards Kazakhstan, which has now become a major supplier for several EU countries.

Isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only lead to the fact that competitors for influence in this geopolitically important country, for whom the push for compliance with civil and human rights is not as important, could assert their influence even more strongly than before.
The linking of economic interests with the commitment to safeguarding citizens' rights is the core of the Central Asia strategy.
This should also form the basis for further negotiations on a partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan.
The present report provides a good orientation for this. Many thanks.
Ladies and gentlemen of the absent Council, perhaps you are following us on the Parliament's video stream, since you obviously have neither the capacity nor the desire to speak with us live.
I consider the Council's absence here and today as a gross disregard for Parliament.
Instead of evading this debate, you should rather reveal your secret as to why you are opposed to any improvement of personal data protection in the fields of police and justice through a directive.

The police and the judiciary have, for years, been a hotbed of data protection violations, as we know. Not only in the case of SWIFT, but also on a daily basis, for example, when data of citizens who are demonstrating against Nazis is unlawfully collected and stored.
We need the same protection standards for the public and private sectors, as well as for the police and the judiciary. This is what it's all about, in order to be able to guarantee citizens' rights.
If the Council demands that the Parliament constructively participate in data protection-related regulations such as EU-PNA or Europol, then this must surely also apply to the Council in reverse.
That is why I demand that you finally put an end to the blockade policy in the area of data protection.
